1. Which of the following methods can be used to identify faded tattoos?

* Ultraviolet lamp

* Infra-red photography

* Variot’s method

* Rubbing and examination with a magnifying glass

* Mixture of papain in glycerin
questions.solution:
The methods to identify a faded tattoo are 1,2,4 (Option D).

A faded tattoo can be visualized by:

* Ultraviolet lamp examination

* Infrared photography 

* Rubbing the part and examining it using a magnifying glass

* High contrast photography

* Computer image enhancement

Techniques that can be used for the erasure of tattoos include:

* Dermabrasion using silver nitrate (Variot’s Method)

* A mixture of papain in glycerin

* Excision & skin grafting

* Scarification

* Carbon dioxide snow

* Electrolysis

Tattoos can be recognized in decomposed bodies and bodies recovered from water when the epidermis is removed. Some pigment migrates from the site of the tattoo to the body’s lymph nodes. Pigmentations of the axillary lymph nodes in upper extremities tattoos could be identified with the naked eye during autopsy.

questions.text: 2. A 42-year-old woman complains of an uncomfortable urge to move her legs, especially at night, which improves with movement. Her symptoms worsen during rest and disrupt her sleep. She was advised a dopaminergic transdermal patch as treatment, which most likely is:
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of restless leg syndrome. Rotigotine, a dopamine agonist, is available as a transdermal patch for treatment.

Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS) is a neurologic disorder characterized by:

* An urge to move the legs, often with an uncomfortable sensation

* Symptoms worsen during rest and improve with movement

* Symptoms typically worsen in the evening or at night

RLS is associated with periodic leg movements (PLMs) during sleep, which disrupt sleep and lead to daytime fatigue. It can be primary (genetic) or secondary to conditions such as iron deficiency anemia, pregnancy, or renal failure. The pathogenesis involves dopamine dysfunction.

The diagnosis is clinical but can be supported by polysomnography. First, general measures such as improved sleep hygiene are tried. If symptoms persist, pharmacological treatment includes low-dose dopamine agonists like Pramipexole, Ropinirole, or Rotigotine (transdermal patch). Levodopa and high-dose dopamine agonists may worsen symptoms (augmentation). Secondary RLS management should be focused on correcting the underlying condition.

Other options: 

Option A and C: Pramipexole and Ropinirole are dopamine agonists available in oral formulations, not transdermal patches.

Option B: Gabapentin is an alternative for RLS, especially in patients with comorbid neuropathic pain, but is not a dopaminergic drug. It is administered in oral, intravenous or transdermal formulations.

questions.text:
3. Arrange the following structures forming the bed of the tonsil in the correct sequence from within outwards.

* Pharyngobasilar Fascia

* Superior Constrictor 

* Buccopharyngeal Fascia

* Styloglossus

* Glossopharyngeal Nerve
questions.solution:
The structures forming the tonsillar bed from within outward are: 

* Pharyngobasilar Fascia

* Superior Constrictor 

* Buccopharyngeal Fascia

* Styloglossus

* Glossopharyngeal Nerve

The palatine tonsil is present in the tonsillar sinus between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches. The lateral surface is covered by a sheet of fascia which forms the hemicapsule of the tonsil which is an extension of the pharyngobasilar fascia. The paratonsillar vein lies in the loose areolar tissue on the lateral surface of the capsule, which is the plane of dissection during a tonsillectomy, hence there is a risk of damaging the vein during tonsillectomy. The structures lateral to the vein form the tonsillar bed.

The main arterial supply to the tonsils is from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. It enters the tonsil by piercing the superior constrictor. Veins drain via the palatine, pharyngeal, or facial veins. Lymphatics drain into the jugulodigastric node. The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear (referred to as otalgia) along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

questions.text: 5. A 30-year-old man is brought to a psychiatrist by his wife, who says that he has been talking to an imaginary friend while claiming to hear voices, has been suspecting his neighbors of attempting to kill him & has stopped grooming himself for the past 2 years. He has previously been prescribed Aripiprazole & Quetiapine, but his condition failed to improve. Which of the following is false about the drug that can be used in managing this patient now?

choices.text: The risk of agranulocytosis increases with the dose of the drug
It has strong affinity towards D4 receptors (D4>D2)
It is used in schizophrenic patients with suicidal ideation

questions.solution:
The given symptoms along with the history of prior treatment with Aripiprazole & Quetiapine with no significant improvement point towards Treatment-resistant schizophrenia. Clozapine is the drug of choice in the management of such cases. The risk of agranulocytosis does not increase with the dose of this drug.

Treatment-resistant Schizophrenia is the lack of response to 2 different antipsychotic agents given at an adequate dose for at least 6 weeks. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that has low affinity to D2 receptors & high affinity to D4 receptors (Option C). This causes the least extrapyramidal side effects. It is indicated in scenarios like

* Treatment-resistant Schizophrenia

* Schizophrenia with suicidal ideation (Option D)

* Treatment Resistant Mania

The common side effects include weight gain [Option A], anticholinergic side effects, excessive salivation, myocarditis, seizures & life-threatening agranulocytosis.

Agranulocytosis & myocarditis are dose-independent side effects. Hence, a patient on Clozapine must be closely followed up with WBC counts. Seizures are a dose-dependent side effect that occurs at high doses.

Pearl PM0339: Clozapine treatment guidelines

Clozapine treatment guidelines:

Indications:  Treatment resistant schizophrenia, schizophrenia associated with suicidality.

Adverse effects: 

* Agranulocytosis

* Seizures

* Myocarditis

* Metabolic syndrome

questions.text: 6. A 50-year-old man presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

* Paper chromatography - most sensitive test

* Nitric acid test

questions.text: 7. A 35-year-old female presented with an adnexal mass. CA-125 was slightly raised and LDH was elevated. Microscopy after tumor resection is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a 35-year-old woman presenting with adnexal mass with raised CA 125 and LDH and the given microscopy, suggests a diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. Beta hCG levels are raised only in 5% of women due to intermittent syncytiotrophoblast. However, serum LDH, placental alkaline phosphatase are used in monitoring individuals for disease recurrence. Dysgerminomas are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement.

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

questions.text: 8. A 26-year-old male, with a history of chronic cough, has a complaint of difficulty in breathing. On examination there are bilateral wheezing sounds. Chest X-ray showed bilateral air trapping within the lungs suggestive of emphysematous changes. The patient has a history of smoking and alcohol consumption. Which mutation is most likely present in this individual?
questions.solution:
PiZZ gene mutation is most likely present in this patient with clinical features and X-ray suggestive of emphysema leading to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

The most common clinically significant mutation causing α1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ. Homozygous individuals with PiZZ have less normal circulating α1-antitrypsin. So, they are at high risk of developing clinical diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.

Option B and D: PiMM and PiSS are normal genotypes seen in normal individuals and PiMM is the most common genotype.

questions.text: 9. Identify the following.

choices.text: A- Cancellous screw; B - Malleolar screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cancellous screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Cancellous screw
A- Cancellous screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Malleolar screw

questions.solution:
In the given image: 

* A represents a malleolar screw

* B represents a cortical screw

* C represents a cancellous screw

Identification features of the screws are as follows:

Malleolar screw: Modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip. It can be inserted without pre-drilling. These screws are used for internal fixation of malleolar fractures.



Cancellous screw: Larger thread, high pitch, compression by partial threading with a blunt tip. The larger threads provide for more purchase in the soft cancellous bone.



Cortical screw: Smaller thread, low pitch, compression produced by over drilling proximal cortex. The whole length of these screws is threaded and has a diameter of 2–4.5 mm. It functions as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.



Most orthopedic implants are made of titanium-based alloys because they are highly resistant to corrosion.

questions.text: 10. A female patient presents with complaints of mild fever, fatigue, and breathlessness. On examination, cyanosis is noted. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic "plop" is heard. The echocardiogram reveals a cardiac mass. A biopsy is taken and sent for histopathology. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis, fever, mid-diastolic "plop", cardiac mass, and biopsy showing globular myxoma cells within mucopolysaccharide ground substance are suggestive of myxoma. It can be seen associated with LAMB syndrome.

Myxomas are the most common type of primary cardiac tumor in adults. They occur at all ages, but mostly in the 3rd to 6th decades of life. They are more common in females and are usually located in the left atrium. Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.

 

Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant mucopolysaccharide ground substance. An abundant amorphous extracellular matrix contains scattered multinucleate myxoma cells, forming various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Cardiac myxomas can either be familial or sporadic. Familial syndromes associated with myxomas can have activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene or null mutations in PRKAR1A. Mutations in GNAS1 are associated with McCune-Albright syndrome. Mutations in the PRKAR1A gene are associated with Carney complex.

Carney Complex is a rare, autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by multiple neoplasms and lentigines. It includes features like cardiac myxomas, endocrine tumors, spotty skin pigmentation, and other benign or malignant tumors.

NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are subsets of Carney complex. LAMB syndrome is Lentigines (hypermelanotic patches on the skin that do not disappear on exposure to UV rays), Atrial myxomas, Mucocutaneous myxomas, and Blue naevi. NAME syndrome is Naevi, Atrial myxomas, Myxoid neurofibromas, and Ephelides (freckles.

Other Options:

Option B: Carney's triad includes Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, Pulmonary chondroma, and extraadrenal paraganglioma.

Option C: Carney-Stratakis syndrome is also called Carney's diad and it includes gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and paraganglioma.

Option D: In Tuberous Sclerosis, the usually associated common cardiac tumors are rhabdomyomas and they usually occur in the ventricles.

Pearl PM1078: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

* Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast

* Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi

* Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

* Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

* Pulmonary chondroma

* Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

* GIST

* Paraganglioma

questions.text:
11. A child is admitted with a high fever and bloody mucoid diarrhea. Stool cultures reveal oxidase-negative, gram-negative bacillus. Following enrichment in selenite F broth, it is cultured on XLD agar as shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?

XLD: xylose lysine deoxycholate
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child and the image showing red-coloured colonies without a black centre on XLD agar are suggestive of bacillary dysentery caused by Shigella.

Shigella causes bacillary dysentery by producing an exotoxin known as Shiga toxin or verotoxin. It invades the M cells (specialised epithelial cells of the gut) to cause inflammatory diarrhoea. It presents with frequent passage of loose, scanty faeces containing blood and mucus, along with abdominal cramps, tenesmus, fever and vomiting. Hemolytic uremic syndrome can occur as a complication in severe cases.

Shigellae are short, gram-negative rods that are non-motile, non-sporing, and non-capsulated. They are indole positive, urea and oxidase negative, and ferment glucose. Colonies on MacConkey agar are colourless due to the absence of lactose fermentation. Hektoen enteric (HE) agar, xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar (XLD), and deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) are the selective mediums used for subculture.

XLD agar is a selective growth medium used to isolate Salmonella and Shigella species from other enteric pathogens. It has a bright red colour due to the indicator phenol red. Sugar fermentation lowers the pH, and the phenol red indicator turns yellow. Shigella colonies cannot ferment the sugar to produce xylose and therefore remain red.

Other options: 

Option A: Salmonella metabolises thiosulfate to produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which leads to the formation of red-coloured colonies with black centres on XLD agar and allows them to be differentiated from the Shigella colonies.

Option C: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative lactose fermenting bacteria and does not grow on XLD agar.

Option D: Enterococcus is a gram-positive bacteria and produces tiny magenta-pink colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: 12. The following image represents the number of cases of iron-deficiency anaemia detected in an old-age home between January 1 to December 31. How many cases would you include to calculate the period prevalence of iron deficiency in the year?
questions.solution:
7 cases will be included to calculate the period prevalence of iron deficiency in the year.

The period prevalence in this scenario includes all the cases i.e., new, old and current, that existed at any time between January 1 to December 31, represented by all the straight lines present in the given date range which are A, B, C, D, E, G, and H,  a total of 7 cases.

Other options:

Option A: 3 could be the incidence in the previous year, i.e., the number of new cases before January 1.

Option B: 4 could be the incidence in the current year, i.e., the number of new cases after January 1 and before December 31.

Option D: 8 is the total number of cases, which could be the period prevalence if the time range includes the previous, current, and following years.

Pearl PM0228: Incidence and Prevalence

* Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:



It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

* Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:



It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

* In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".

* In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.

* If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.

* If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: 13. A village has been awarded ODF+ (Open Defecation Free Plus) status under Swachh Bharat Abhiyaan. Which of the following is not a mandatory requirement for achieving ODF+ certification?

choices.text: Every household must have access to and use a functional toilet.
The village must have an effective and safe disposal system connected to all toilets
The village must conduct biannual surveys on sanitation awareness
Public and community toilets should be functional and well maintained

questions.solution:
Conducting biannual surveys on sanitation awareness is not a mandatory requirement for ODF+ certification. While awareness programs and IEC (Information, Education, & Communication) activities are encouraged, they are not a strict prerequisite for achieving ODF+ status.

Swachh Bharat Abhiyan is a nationwide initiative launched by the Government of India in 2014, aimed at cleaning streets, roads, and the country’s infrastructure.. It has two sub-missions, namely Swachh Bharat Mission Urban and Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin. The mission in rural India aims for improving the level of cleanliness through solid and liquid waste management and making gram panchayats free of open defecation, clean, and sanitized. 

The conditions for certifications of Open Defecation Free (ODF) status are as follows: 

* ODF: At any point of the day, not a single person is found defecating and/or urinating in the open

* ODF+: At any point of the day, not a single person is found defecating and/or urinating in the open, and all community and public toilets are functional and well maintained

* ODF ++: It meets all conditions pertaining to ODF and ODF+ and entire sewage, including faecal sludge & septage is safely managed and treated, with no open discharge/dumping of untreated entire sewage, including faecal sludge & septage in water bodies or open areas.

For ODF + certification, there are three mandatory requirements: 

* Nobody should be found defecating or urinating in the open. Hence every household must have access to and use a functional toilet

* All community/public toilet and standalone urinals should be functional and well maintained

* All toilets are connected to a safe disposal system: a Septic tank with soak pit or twin pit or sewers or pucca municipal drains

Having achieved ODF status in Phase I of the mission, Swachh Bharat Mission Phase II was launched in 2020-21 with the objective of sustaining the ODF status and managing solid and liquid waste to bring about visual cleanliness by 2024-25 and transforming all the villages from ODF to ODF Plus.

questions.text: 14. A child presents with pain in his fingers and toes. He has a history of multiple blood transfusions in the past. His peripheral blood smear shows sickled red blood cells. Which of the following molecular alterations is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
A child with pain in his fingers and toes, a history of blood transfusions, and the presence of sickle cells on a peripheral blood smear is suggestive of sickle cell Anaemia. It is caused due to a non-conservative missense mutation in the β-globin gene.

Missense mutations involve the alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases. It leads to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. These mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein. Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

* Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original (replacement of polar amino acid with another polar amino acid). It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.

* Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the amino acid with a biochemically different one. Ex: Replacement of polar amino acid (glutamic acid) with a non-polar amino acid (valine) in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11, in sickle cell anemia. 

Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a missense mutation (a type of point mutation) in the β-globin gene of haemoglobin, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated haemoglobin (HbS).



Nonsense mutation (Option A) is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

Frameshift mutation (Option D) is a genetic mutation in which a number of nucleotides not divisible by 3 are inserted into or removed from a coding DNA sequence. As a result, the reading frame is shifted during protein translation, resulting in an entirely different peptide sequence.

questions.text: 15. A 50-year-old lady presents with a 5x4x3cm lump in the right breast. It is hard in consistency and is fixed to the skin. On examination, there are fixed and matted axillary lymph nodes in the left and right axilla. Mammography reveals the presence of microcalcifications with irregular spiculated margins. A tru-cut biopsy is performed which shows ductal carcinoma. What is the staging of the tumor as per the recent AJCC classification?
questions.solution:
A contralateral lymph node involvement is considered metastasis. The presence of metastasis classifies the tumor under stage IV. (T4bN2aM1)

The TNM status in the above scenario is:

* Tumor: Skin involvement over the breast- peau d'orange appearance classifies this as stage T4b.

* Nodes: Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes come under N2A.

* Metastasis: Contralateral lymph node involvement (Here, mass is on the right breast and axillary lymph nodes on the left side are involved) is considered as M1.

Some important considerations while staging a breast tumor:

* In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is considered. For example, if a mass is 6*2cm in size, 6cm is taken into account and it comes under T3 (>5cm).

* Any skin involvement other than those mentioned under T4b and T4d is not considered for staging. Thus, skin changes like dimpling of skin or nipple retraction are not considered for staging.

* Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.

* Metastasis to any contralateral lymph node or metastasis to any lymph node other than those mentioned in N staging is considered distant metastasis (M1). Thus, the involvement of the cervical lymph node (ipsilateral or contralateral) would be considered a distant metastasis.

* If two masses are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger mass.

questions.text: 16. A patient was brought to emergency with a BP of 230/120 mm Hg. The fundoscopy showed bilateral retinal flame hemorrhages. The biopsy finding of the renal arteriole of the patient is given below. What gross pathology can be expected in the kidneys of this patient with malignant hypertension?

choices.text: Bilaterally enlarged kidneys with numerous cysts
White wedge shaped area of infarct

questions.solution:
The given scenario of severe hypertension (blood pressure ≥180/≥120 mmHg) with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages and/or papilledema) is suggestive of malignant hypertension (also known as hypertensive emergency/crisis). The histopathological image shows fibromuscular hyperplasia of the arterioles having a typical onion-skin appearance. It is associted with flea-bitten appearance of the kidneys.

Malignant hypertension is characterized by severe hypertension with ischemic complications of multi-organs. The commonly affected organs are eye (resulting in retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots with or without papilledema) and kidney (causing malignant nephrosclerosis).

The pathophysiology behind this condition is due to hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. It affects small arteries and arterioles causing thickening and hardening of the wall with loss of elasticity. Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.

Histopathological features of malignant hypertension are:

* Smooth muscle and collagen proliferation are seen resulting in reduced size of the lumen. This further leads to concentric, laminated arteriolar thickening of the vessel wall with duplication of the basement membrane giving rise to an onion-skin appearance. 

* They are also accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arterioles), particularly in the kidney and can lead to acute renal failure.



Other options - 

Benign hypertension  is associated with hyaline deposition in the vessel wall. Here, the arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is irregular and markedly narrowed. Grossly we can see bilaterally contracted kidneys with the renal surface showing diffuse, fine granularity that gives leather grain appearance (option A). The loss of mass is due mainly to cortical scarring and shrinking.

The image below  show hyaline deposition in the vessel wall.





Option C: The kidneys in Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) are transformed into bilaterally enlargerd, cystic masses, with a significant loss of normal renal parenchyma.

Option D: White wedge shaped infarcts are seen with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation like heart, spleen, and kidney, and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Pearl PM2486: Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy describes the fundus changes that occur in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded as follows:

* Grade 1 - Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing

* Grade 2 - Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).

* Grade 3 - Grade 2 changes with the following:

* Copper-wiring of arterioles

* Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema)

* Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings

* Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings  Macular star (Deposition of hard exudates around the fovea) may be present. 

* Grade 4 - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

Onion skin appearance:

A pattern characterised by concentric laminations of differing radiologic or histologic densities. It is seen in:

* Castleman disease: Onion skin appearance of Mantle zone lymphocytes

* Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Onion skin lesions in spleen

* Thrombotic thrombocytopenia purpura (TTP): Onion skinning of renal arteries and arterioles

* Ewing sarcoma: Laminated periosteal reaction (onion skin)

* Malignant hypertension: Onion skin lesion/ Hyperplastic arteriolitis

* Tay–Sach's disease: Whorled arrangement (onion skin) of cytoplasmic inclusions within lysosomes of ganglion cells under electron microscopy

* Lyme arthritis: Onion skin thickening of the arterial wall

* Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) and Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease: Onion bulb formation of proliferated Schwann cells around the axon due to recurrent demyelination and remyelination

questions.text: 17. While performing a hernia surgery, the surgeon notices that the sac contains two loops of the bowel and that the central portion of the loop is strangulated. The diagrammatic representation of the hernia is given below. Name the hernia based on the clinical scenario and image.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image points to the diagnosis of Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-in-W. 

Maydl hernias have two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac forming a "W" shape. The center portion of the 'W' loop is strangulated and it lies within the abdominal cavity.

Other Options:

Option A: In Richter's hernia, only part of the bowel wall or portion of the circumference is the content. Strangulation can occur without any signs of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. 

Option C: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

questions.text: 18. A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal discharge, pruritus, and dysuria. On examination, a greenish frothy discharge is noted, along with a strawberry cervix. Vaginal pH is 4.5. What is the most likely finding on saline microscopy?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, which are motile flagellated organisms.

The characteristic findings include:

* Greenish, frothy vaginal discharge: a hallmark feature of trichomoniasis

* Strawberry cervix: punctate haemorrhages due to the parasite’s irritative effect

* Alkaline vaginal pH (>4.5): common in Trichomonas infections

* Dysuria and pruritus: typical symptoms of vaginal inflammation

* Saline microscopy: demonstrates motile, flagellated protozoa, confirming the diagnosis



Other options:

Options A and C: Budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae: seen in vulvovaginal candidiasis, which presents with thick, curdy white discharge, severe pruritus, and a low vaginal pH (<4.5).

Option B: Clue cells are seen in bacterial vaginosis, which is characterised by a thin, greyish-white discharge with a fishy odour (positive whiff test). No inflammation or pruritus is usually present.

questions.text: 19. A long-distance runner is undergoing a physiological assessment. A graph is provided comparing the oxygen dissociation curves of two oxygen-binding proteins (Curve X and Curve Y). Which of the following is incorrect about the proteins representing the two curves?

choices.text: Curve X protein binds only one molecule of oxygen, whereas Curve Y protein can bind up to four.
Curve X protein is found primarily in muscle tissues, while Curve Y protein is mainly present in red blood cells.
Curve X protein exhibits cooperative binding, whereas Curve Y protein does not.
Curve X protein primarily functions as an oxygen reservoir in muscles, whereas Curve Y protein plays a major role in oxygen transport

questions.solution:
Myoglobin (curve X) does not exhibit cooperative binding whereas hemoglobin (curve Y) does.

Myoglobin, found in muscle tissue, acts as an oxygen reservoir. It has a single oxygen-binding site and does not exhibit cooperative binding. With its high oxygen affinity, myoglobin binds oxygen tightly and releases it only when oxygen levels are low. Its hyperbolic dissociation curve reflects this efficient storage function.

Hemoglobin, found in red blood cells, is the primary oxygen transporter. It consists of four subunits and exhibits cooperative binding. Cooperative binding refers to the phenomenon where the binding of one oxygen molecule to hemoglobin increases its affinity for subsequent oxygen molecules, resulting in a sigmoidal oxygen dissociation curve. This allows hemoglobin to efficiently load oxygen in the lungs and release it in tissues. Its sigmoidal dissociation curve ensures effective oxygen delivery as needed.

questions.text:
20. Assertion (A): Correcting the anion gap for hypoalbuminemia is necessary in patients with metabolic acidosis to assess the acid-base disturbance accurately.
Reason (R): Hypoalbuminemia can lead to a decrease in serum sodium concentration

choices.text: Both (A) and (R) are true, and (R) is the correct explanation for (A)
Both (A) and (R) are true, but (R) is not the correct explanation for (A)

questions.solution:
Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but Reason (R) is not the correct explanation for Assertion (A).

In metabolic acidosis, the anion gap is used to identify unmeasured anions (e.g., lactate, and ketoacids) that contribute to acidosis. However, when hypoalbuminemia is present, the anion gap can be falsely low, as albumin is a major unmeasured anion. Correcting for hypoalbuminemia ensures an accurate anion gap that accounts for decreased albumin levels.

Although the reason (R), hypoalbuminemia affects sodium concentration measurement, it doesn’t explain the necessity for correcting anion gap. The primary reason for AG adjustment in hypoalbuminemia is to account for the reduction in unmeasured anions due to low albumin, which impacts AG interpretation independently of sodium levels.

The normal anion gap (AG) of 10 mmol/L is based on a normal serum albumin level. If a patient has low albumin (hypoalbuminemia), the AG must be adjusted. For every 1 g/dL decrease in albumin below the normal level (4.5 g/dL), add 2.5 mmol/L to the uncorrected AG. For example, if a patient has an albumin level of 2.5 g/dL (2 g/dL below normal) and an uncorrected AG of 15, you calculate the corrected AG by adding 5 mmol/L (2.5 × 2 = 5) to the uncorrected AG. So, 15 + 5 = a corrected AG of 20 mmol/L.

questions.text: 21. A 55-year-old female patient presented with uncontrolled bleeding from the nose, that failed to settle with conservative methods. When examined, the bleeding point was difficult to localize. A transnasal endoscopic procedure was performed for artery ligation. An adjunctive procedure was performed in order to further control the epistaxis, with the incision shown in the image below. Which among the following arteries are exposed and ligated following this incision?
questions.solution:
The incision shown in the given image is the Lynch incision (external ethmoid incision), which exposes the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated as an adjunctive procedure to Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL).

Spontaneous epistaxis in a hypertensive patient, >40 years of age which is difficult to localize is suggestive of posterior epistaxis.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Site Little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize
Age Children, young adults >40 years of age
Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hypertension or IHD
Bleeding Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalization and posterior nasal pack


Management of Epistaxis:

* Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 min compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.

* Trotter’s method: The patient sits, leaning forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathes quietly from the mouth. Cold compresses should be applied to the nose to cause reflex vasoconstriction.

* Cauterisation of the bleeding point- with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.

* Anterior nasal packing

* Posterior nasal packing - Patients should be hospitalized.

* Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 

* Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.

* Ligations of vessels:

* External carotid artery.

* Maxillary artery- Approached via Caldwell Luc operation.

* Ethmoidal arteries- Approached via Lynch incision.

* Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL)- Under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia, the sphenopalatine artery (SPA) is localized and closed with a vascular clip as it exits the foramen. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated by Lynch incision as an adjunctive procedure. It is effective in controlling posterior bleeds.

* Embolization of the maxillary arteries by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization. Ethmoidal arteries cannot be embolized.

questions.text: 22. The below image depicts an implant that was used in a case of refractory heart failure. Identify the implant.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, where a patient has refractory heart failure and the image shows a pump attached to the left ventricle channeling blood to the aorta, which is called a left ventricular assist device. (LVAD)

Left ventricular assist devices are specifically designed prosthetics for the failing heart. They take over the function of the left ventricle. There are two indications for the device:

* As bridging treatment

* As destination treatment

Bridging treatment refers to a temporary setup whereby individuals who need a cardiac transplant are provided with a LVAD until a suitable donor can be identified and recepient can be declared fit for transplantation. Bridge or temporising measures are required frequently as donor hearts are few and the demand for them is high.

Destination treatment is a newer approach with LVAD as a permanent solution to cardiac problems. With advancement in technology, LVAD complications have reduced significantly along with a reduction in the bulk and increase in the portability and servability of the device, so new versions of LVAD are aiming to be the final solution rather than a bridge. LVAD in the future may replace cardiac transplant in a select patient population. 

A typical patient requiring LVAD includes any of the following features: with multiple hospitalizations for drug-resistant heart failure requiring inotropic support, with NYHA 3-4 symptoms with possible end organ damage due to poor perfusion. Examples of LVADs are HeartMate 2, HeartMate 3, etc. 

An LVAD essentially comprises a pump and tubing connecting this pump to the left ventricle and the aorta. Blood is driven into the pump from the left ventricle, and pushed into the aorta by a pump. The pump is connected via a driveline to an external power source like a battery.

Complications of LVAD:

* Pump thrombosis resulting in machine failure requiring replacement.

* Shear stress to RBC resulting in hemolysis

* Iron deficiency anemia

* Acquired von Willebrand disease 

* Gastrointestinal bleeds

* Cerebrovascular diseases like hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke

* Infection, most often involving the driveline

* Right heart decompensation

* Arrhythmias

Other Options:

Option B: Blalock Taussig Shunt is an aortopulmonary shunt usually made of Gore-Tex involving a side-to-side anastamosis between the subclavian and pulmonary artery on the same side. It is indicated in Tetralogy of Fallot.



Option C: ICD or Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator is a device used to terminate arrhythmias of the heart by applying a shock to shockable rhythms like ventricular fibrillation. They save time in patients who are at high risk for recurrent arrhythmias. In LVADs, ICDs are frequently coimplanted because of the high risk of arrhythmia.



Option D: Glenn Shunt is a surgical anastomotic procedure between the superior vena cava and the pulmonary arteries. It is indicated in Tricuspid atresia and hypoplastic left heart syndrome.

questions.text: 23. A 34-year-old male was diagnosed with a urogenital tumor. History revealed that the patient had cryptorchidism in his childhood. Which of the following tumors is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common cancer in patients who had cryptorchidism in childhood is seminoma.

The most common type of testicular cancer to develope in untreated undescended testes is seminoma. The cancer risk for adults who have history of cryptorchidism in childhood depends on the time of orchidopexy. 

* Risk is 2-3 times greater if orchidopexy is done before puberty.

* Risk is 5-10 times greater if orchidopexy is done after puberty.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT) (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.



The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

questions.text: 24. A 29-year-old woman, who had a spontaneous vaginal delivery 20 minutes ago, develops sudden-onset dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and oxygen desaturation. She appears cyanotic, tachycardic, abefrile and has a diffuse petechial rash on her torso. Which of the following is the primary initiating pathophysiologic mechanism responsible for her condition?

choices.text: Pulmonary vasoconstriction and right ventricular failure

questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation suggests amniotic fluid embolism (AFE). The pathophysiology for the same is amniotic fluid embolism causing pulmonary vasoconstriction and right ventricular failure.

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is an obstetric emergency caused by the entry of amniotic fluid, fetal cells, or debris into the maternal circulation. It typically occurs during labor, delivery, or immediately after delivery. Amniotic fluid emboli occlude pulmonary circulation, causing intense pulmonary vasoconstriction and increased pulmonary artery pressures. This leads to acute right ventricular failure (RVF) and reduced pulmonary blood flow, impairing oxygenation and causing sudden hypoxemia and respiratory distress. The failing RV cannot pump blood effectively, causing systemic hypotension and cardiogenic shock.

The diagnosis is clinical and the classic triad of amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) includes abrupt hemodynamic collapse, respiratory distress, and consumptive coagulopathy (DIC). The diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) include:

* Onset occurs during labor or within 30 minutes of placental delivery.

* Abrupt hypotension, respiratory distress, or cardiac arrest.

* Coagulopathy: Presence of overt disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

* No fever ≥38°C, ruling out infectious causes.

Treatment is supportive and includes immediate cardio-pulmonary resuscitation, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation if needed. Blood product transfusion (platelets, fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate) is crucial to managing DIC. In refractory cases, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may be required. 

Other options:

Option B: Leukotriene-mediated bronchospasm is primarily involved in the pathogenesis of asthma and other allergic reactions.

Option C: Direct myocardial depression is an incorrect statement since AFE is embolization of amniotic fluid and does not cause direct myocardial depression. 

Option D: Disseminated intravascular coagulation triggered by amniotic fluid components is a secondary event in AFE. It is not the initiating event for AFE.

questions.text: 25. A female child is brought with complaints of severe bleeding diathesis. There is a family history of Hemophilia A in mother's family and the father's family is normal. On evaulation, the child was found to have inherited hemophilia A. What could be the rationale for the inheritance?
questions.solution:
Female child inheriting hemophilia A can be explained by unfavourable lyonization.

In lyonization, one of the two X chromosomes is randomly inactivated in each somatic cell during early embryonic development. Hemophilia A and B mostly affect males, but rarely can affect females also. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder (option B), affecting mainly males and homozygous females. It can rarely occur in heterozygous females due to the inactivation of the X chromosome bearing the normal factor VIII allele by chance in most cells i.e., unfavourable lyonization. This explains why some female carriers may experience symptoms of Hemophilia A. 

Polygenic inheritance involves multiple genes. Hemophilia A is a single-gene disorder (option C).

Hemophilia A is caused by a specific gene mutation on the X chromosome, not a general karyotype alteration (option D).

questions.text: 26. A male baby was brought to the pediatrician in the 5th week of life with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign on ultrasound is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hence the ABG which shows a pH: 7.48, pCO2: 47, HCO3: 30 is the answer.

A pH >7.40, with increased HCO3, and increased pCO2 indicate metabolic alkalosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

* Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach

* Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

* The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.

* The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign



 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 



 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign



 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.



Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 



 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.



 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.



 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).



Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.



Pearl PM1343: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: 27. A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of protein C deficiency presents with a painful limp on the right side. His parents give a history of limping after he comes home after playing, 1 week back. On examination, he is afebrile. The boy whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and relieves by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

* Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus

* Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis

* Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase

* Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The below radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.



Treatment:

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates

Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy

For children aged 9 and above - operative management with pelvic osteotomy

Other options:

Option A- Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option B- Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder.

Option D- Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm.

questions.text: 28. A 68-year-old woman presents with acute severe chest pain and shortness of breath. An emergency cardiac catheterization showed occlusion of the anterior descending branch of the left coronary artery. Laboratory reports and ECG support the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks?
questions.solution:
The most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks is a collagen-rich scar. It usually develops 2-8 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI).

The gross and microscopic appearance of the myocardial infarct depends on the duration of survival of the patient following the ischemic injury. Areas of damage undergo a progressive sequence of changes. These include ischemic coagulative necrosis, inflammation, and finally repair with fibrosis. 12 to 24 hours after the MI, it appears reddish-blue due to congestion and extravasated blood.

The sequence of microscopic findings in acute myocardial infarction include:

* 1-3 days after the occlusion: 

* Gross: Yellowish-tan infarct center with mottling

* Microscopic: Signs of coagulative necrosis with nuclear pyknosis, myocyte hypereosinophilia, and marginal contraction band necrosis. It is followed by the loss of nuclei and striations. Myocyte vacuolization is seen at the margins which indicate that the myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.

* 3-7 days:

* Gross: Yellowish-tan center softens, and borders become hyperemic

* Microscopic: Polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages are seen, with the disintegration of dead myofibers, and neutrophils. Phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border.

* 7-14 days:

* Gross: Maximal softening of yellowish-tan area, margins are depressed and reddish-tan to reddish-gray

* Microscopic: Capillary-rich granulation tissue at the margins, collagen deposition, further phagocytosis of dead material

* 2- 8 weeks:

* Gross: Greyish white scar

* Microscopic: Replacement of the necrotic myocardium with collagen-rich scar tissue from the border to the infarct core. The scar is well developed by the end of the sixth week.

Left anterior descending coronary artery is involved in 40% to 50% cases. The infarct involves the anterior wall of left ventricle near the apex, the anterior portion of ventricular septum and the apex circumferentially.

questions.text: 29. A 28-year-old primigravida at 39+4 weeks of gestation presents to the labor ward with regular painful contractions every 5 minutes for the past 3 hours. On vaginal examination, her cervix is 4 cm dilated, 80% effaced, and the fetal head is at -2 station. After 6 hours, a repeat examination shows 6 cm cervical dilation with strong uterine contractions. Based on the latest updates in the definitions of stages of labor, in which stage and phase of labor is this patient currently?

choices.text: Latent phase of the first stage
Active phase of the first stage
Accelerated phase of the first stage

questions.solution:
The patient is in Active phase of the first stage of labour currently as per the latest updates from Zhang’s labor curve and ACOG guidelines where the active phase begins at 6 cm cervical dilation, rather than 4 cm (as per Friedman’s labor curve)

Friedman’s Curve (Old Definition): Defined active labor as starting at 4 cm dilation. Progress was expected to be ≥1.2 cm/hr in nulliparous women and ≥1.5 cm/hr in multiparous women.

Zhang’s Curve (Updated Definition): Based on contemporary data, labor progress is slower in early dilation and accelerates after 6 cm. Thus, the active phase is now defined as starting at 6 cm dilation, not 4 cm.

Other options:

Option A) Latent phase of the first stage: According to Zhang’s curve, the latent phase is less than 6 cm dilation (not 4 cm as per Friedman). Since this patient is already at 6 cm dilation, she has entered the active phase, not the latent phase.

Option C) Accelerated phase of the first stage: The term "accelerated phase" is not an official classification in modern labor definitions. However, the active phase does show an accelerated rate of cervical dilation (typically ≥1 cm per hour in nulliparous women). Despite this, the correct terminology remains "active phase of the first stage," making this option incorrect.

Option D) Prolonged latent phase: Prolonged latent phase is defined as >20 hours in nulliparas and >14 hours in multiparas before reaching 6 cm dilation. Since this patient reached 6 cm within 6 hours, her labor is progressing normally.

questions.text: 30. A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows the following appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining. What is the likely causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pneumonia along with the characteristic fried egg appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Mycoplasma colonies can be best studied after staining with Diene's method. The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. The central dark bluish area represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are highly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

* M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia

* Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis

* M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia/ atypical pneumonia/ walking pneumonia. Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat, and fever.

Pearl PM0150: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum

X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.


 

* The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.

* The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

* The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-

* Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)

* The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: 31. An intern is assisting the resident in evaluating a newborn after birth. The newborn's APGAR score at 1 minute is 3. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this patient's APGAR score?

choices.text: The baby had some form of intrapartum depression
The baby may have a very low birth weight
The baby will have poor neurological outcome

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement in the above question is that the child will have a poor neurological outcome.

APGAR score is a systematic way of assessing infants at 1 and 5 minutes after birth. The best possible score is 10, which indicates the best outcome in any infant. In this question, the APGAR score is 3 at 1st minute, which denotes that there is some neurological depression at the time of birth. An APGAR score of 0–3 requires immediate resuscitation, but a lower APGAR score at 1st minute does not signify a poor neurological outcome. Studies suggest poor neurological outcomes are associated with lower Apgar scores at 5 minutes

The longer the period of severe depression, the higher the risk of long-term neurological issues, such as brain injury, and conditions like cerebral palsy. However, many infants with prolonged depression can still have normal long-term outcomes due to advances in neonatal care, resuscitation techniques, and early interventions. Thus a lower 1st minute APGAR score will not always have a poor neurological outcome. 

Other options:

Option A: The baby had some form of intrapartum depression is a correct statement since any patient with intrapartum depression, such as hypoxia, hemorrhage, etc., can cause fetal distress and thus have a lower Apgar score.

Option B: Babies with low Apgar scores can have a very low birth weight.

Option D: Abnormal umbilical cord blood pH signifies any event of intrapartum insult in the form of hypoxia or hemorrhage. Thus, in the majority of the patients present with low Apgar scores, there will be acidic blood pH.

Pearl PM2195: APGAR score

questions.text: 32. A 52-year-old woman complains of fatigue, dry skin and cold intolerance since 2 weeks. She was started on amiodarone 1 month ago for persistent atrial fibrillation. Tests show high TSH (15 mU/l) and low free T4 levels. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine supplementation is indicated for amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism, which is characterized by symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, cold intolerance) and lab findings (elevated TSH, reduced free T4) following amiodarone use.

Amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism (AIH) can occur shortly after (as early as 2 weeks) amiodarone use due to iodine-induced thyroid suppression (Wolff Chaikoff effect), where excessive iodine leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. It is characterized by clinical features of hypothyroidism and lab findings of elevated TSH and reduced free T4. AIH occurs more frequently in women and those with positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies. It is managed by thyroxine supplementation without the need to discontinue amiodarone (Option A).

Amiodarone is an iodine-containing compound structurally related to thyroid hormone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that increases the duration of an action potential by blocking potassium channels, thereby increasing the time taken for repolarization. It is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation.

Other adverse effects of amiodarone include hypotension, bradycardia, myocardial depression, photosensitization, corneal microdeposits (corneal verticillata), pulmonary fibrosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options: 

Option C: Corticosteroids would be indicated in amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis, not amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism.

Option D: Asymptomatic patients with subclinical hypothyroidism following amiodarone use can be managed by observation and regular monitoring with thyroid function tests. Subclinical hypothyroidism is characterized by TSH levels> 4.5 and ≤ 10 mU/l, normal FT4, and absence of clinical features of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: 33. Given below is a schematic diagram showing embryological structures forming the diaphragm. Which of the following structures shown(labeled 1-4) additionally contributes to the formation of liver sinusoids, fibrous pericardium, and esophageal mesentery, apart from the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Structure 1 which is the Septum Transversum contributes to the formation of liver sinusoids, fibrous pericardium, and esophageal mesentery while also forming the diaphragm.

The embryological structures forming the diaphragm are:

* Septum Transversum ( Structure 1 )

* Pleuroperitoneal membrane ( Structure 2 )

* Lateral body wall muscle ( Structure 3 )

*  Esophageal mesentery ( Structure 4 )



The central portion of the diaphragm is formed from the septum transversum. Other structures formed by the septum transversum:

* Sinusoids of the liver

* Tissues within the lesser omentum  (including ventral mesogastrium containing esophageal mesentery)

* Falciform ligament

* The fibrous pericardium of the heart and epicardium

The diaphragm's development begins at the cervical C3-C4 level in the fourth week, and it later descends with the expansion of the pleuropericardial cavity. This explains the Phrenic nerve roots arising from C3, C4, and C5 and taking a long course before innervating the diaphragm.

 The dorsal part of the diaphragm develops faster than the ventral part due to the growth of the spine around the 6th week resulting in the curvature of the diaphragm. The peripheral portion of the diaphragm initially remains open connecting the pleuropericardial and peritoneal cavities.

Later a membrane develops to close the opening, called a pleuroperitoneal membrane.  Failure of proper closure results in congenital diaphragmatic hernias, specifically the Bochdalek type.

The lateral-most part of the diaphragm develops from the adjacent lateral body wall muscle. The crura are formed by the mesentery of the esophagus.

questions.text: 34. A 68-year-old man came to the ER with shortness of breath. On examination, he had a tense abdomen and his flanks were full. He gave a history of excessive alcohol intake for the past 35 years. A CT abdomen was done, which is shown below. What would be the CT attenuation value of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where an elderly alcoholic presents with shortness of breath, tense abdomen, and fullness of flanks is suggestive of ascites due to liver dysfunction. CT scan shows fluid collection in the peritoneal cavity, which is the marked structure. The attenuation value of ascitic fluid is 0-20 HU.

"Attenuation" refers to a decrease in signal intensity due to passage through various media. In CT scan, the x-rays are made to pass through the body, and based on the composition of the material, different substances attenuate the rays differently. This attenuation is expressed in the form of a dimensionless unit, Hounsfield Unit(HU). 

The higher the attenuation value, the more "hyperdense" or bright the signal intensity is. The attenuation coefficient of various substances is as follows:

SUBSTANCE ATTENUATION VALUE
Air -1000
Lung -500
Fat  -50 to -100
Water 0
Kidney 30
Contrast 100-300
Muscle 10-40
Blood 30-45
CSF 15
Cancellous bone 700
Cortical bone 3000


Attenuation values are valuable parameters useful in identifying the nature of various signal intensities noted on the scan.

questions.text: 35. A 19-year-old woman is found unconscious in a nightclub. Her friends report that she had only one drink before rapidly becoming drowsy, confused, and eventually unresponsive. On examination, she has stable vitals and decreased muscle tone. She regains consciousness after several hours but has no memory of the events. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most likely drug involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests that the woman was exposed to a date rape drug, with rapid-onset CNS depression, amnesia, and recovery within hours. The most probable substance involved is benzodiazepines (flunitrazepam-Rohypnol), which act by GABA-A receptor potentiation. 

Benzodiazepines are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone by promoting the binding of the major inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA to the GABA-A receptor, a pentameric ligand-gated, anion-conducting channel.

Flunitrazepam (Rohypnol) is a benzodiazepine derivative whose hypnotic effect predominates and, when added to drinks served to unsuspecting young women, produces sedation, disinhibition, muscle relaxation, and amnesia. It reduces the will to resist sexual advances and hence is misused as a date rape drug. The effect synergizes with alcohol, leading to excessive impairment.

Option (A):Opioids (e.g., heroin, fentanyl) cause CNS and respiratory depression with pin-point pupils and do not typically cause amnesia. 

Option (C): Dopamine receptor blockade (e.g., antipsychotics) leads to sedation, extrapyramidal symptoms, and autonomic instability, not sudden unconsciousness with amnesia.

Option (D): Serotonin reuptake inhibition (e.g., SSRIs, MDMA) would cause euphoria, hyperthermia, and serotonin syndrome rather than sudden unconsciousness.

questions.text:
36. Which of the following are true statements about sound and noise pollution?

* The audiometry curve shows a characteristic dip at 4000 Hz in people with noise-induced hearing loss.

* Frequencies of 300–500 Hz cause the most disturbance to speech communication in everyday life.

* The maximum safe limit, as recommended by the Ministry of Labour under the Factories Act, is 80 dB, 10 hours a day for 5 days per week. 

* Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz.

* Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 80 dB.
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 4 are correct statements.

The effects of noise exposure can be auditory and non-auditory. Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. The audiometry curve shows a characteristic dip at 4000 Hz in people with noise-induced hearing loss. Noise exposure can lead to temporary or permanent hearing loss.

Non-auditory effects include interference with speech and annoyance. Frequencies of 300–500 Hz cause the most disturbance to speech communication in everyday life.

Other options:

In statement 3, the maximum safe limit, as recommended by the Ministry of Labour under the Factories Act, is 90 dB, 8 hours a day for 5 days per week.

Statement 5 is incorrect, as permanent hearing loss can occur after repeated or continuous exposure to sound around 100 dB.

Pearl PM1654: Effects of Noise Exposure

* Auditory effects

* Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.

* Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.

* Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.

* Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.

* Non-auditory effects

* Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz

* Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration

* Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: 37. You are a microbiologist examining a water sample brought to you by the municipal corporation. They suspect fecal contamination of the source of drinking water. The sole presence of which of the following organisms indicates that the contamination was not recent?
questions.solution:
The presence of Clostridium perfringens alone, in the absence of the coliform group, in a water sample suggests that the contamination is not recent.

Clostridium perfringens occur in faeces in much smaller numbers than E. coli. The spores of this organism are capable of surviving in water for a longer time than organisms of the coliform group and resist chlorination at the doses normally used to disinfect.

Detection of Clostridium perfringens can be done using varying quantities of the water samples, incubated in a litmus milk medium (anaerobically) at 37°C for five days. The presence of 'stormy clot' formation indicates the presence of Clostridium perfringens.

Classification of the quality of drinking water based on bacteriological tests :

  Presumptive coliform count/100ml E.coli count/100ml
Class I - Excellent 0 0
Class II - Satisfactory 1-3 0
Class III - Suspicious 4-10 0
Class IV - Unsatisfactory >10 0.1 or more


Other options:

Option A: Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci).

Option C: If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination.

Option D: Bacteroides species are present in feces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for fecal pollution of water.

questions.text: 38. A 27-year-old male was brought to the ER following a head injury. His GCS is 15/15 and there is no focal neurological deficit. The following finding is noted on examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in a patient with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) with a sign of base of skull fracture (Battle sign as shown in the image) is a CT scan of the head.

Mild TBI is defined as a post-resuscitation GCS score between 13 and 15. These patients might have a history of a transient loss of neurological function in the form of disorientation, amnesia, or transient loss of consciousness.

Indications for CT Brain in Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI):

A CT scan of the head should be considered in a patient with mild TBI when any of the following criteria are present:

* Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score below 15 two hours after the injury

* Clinical suspicion of an open or depressed skull fracture

* Features suggesting a basal skull fracture, such as:

* Hemotympanum

* Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes)

* Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) otorrhea or rhinorrhea

* Mastoid ecchymosis (Battle’s sign)

* More than two episodes of vomiting

* Age over 65 years

* Current use of anticoagulant therapy

* Loss of consciousness lasting longer than 5 minutes or amnesia preceding the injury

* High-risk mechanism of injury, for example:

* Pedestrian struck by a vehicle

* Ejection from a motor vehicle

* Fall from a height greater than approximately one meter (three feet)



If these indications are absent in a patient with mild TBI, the patient is observed with serial GCS examinations until the GCS is 15 and the patient has no memory deficit. Following this, the patient is discharged.

All cases of moderate (GCS 9-12) and severe (GCS 3-8) traumatic brain injury mandatorily require a CT scan for further evaluation.

questions.text: 39. Which of the following microscopes can be used to detect antibodies to bacteria?
questions.solution:
Fluorescent microscope can be used to detect antibodies to bacteria.

The technique is known as the fluorescent-antibody technique, also called immunofluorescence. Specific antibodies are chemically labelled with a fluorochrome, such as a fluorescein isothiocyanate, and added to a microscope slide containing the clinical specimen. This microscope uses light from a high-intensity source, which excites a fluorescent agent that, in turn, emits a low-energy light of a longer wavelength that produces the image.

Other options:

Option B: Light Microscope helps to visualise bacteria in a living state or after fixation and staining, but details cannot be appreciated due to lack of contrast.

Option C: Dark-Field Microscope- This is a light microscope in which the lighting system is modified to create a “dark field” that contrasts against the highlighted edge of the specimens. The contrast gives an illusion of increased resolution so that very slender organisms, such as spirochetes, can be seen, which are not visible under ordinary illumination. 

Option D: Phase-Contrast Microscope helps to visualise structures that differ in thickness or refractive index.

questions.text: 40. The direct oral factor Xa inhibitor is ______.
questions.solution:
Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (Venous Thrombo Embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

* Rivaroxaban

* Apixaban

* Edoxaban

* Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

* Bivalirudin

* Argatroban

* Desirud

 Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

Pearl PM0609: Classification of Anticoagulants



Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
