questions.text: 41. Investigation for monitoring treatment response in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis is ______________ .
questions.solution:
Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) is used to assess treatment response in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis. Failure of nontreponemal test titers to decrease fourfold within 12-24 months after therapy, depending on the stage of syphilis (inadequate serologic response), might be indicative of treatment failure.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

* Screening or diagnosis - RPR or VDRL

* Quantitative measurement of antibodies to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy - RPR or VDRL

* Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test - FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA 

* RPR - Rapid plasma reagin test

* FTA-ABS - Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test 

* TPHA - Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay 

* EIA - Enzyme immunoassay

* CIA - Chemiluminescence immunoassay

VDRL test is a slide flocculation test used widely for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

In this test, the serum is inactivated at 56°C for 30 minutes and a measured volume of serum is placed on a special cavity slide. The cardiolipin antigen after preparation is added to the serum sample on a slide and is rotated on a VDRL rotator for a specified period of 4 minutes. In a positive test, the cardiolipin antigen reacts with reagin antibodies present in the infected serum and forms visible clumps. In a negative test, cardiolipin continues to remain as uniform crystals in the serum.

The result of the test is reported as reactive, weak reactive, or nonreactive depending on the extent of the formation of the clumps. The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1–2 weeks after the appearance of the chancre. It is a highly sensitive test and the sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of the disease:-

* The test is 60–75% sensitive in primary syphilis

* The test is 100% sensitive in secondary syphilis

* High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascular or cardiovascular complications.

* The test is usually negative in the tertiary stage of syphilis

* This test is negative in early primary syphilis, latent acquired syphilis, and late congenital syphilis

Other options:

Option A: Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is an indirect immunofluorescence test used to detect specific treponemal antibodies. It is not available for routine testing as it is done only in suitably equipped labs.

Option C: Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test detects the presence of treponemal antibodies in the serum. Similar to the FTA-ABS test, it is also not available for routine testing.

Option D: Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

questions.text: 42. A 40-year-old man presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain for 4 months, episodic hot flushes involving the face and upper chest for 2 months, and watery stools 5–6 episodes per day for 1 month.CT abdomen shows a mass in the terminal ileum. The resected specimen is positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can occur as a result of the above condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of intermittent upper abdominal pain, episodic hot flushes, watery diarrhea, and the resected specimen staining positive for synaptophysin are diagnostic of carcinoid syndrome. In carcinoid syndrome there is an overproduction of 5-hydroxytryptamine which may account for as much as 60% of the body’s tryptophan metabolism, causing pellagra because of the diversion away from niacin synthesis. 

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, found mostly among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which are low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

The 4Ds of pellagra:

* Diarrhea

* Dermatitis

* Dementia

* Death

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid 3 times daily for 5 days.

Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic disorder characterized by diarrhea, skin rashes, bronchospasm, tumors in the gastrointestinal tract, flushing, and cyanosis. The pathogenesis is mediated by components like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), bradykinin, tachykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins. The tumors arise from Kulchitsky cells.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

* Neuron-specific enolase

* Synaptophysin

* Chromogranin A

questions.text: 43. A 17-year-old girl visited the emergency department with complaints of several episodes of palpitations and dizziness. The patient has a history of secondary amenorrhea and is also under evaluation for body dysmorphic disorder with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2. ECG of the patient is as given below. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is most likely responsible for the condition depicted in the ECG?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is most likely responsible for the condition depicted in the ECG.

The given ECG shows typical changes of torsade des pointes which is seen due to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia. The female, with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 and secondary amenorrhea, is under psychiatric evaluation and most probably she is suffering from Anorexia Nervosa. Patients with anorexia nervosa have multiple electrolyte abnormalities such as hypokalemia and hypocalcemia. 

Other options:

Option A: Hypermagnesemia can cause bradycardia and heart blocks.

Option B: Hypercalcemia may cause ECG changes in the form of shortened QT interval. The ECG and the symptoms of the patient do not show the changes related to hypercalcemia.

Option C: Hyponatremia can cause neurological symptoms such as confusion, dizziness, and nausea. However, it does not typically cause ECG changes associated with palpitations or arrhythmias directly. In severe cases, hyponatremia may lead to seizures or altered mental status but would not be the primary cause of palpitations or arrhythmias.

questions.text: 44. A patient with documented anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies and a history of recurrent miscarriage presents with dull abdominal pain since 6 months. USG shows ascites and cirrhotic changes in the liver, and colour doppler shows absent filling of the hepatic veins draining into the IVC. Hepatic venography confirms the diagnosis. What is the type of portal hypertension usually seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Post hepatic portal hypertension is seen in Budd Chiari Syndrome.

The given clinical scenario, where a woman has recurrent miscarriage and documented anti-beta-2 glycoprotein antibodies, is together suggestive of APLA syndrome(Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome), a hypercoagulable state.

She presents with dull abdominal pain and USG finding of cirrhosis with ascites and colour doppler showing absent filling of hepatic veins draining into IVC, where hepatic venography confirms the diagnosis is highly suggestive of Budd-Chiari Syndrome. In Budd-Chiari syndrome, post-hepatic portal hypertension is seen.

USG can have two significant findings in Budd Chiari Syndrome. One is a hyperechoic shadow in the hepatic vein draining into the IVC, which would indicate a clot. Second, the colour doppler mode may show no flow into the IVC. APLA syndrome is a known cause of hypercoagulable state in the body, and can predispose to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Budd Chiari Syndrome is an uncommon condition typically occurring in the background of a hypercoagulable state(primary type) where a thrombus forms and occludes the blood flow from the liver and can occur anywhere from the hepatic vein to the IVC draining to the right heart. Secondary causes include tumours or membranes, which are occluding the hepatic outflow tract. It can have an acute or chronic presentation.

Acute obstruction can present as sudden right hypochondric pain combined with jaundice, hepatomegaly and rapidly progressive ascites. Chronic cases may present with a dull abdominal pain and nonspecific features, and depending on the duration, various manifestations of chronically deranged hepatic function including cirrhosis, post-hepatic portal hypertension, etc.

The diagnosis is made by USG showing thrombus in the hepatic veins, which is confirmed by CECT or Hepatic Venography. Blood investigations can also show other signs of a hypercoagulable state (PT, aPTT, PT INR)and deranged liver function(LFT). Below is an image of USG with color doppler showing absent filling into the IVC from hepatic veins and a clot in the hepatic vein :



Treatment includes anticoagulation, endovascular stenting procedures, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunts, and as a final measure in chronic or fulminant cases, liver transplant. Portal hypertension can arise from obstruction at different points along the portal venous system and is classified as prehepatic, intrahepatic (which includes presinusoidal, sinusoidal, and postsinusoidal), or posthepatic, depending on the location of the disruption to portal blood flow, as outlined in the pearl below.

questions.text: 45. The onset of rigor mortis is delayed due to which of the following causes of death?
questions.solution:
Asphyxia causes delayed onset of rigor mortis.

Rigor mortis, also known as cadaveric rigidity, is a state of stiffening of muscles after death. It affects all muscles- both voluntary and involuntary and starts within one to two hours after death. It does not start in all muscles simultaneously and first appears in involuntary muscles. The sequential order in which cadaveric rigidity appears is given by Nysten's rule. Muscles are affected in the given order:

* Myocardium - First to be affected

* Eyelids

* Neck and lower jaw

* Face

* Chest

* Upper extremities

* Abdomen

* Legs

* Fingers and toes

Rigor mortis is affected by many conditions altering its onset and duration. The table given below describes various causes of early and delayed onset of rigor mortis.

Early onset of Rigor mortis  Delayed onset of Rigor mortis 
  • Diseases causing wasting and exhaustion like cancer, typhoid, cholera, tuberculosis 
  • Violent death due to electrocution, lightening, firearms 
  • Organophosphate poisoning
  • Poisoning due to hydrocyanic acid and strychnine
  • Heat stroke
  • asphyxia
  • severe haemorrhage
  • apoplexy
  • pneumonia
  • nervous diseases causing paralysis of the muscle


Other options : 

Option B: Cholera- The onset of rigor is early, and the duration is short. Diseases like typhoid, tuberculosis, and cancer also have early onset and shorter duration of rigor.

Option C: Electrocution- Causes of violent deaths such as electrocution, firearms and lightning have early onset of rigor and shorter duration.

Option D: Strychnine poisoning- In cases of poisoning due to strychnine or hydrocyanic acid, the rigor starts early and persists for a longer duration.

questions.text: 46. A 6-month-old female child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of an abnormal shaped head. On further examination, you notice that the child has a triangle-shaped head, with a pointed forehead and eyes placed abnormally closer to each other. Which of the following sutures would have closed prematurely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The shape of the skull described in the question indicates the abnormality of Trigonocephaly. The metopic suture has closed prematurely.

Craniosynostosis is premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, resulting in an abnormal head shape.

* Primary craniosynostosis: It results from a primary defect of ossification.

* Secondary craniosynostosis: It results from the failure of brain growth.

Trigonocephaly is a skull deformity that presents with a pointed forehead and a midline ridge with hypotelorism. It is caused by the premature closure of the metopic suture which is between the two frontal bones.





Other options:

Option B: Premature closure of sagittal sutures causes Scaphocephaly causing frontal bossing and prominent occiput.

Option C: Brachycephaly is caused by premature closure of bilateral coronal sutures forming a broad and flattened head.

Option D: Premature closure of one side of lambdoid suture causes Plagiocephaly of the respective side.

questions.text: 48. Arrange the following images in ascending order of severity as per WHO grading of Xerophthalmia.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of images in ascending order of severity as per WHO grading of Xerophthalmia is 4 -1-2-3 (Option B). Conjunctival xerosis → Bitot’s spots →  Corneal ulcer → Corneal scar.

In the given image- 1: Stage X1B - Bitot’s spots 2: Stage X3 - Corneal ulcer 3: Stage XS - Corneal scar 4: Stage X1A - Conjunctival xerosis

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can occur as carotenoids (most commonly - beta-carotene from plant sources) or retinoids (from animal sources). Dietary sources of vitamin A are liver, fish, eggs, dark green, and deeply colored fruits and vegetables.

Other functions of Vitamin A include anti-oxidant properties and maintenance of normal epithelial and skin health. Ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency include loss of sensitivity to green light (earliest to appear), nyctalopia (night blindness), and xerophthalmia.

Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot’s spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that lead to corneal scarring and ultimately, blindness. Other manifestations are general impairment of immunity and keratinization of skin (phrynoderma/toad skin).

Treatment: The WHO recommended schedule for all patients above the age of 1 year (except women of reproductive age): 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection should be given immediately on diagnosis (day 0) and repeated the following day (day 1) and 4 weeks later. Children of <1 years age or of any age with weight <8kg should be given half of the dosage given to > 1 year olds.

For women of reproductive age, whether pregnant or not:

* Those with night blindness (XN), conjunctival xerosis (XlA), or Bitot’s spots (XlB) should receive 10,000 IU of vitamin A orally (one sugar-coated tablet daily) for 2 weeks.

* For corneal xerophthalmia, the full vitamin A dosage schedule recommended for patients over 1 year of age should be administered.

questions.text: 49. An 88-year-old frail female with long-standing, symptomatic, full-thickness rectal prolapse presents with fecal incontinence, perineal discomfort, and occasional rectal bleeding. Examination reveals a large, irreducible, circumferential rectal prolapse with mild mucosal ulceration. The prolapse appears incarcerated and strangulated. Which surgical procedure is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Altemeier’s procedure is the best choice for this patient due to its lower operative risk, better tolerance in frail elderly patients, and effectiveness for long-standing, full-thickness prolapse.

Altemeier's procedure is a perineal approach surgery for rectal prolapse. It involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, including any associated colonic prolapse. Colorectal continuity is restored using either a hand-sewn or stapled anastomosis. It is the preferred procedure for incarcerated (irreducible) or strangulated (compromised vascularity) rectal prolapse.

Delorme’s procedure involves stripping the rectal mucosa, plicating the rectal muscle, and excising excess mucosa to reduce short-segment rectal prolapse. It is preferred for short-segment prolapses but has a high recurrence rate. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Laparoscopic ventral mesh rectopexy, Ripstein's procedure (open anterior mesh rectopexy), and Goldberg sutured rectopexy are abdominal procedures. While they have lower recurrence rates, they do carry higher mortality and morbidity risks, especially in frail and elderly patients. Given the patient's age and frailty an abdominal approach is contraindicated.

questions.text: 50. A child presents with features of parkinsonism and spasticity. His MRI brain is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI image showing the eye of the tiger sign, is suggestive of the Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome.

The eye of the tiger sign refers to an abnormal, low T2 signal intensity on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus, with a longitudinal stripe of high signal intensity (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome, or pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), is an autosomal recessive disorder. It causes involuntary spasticity and progressive dementia, along with parkinsonism and dystonia starting from childhood itself. It is a subset of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA). 

The image below shows an MRI depicting the eye of a tiger sign.

Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impressions and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow as shown below. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

Bansdola: Neck is compressed between two bamboo sticks one held in front of the neck and the other behind it.

questions.text: 52. A 23-year-old male presents with fever, retro-orbital pain and extensive petechial rashes for 4 days. He also reports black stools for 2 days. Blood pressure is 100/60mmHg. Lab investigations reveal a low platelet count and low haemoglobin. The patient had a dengue infection about 5 years back. What can be the reason for the worsening condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of dengue infection and non-neutralising heterologous antibodies are responsible for the worsening condition of the patient.

Dengue, also known as break-bone fever, manifests after an incubation period of 3-14 days. Dengue fever is an acute febrile illness with two or more of the following manifestations- headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and rash.

Dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome can occur in individuals with preexisting non-neutralizing heterologous dengue antibodies caused by previous infection with a different serotype of the virus or passively acquired maternal antibodies in children. Initially, symptoms simulate normal dengue however, the patient’s condition worsens.

The virus–antibody complexes are formed within a few days of the second dengue infection, and the non-neutralizing enhancing antibodies promote infection of higher numbers of mononuclear cells followed by the release of cytokines, vasoactive mediators, and procoagulants, leading to the disseminated intravascular coagulation seen in the hemorrhagic fever syndrome. 

The most important pathology of dengue hemorrhagic fever is increased vascular permeability with plasma leakage into the interstitial spaces associated with increased levels of vasoactive cytokines which can lead to life-threatening shock in some patients. The clinical criteria of dengue haemorrhagic fever is dengue fever with hemorrhagic tendencies evidenced by one or more of the following:

* Positive tourniquet test 

* Petechiae, ecchymoses or purpura

* Bleeding from the mucosa, gastrointestinal tract, injection sites or other sites

* Thrombocytopenia, a more than 20% drop in haematocrit following volume replacement treatment compared to baseline

* Signs of plasma leakage (pleural effusion, ascites, hypoproteinemia) 

Dengue shock syndrome is characterised by all the above criteria for dengue haemorrhagic fever with evidence of circulatory failure manifested by rapid, weak pulse and narrow pulse pressure or hypotension for age, cold, clammy skin and restlessness.

questions.text: 53. A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to the abdomen. He is diagnosed to have a retroperitoneal injury with a pulsatile hematoma in the zone highlighted in the image below. Which of the following is true about the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in the image represents Zone 2 of the retroperitoneum and an injury here with a pulsatile hematoma should be treated surgically.

The retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.



Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization


If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done. Pelvic hematomas are difficult to control. Compression and extraperitoneal packing are preferred whenever possible.

questions.text:
54. A 3-year-old male child is brought to the clinic with complaints of biting of nails and lips, spasticity in both lower limbs, involuntary movements, and developmental delay. Lab reports indicate high blood uric acid levels. What of the following abnormality will be seen in this patient?

HGPRT- Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase PRPPS - Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase
questions.solution:
Complaints of biting of nails and lips, spasticity in both lower limbs, involuntary movements, developmental delay, and high blood uric acid levels indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. A complete deficiency of HGPRT enzyme will be seen in this patient.

Lesch Nyhan syndrome is an X- linked recessive disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This enzyme is responsible for recycling purines by converting guanine and hypoxanthine into guanosine monophosphate and inosine monophosphate, respectively. Lack of the enzyme causes an increase in guanine and hypoxanthine, which eventually get converted into uric acid. 

Other options:

Option A: Partial deficiency of HPRT causes a similar syndrome known as Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome. It is similar to Lesch Nyhan syndrome but has mild neurological symptoms and usually does not present with self-destructive behavior.

Option B: PRPPS enzyme (participates in the synthesis and salvage of purines and pyrimidines) is an X-linked enzyme that gets activated by inorganic phosphate and inhibited by purine nucleotides (end product inhibition). Therefore, in Lesch Nyhan Syndrome, there is increased activity of PRPPS.

Option D: There will be increased levels of hypoxanthine in this patient as HGPRT is responsible for recycling purines by converting guanine and hypoxanthine into guanosine monophosphate and inosine monophosphate, respectively. Lack of the enzyme causes an increase in guanine and hypoxanthine, which eventually get converted into uric acid.

Pearl PM2327: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

* Intellectual disability

* Self-mutilation

* Aggression

* Hyperuricemia 

* Gout

Treatment:

* Allopurinol

* Febuxostat

questions.text: 56. Select the correct statement about the principle of ‘Res Ipsa Loquitor.’

choices.text: An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees
For this prinicple to be applicable, the patient should not be guilty of contributory negligence
The patient needs to prove the doctor’s guilt with medical evidence

questions.solution:
For the principle of res ipsa loquitor to be applicable, the patient should not be guilty of contributory negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." It implies that the negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. The patient has to only state the negligent act. This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

* In the absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred.

* The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.

* The patient should not be guilty of contributory negligence.

Other Options:

Option A: Vicarious liability implies that an employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Option C: Res ipsa loquitor can be applied to both Civil and criminal negligence.

Option D: For res ipsa loquitor to be applicable, the negligent act needs to be so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence.

questions.text: 57. Which of the following statements is true regarding the type of cell death represented by '3' in the given agarose gel electrophoresis pattern?

choices.text: Inflammation is absent in this type of cell death
There is activation of apoptotic proteases-caspases
There is activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.
It represents control used in electrophoresis

questions.solution:
In the given image of agarose gel electrophoresis of DNA, '3' represents necrosis. In necrosis, DNA is cleaved by the activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.

* Lane 1 represents control.

* Lane 2 represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. This pattern is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. A DNA ladder is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA between nucleosomes to generate fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs).

* Lane 3 represents a smear pattern seen in the case of necrosis. In necrosis, DNA is usually not cut in an orderly manner due to the activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.

questions.text: 58. An elderly hypertensive male presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. He was started on anti-hypertensives. A CT chest of the patient showed aortic dissection limited to the descending aorta. The patient had persistent pain despite adequate medical therapy. What is the preferred management for this patient?

choices.text: Strict control of blood pressure using beta blockers.
Emergency graft replacement of the descending aorta.

questions.solution:
The patient presents with aortic dissection limited to the descending aorta. As his pain fails to settle despite therapy, he comes under the complicated Stanford type B classification. Percutaneously placed endovascular stent is currently the management of choice over open surgical management in complicated Stanford Type B dissections.

Type III DeBakey/ Stanford Type B dissection is usually managed conservatively. The intervention is indicated in complicated cases with features of:

* Worsening chest pain indicating imminent rupture or failure of resolution of pain

* The progressive expansion of lesion on serial chest imaging (radiograph or CT scan)

* Malperfusion syndrome results in organ dysfunction, such as renal failure, or limb and neurological complications.



Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta




Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta.

Predisposing factors: 

* Age

* Hypertension

* Marfan syndrome

* Pregnancy

* Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus

* Coarctation of the aorta

* Turner or Noonan syndromes

* Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic). 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. Double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

The initial management of patients with all types of aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol.

Treatment options:

* Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

* Stanford Type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. For patients with complicated type B dissection, percutaneously placed endovascular stents are currently preferred. Surgery is reserved for the rare patients not suitable for stenting.

questions.text: 59. When does the gastrointestinal movement depicted in the graph below take place?

choices.text: Between two phases of gastric secretion
During fasting between the periods of digestion

questions.solution:
The type of gastrointestinal motility seen in the given graph is the migrating motor complex (MMC) which shows a pattern of electrical and motor activity that occurs during fasting between the periods of digestion (inter-digestive period).  

MMCs are initiated by motilin. These cycles (MMC) migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and occur at intervals of approximately 100 minutes. It helps to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal. Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC.

After ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC isn't generated. Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases:

* Phase I - quiescent period

* Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity

* Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity



Pearl PM1300: Types of gastrointestinal motility



Pearl PM1301: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: 60. A male patient who lost his job recently became irritable and had a sad mood for most of the time. Thinking about the future made him worried and he felt irritated towards his family members. He occasionally went out for watching movies with his friends and was able to enjoy but on returning home he felt similar symptoms. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sad and irritable mood following a loss of job recently and impairment in the social functioning point to a probable diagnosis of adjustment disorder. 

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event. Stressors may be:

* Single like loss of job or divorce 

* Multiple like the death of a parent together with the loss of a job 

* Recurrent like seasonal business difficulties

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder include:

* Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor

* The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met - 

* The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor

* Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning

* Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder

* The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement

* Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months

Treatment:

* Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice

* Pharmacotherapy- anxiolytic or antidepressant medications 

Others options: 

Option A: Generalized anxiety disorder is excessive worry and anxiety with respect to several activities or events for most days during at least 6 months period. 

Option C: Mixed anxiety with depression is diagnosed when there are subsyndromal symptoms of both anxiety and depression along with autonomic symptoms such as tremors, palpitation, dry mouth, and sensation of churning in the stomach. 

Option D: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events, significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment.

questions.text: 61. A 23-year-old pregnant woman in the active stage of labor requests epidural anesthesia. Immediately following the injection of 1.5% lidocaine with 1:200,000 epinephrine through the epidural catheter, the patient complains of lip numbness and becomes very apprehensive. Her heart rate is 50/min, and her BP is 90/60 mmHg. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The above condition is most likely due to accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic into the epidural vein resulting in local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST).

Features of LAST:

* CNS (in the order of appearance)

* Tinnitus, blurred vision, dizziness, tongue paresthesia, and circumoral numbness

* Excitatory signs such as nervousness, agitation, restlessness, and muscle twitching leading to tonic-clonic seizures

* CNS depression with slurred speech, drowsiness, unconsciousness, and then respiratory arrest

* Patients who have received CNS depressant drugs may present with only CNS depression without any preceding excitatory signs

* CVS

* Prolonged PR intervals and widened QRS complexes, and sinus bradycardia/arrest

* Ventricular arrhythmias, including fibrillation, are more likely to occur with bupivacaine than lidocaine.

Prevention:

* Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anesthesia

* Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline

* Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose

* Close observation for early signs of intravascular injection

Treatment:

* Supplemental oxygen should be given.

* Seizures: Benzodiazepine; if not available, a small dose of propofol or thiopentone. If seizures persist, a neuromuscular blockade to minimize acidosis and hypoxemia

* Cardiac arrest: standard ACLS protocol with few modifications

* Lipid emulsion therapy

* Last resort: cardio-pulmonary bypass

Other options:

Option A: Accidental subdural injection typically causes patchy or delayed anesthesia rather than the immediate CNS toxicity seen in this patient. It also does not explain the lip numbness and apprehension.

Option B: Accidental subarachnoid injection would cause a sudden, profound motor block and severe hypotension rather than CNS toxicity symptoms like lip numbness and apprehension.

Option D: An allergic reaction to lignocaine typically causes rash, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis, not bradycardia and hypotension.

questions.text:
62. A young couple presents to the infertility clinic with failure to conceive for the past 2 years. The male partner has no significant medical history and denies the use of anabolic steroids or prior surgeries. His secondary sexual characteristics are normal, and both testes are palpable and of normal size. Semen analysis findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

* Volume: 2.4 mL

* Sperm concentration: 1.8 million/mL

* Progressive motility: 14%

* Morphology: 3% normal forms

* pH: 7.4
questions.solution:
Low sperm concentration, reduced motility, and 3% normal sperms in a male with the inability to conceive point towards the diagnosis of Oligo-astheno-teratozoospermia (OAT syndrome).

The reference values for normal semen analysis according to WHO are:

 Semen volume (ml)

 ≥ 1.4
Total sperm number (106 per ejaculate) ≥ 39 
Sperm Concentration (per ml) ≥ 16 million
Total motility (%) ≥ 42
Progressive motility (%) ≥ 30
Vitality (%) ≥ 54
Normal forms (%) ≥ 4


OAT syndrome is one of the most common causes of male infertility, often associated with idiopathic factors, varicocele, hormonal imbalances, or genetic conditions (Y-chromosome microdeletions, Klinefelter syndrome). Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome) is a condition that affects sperm count, motility, and morphology and is characterized by:

* Oligospermia (normal sperm concentration: ≥ 16 million/mL) → 1.8 million/mL

* Asthenospermia (normal total motility: ≥ 42%) → 14% motility

* Teratozoospermia (normal forms:≥ 4 %) → 3% normal forms

Management includes addressing underlying causes, hormonal therapy (if applicable), and assisted reproductive techniques (ICSI is often required).

Other options:

Option A: Obstructive azoospermia presents with a complete absence of sperm in semen due to blocked sperm transport. Semen volume is usually low, and fructose is absent. Since this patient has sperm present, obstruction is unlikely.

Option B: Non-obstructive azoospermia results from impaired spermatogenesis, often due to testicular failure, with absent sperm in semen and elevated FSH.

Option D: Globozoospermia is a rare condition where sperm lack acrosomes, impairing fertilization. Sperm count and motility may be normal, unlike the severe oligospermia and asthenospermia seen here.

questions.text: 63. A 22-year-old college student with a history of long-term heavy cannabis use is brought in by his parents due to declining academic performance, lack of motivation, and persistent apathy. He spends most of his time at home, appears indifferent to responsibilities, and has gained weight over the past year. Which of the following best explains his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation is explained by Amotivational syndrome.

Amotivational syndrome is associated with chronic heavy cannabis use and is characterized by apathy, lack of motivation, decreased goal-directed behavior, and social withdrawal. Individuals with this condition often exhibit poor academic or occupational performance, increased sedentary behavior, and weight gain due to inactivity. The patient's history of long-term cannabis use and symptoms of apathy and academic decline strongly support this diagnosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Cannabis withdrawal syndrome typically occurs after cessation of heavy use and includes symptoms such as irritability, insomnia, decreased appetite, restlessness, and anxiety. 

Option C: Major depressive disorder can present with apathy and social withdrawal, it is usually accompanied by persistent sadness, feelings of worthlessness, guilt, and sleep disturbances (insomnia or hypersomnia). 

Option D: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive, persistent worry about various aspects of life, along with symptoms such as restlessness, fatigue, muscle tension, and sleep disturbances.

questions.text: 64. A male baby born 30 hours ago is transferred to the pediatric surgery department with a diagnosis of an imperforate anus. After initial resuscitation in the NICU, you are asked to comment on the next investigation that is needed for surgical management. What would you recommend?
questions.solution:
This patient, with an imperforate anus, should undergo a cross-table lateral X-Ray to classify the malformation.

Once the diagnosis of imperforate anus has been established, it is important to classify the malformation as a high or a low anomaly based on the distance of the formed rectum from the potential anal opening. A cross-table radiograph shows the height of the rectal air and how close it is to the perineum, guiding the surgical management of this condition.

Technique for a cross-table lateral radiograph: A roll has been placed beneath the hips of the infant to elevate the buttocks and allow air to migrate superiorly to the end of the rectum.



Actual crosstable lateral radiograph: Air is visualized distal to the coccyx (arrow in Image 2).



Other options:

Option A: MRI Abdomen & Pelvis is more expensive and not the first line investigation.

Option C: CT abdomen involves radiation exposure, is more expensive, and is time-consuming. While a CT scan can provide detailed anatomical information, it's not the first-line investigation for initial surgical planning in imperforate anus.

Option D: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure. It might be considered later in the surgical management, especially for high-type imperforate anus.

questions.text: 65. A physician believes that the nursing staff is uncomfortable talking to him, when in fact, he is uncomfortable talking with them. The defense mechanism used is
questions.solution:
Projection is a defense mechanism that involves taking our own unacceptable qualities or feelings and ascribing them to other people.

Pearl PM0351: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.


 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: Persistent preoccupation or fear about the possibility of having a serious or life-threatening disease. Physical signs and symptoms are anxiously interpreted as abnormal. 

  • Eg: Believing that one has a tumour which cannot be detected. 

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.


 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.


 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: 66. A woman brought her 13-month-old daughter to the pediatric OPD with recurrent urinary tract infections. Investigations reveal Grade-III vesicoureteral reflux and acute UTI. After treating her infection, which of the following investigation will she be followed up with, after 6 months?
questions.solution:
A dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may help to locate and delineate the scarring.

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

* Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter

* Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation

* Grade III: VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices.

* Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter

* Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

In a typical first episode of urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, initial imaging should be ultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.

A Voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient has atypical features, or after a recurrent febrile UTI.

A dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may help to locate and delineate the scarring.

Magnetic resonance imaging does not have any significant role in the follow-up of this condition.

questions.text: 67. A 7-year-old child was brought by his parents with complaints of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain. Suspecting a helminthic infection, you perform a sigmoidoscopy which reveals a characteristic coconut cake rectum where the adult worm causing the infection is seen as white bodies hanging from the inflamed rectal mucosa. Infection with which of the following helminths is most likely?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain along with sigmoidoscopy revealing a characteristic coconut cake rectum are suggestive of Trichuriasis caused by Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

In heavy infection of 200 adult worms or more, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

The mode of transmission in humans is when the mature embryonated eggs containing the infective larvae are swallowed in contaminated food or water. The eggs hatch in the small intestine. The larva, which emerges through the pole of the egg, passes down into the cecum where it develops into the adult worm.

Here the male and female mate and the female worm lays the unembryonated eggs which are passed in the stool.

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of Trichuris trichiura.



Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

* Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colourless.

* They float in the saturated salt solution.

* It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.



In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Some patients, particularly young children, may develop rectal prolapse.

Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm. Treatment includes mebendazole or albendazole.

Other options:

Option B: Trichinella spiralis is sometimes also known as pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles,

Option C: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method. 

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode infecting humans. The infective form is the embryonated egg containing rhabditiform larva. Demonstration of egg in stool or adult worm in stool or sputum is helpful in diagnosis.

Pearl PM1755: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

* Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve

* Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve

* Wave III – cochlear nucleus

* Wave IV – superior olivary complex

* Wave V – lateral lemniscus

* Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus



Findings:

* Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal

* Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent

* Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

* To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA

* Best audiometric test for:

* Confirming hearing loss in infants

* Diagnosing acoustic neuroma

*

* Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss

* Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: 69. According to its mechanism of action, sumatriptan is a _____.
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B and 5-HT1D receptor agonist. The pharmacological effects of the drug are limited to the 5HT1 family of receptors.

The activation of 5HT1B/1D receptors causes constriction of intracranial blood vessels and restores blood flow to the brain. It also acts by preventing vasoactive peptide release.

Side effects are coronary vasospasm, mild paresthesia, and serotonin syndrome (in combination with other 5-HT agonists).

questions.text: 70. Which of the following options represents the blood supply and site of termination of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the fornix, and the blood supply and site of termination of the fornix are the anterior cerebral artery and mammillary body, respectively. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus, which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. The blood supply of the fornix is by the anterior communicating artery, which arises from the anterior cerebral artery. 

The fornix has two types of fibres:

* Association fibres connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

* Commissural fibres connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

* Projection fibres connect the cerebral cortex with the subcortical grey matter of the cerebral hemispheres, brainstem and spinal cord.

The limbic system is a group of structures between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus. It is involved in emotional and motivational activity, learning, and memory.





Pearl PM2240: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

* Corpus callosum

* Anterior and posterior commissure

* Habenular commissure

* Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

* Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus

* Long association fibers:

* Uncinate fasciculus

* Cingulum

* Superior longitudinal fasciculus

* Inferior longitudinal fasciculus

* Fronto-occipital fasciculus

* Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)



Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

* Internal capsule

* Corona radiata

questions.text: 72. A 50-year-old man who presented with dysphagia was diagnosed with oesophagal carcinoma and underwent multiple cycles of cisplatin. Which of the following is not a side effect of cisplatin?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is not seen with cisplatin use.

Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent that damages renal tubules. Cisplatin-induced renal tubular damage and diuresis typically lead to hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia. It can cause anaemia after multiple cycles of treatment. It particularly affects the reabsorption in the distal tubules, causing:

* Hypomagnesemia

* Hypokalemia

* Hypocalcemia

* Hypophosphatemia

Cisplatin produces responses in cancers of the bladder, head and neck, cervix, and endometrium, all forms of carcinoma of the lung, anal and rectal carcinomas and neoplasms of childhood. The drug also improves the sensitivity of cells to radiation therapy and helps in controlling locally advanced lung, oesophagal, and head and neck tumours when given along with radiation therapy.

questions.text: 73. An 8-year-old boy presents with complaints of dull, aching headaches and difficulty seeing the class board for the past few months. He is below the 25th percentile for height and weight. Deep tendon reflexes are sluggish. Eye examination reveals papilledema and bitemporal hemianopsia. An MRI shows a mixed cystic and solid lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a calcified cystic lesion in the suprasellar region and symptoms of headache with bitemporal hemianopsia is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. 

It is a benign tumor that is derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). 

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous and have both solid and cystic components and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."

Clinical presentation:

* Features of raised intracranial pressure, including headache that is a continuous dull-aching type and papilledema

* Visual impairment, with decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopsia)

* Endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction

Radiological findings:   

* CT: May show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic wall components.

* MRI: 

Cysts
T1 Iso- to hyperintense to the brain (due to high protein content "machinery oil cysts")
T2 Mostly hyperintense
Solid component
T1  Vivid enhancement
T2  Variable or mixed


Other options: 

Option B- Pituitary macroadenomas (with cystic degeneration or necrosis) usually have an intrasellar epicenter with pituitary fossa enlargement rather than suprasellar epicenter. Calcifications are mostly absent, in contrast to craniopharyngiomas. In addition, on imaging, indentation at the diaphragma sellae gives rise to snowman/figure of eight appearance/cottage loaf.

Option C- Optic nerve gliomas can be seen involving the optic nerves, optic chiasm, and optic tracts and can be differentiated from craniopharyngiomas with the help of calcifications that are characteristically seen in the latter. They are a type of pilocytic astrocytes that occur in childhood.

Option D- Rathke's cleft cysts appear completely cystic with a smooth, thin wall and no calcifications on MRI. They are mostly seen in the intrasellar region; this is in contrast to craniopharyngiomas, which are mostly suprasellar.

questions.text: 74. A patient with bronchogenic carcinoma presents to the OPD complaining of hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, you notice that the left vocal cord is in the paramedian position and you start the patient on speech therapy. Which of the following muscles of the larynx is not affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given image-

* Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

* Transverse arytenoid muscle

* Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

* Cricothyroid muscle.

The given case scenario is of unilateral vocal cord palsy secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma which is an important cause of left recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Cricothyroid muscle is not affected in this condition.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid, a tensor of the vocal cord, present between the cricoid and thyroid cartilage, is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, the affected vocal cord assumes a median or paramedian position and does not move laterally on deep inspiration.

One-third of the patients are asymptomatic while the others have some change in voice but no problems with airway obstruction. The voice in unilateral paralysis gradually improves due to compensation by the healthy cord which crosses the midline to meet the paralysed one.

Treatment includes speech therapy, injection laryngoplasty (materials used - autologous fat, carboxymethylcellulose) and thyroplasty type I (medialization thyroplasty).

The lateral cricoarytenoid and transverse arytenoid muscles are adductors of the vocal cord and posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is an abductor of the vocal cord.

questions.text: 76. A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

* Seizures

* Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)

* Hepatomegaly

* Growth retardation

* Hypoglycemia 

* Elevated blood uric acid levels 

* Lactic acidosis

* Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides

* Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

* Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 

* Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.

* Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.

* Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

77. A patient presenting with poor appetite and weight loss along with a few episodes of hematemesis is diagnosed with Siewert type 3 adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the correct anatomical location of adenocarcinoma seen in this patient?

GE junction: Gastroesophageal junction

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma located 4 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 2 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 1 cm distal to GE junction

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction indicates the location of adenocarcinoma seen in patients diagnosed with Siewert type 3 tumours.

Siewert classification system is based on the anatomical location of adenocarcinoma which is in close proximity to the GE junction. Type 3 tumours are also called sub-cardinal tumours and are located 2 to 5 cm below the GE junction. These tumours are usually treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma. Type III adenocarcinomas generally have a worse prognosis. Siewert types I and II tumours are treated similar to oesophagal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: 78. A 60-year-old man diagnosed with Parkinsonian features is unresponsive to levodopa. MRI brain is given below. Which of the following will be the predominant feature seen in the biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Neuronal loss and accumulation of tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the frontotemporal regions
Alpha-synuclein containing cytoplasmic inclusions in oligodendrocytes with silver impregnation
Lewy bodies in neurons of the basal nucleus of Meynert and locus ceruleus
Substantia nigra and locus ceruleus showing neuronal loss, ballooned neurons, and tangles.

questions.solution:
A patient with Parkinsonian features unresponsive to levodopa and an MRI image showing the characteristic hummingbird sign of the brainstem is suggestive of Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). On histopathology in PSP, the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus show neuronal loss, ballooned neurons, and tangles. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a tauopathy and a type of Parkinson's plus syndrome. PSP typically begins with falls and subtle personality changes, such as disinhibition or apathy. It progresses to an oculomotor syndrome characterized by square wave jerks, slowed saccades that are worse in the vertical direction, and vertical gaze palsy (especially downward gaze). Patients also develop dementia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and axial rigidity, leading to a stiff posture with jerky gait.  

The atrophy of the midbrain results in the characteristic hummingbird sign of the brainstem. The preserved pons form the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain, the head, with the beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasma.



In PSP, there is widespread neuronal loss in the globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus, substantia nigra, colliculi, periaqueductal gray matter, and dentate nucleus of the cerebellum. In affected regions of the cortex, there is severe loss of neurons, gliosis, and ballooned neurons. The substantia nigra and locus ceruleus show neuronal loss, ballooned neurons, and tangles. 

Other Options:

Option A: Neuronal loss and accumulation of tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the frontotemporal regions is seen in frontotemporal dementia.

Option B: Alpha-synuclein containing cytoplasmic inclusions in oligodendrocytes with silver impregnation is seen in multiple system atrophy.

Option C: Lewy bodies in the cholinergic neurons of the basal nucleus of Meynert and in other brainstem nuclei including the locus ceruleus are seen in Parkinson's disease.

79. Accidentally administering excess atropine to a patient would manifest as:

* Delirium

* Flushed face

* Hypothermia

* Increased thirst

* Miosis
questions.solution:
Excess atropine would manifest as delirium, flushing, and increased thrist. Hyperthermia and mydriasis are seen in atropine toxicity, not hypothermia and miosis.

Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. It acts through reversible, competitive inhibition of the postsynaptic muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is indicated in the treatment of organophosphate/muscarinic poisoning, in bradycardia, and to reduce salivary secretions.

The adverse effects of atropine are due to the antimuscarinic effects, including xerostomia, blurring of vision, photophobia, tachycardia, flushing, warm, dry skin, constipation, urinary retention, anhidrosis, delirium, and coma. Intoxication with atropine results in all the above symptoms along with convulsions, and circulatory collapse due to respiratory failure. Death may occur secondary to respiratory paralysis.

Below is an image of a mnemonic to remember the symptoms of atropine overdose.



Treatment of atropine intoxication includes administration of a short-acting barbiturate or diazepam to control convulsions. Physostigmine is used as an antidote to atropine poisoning to treat delirium and coma. Other measures for symptomatic management are respiratory support and control of hyperthermia.

questions.text: 80. A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have a bilateral loss of peripheral visual fields. On tonometry, intraocular pressure was raised. Fundoscopy showed cupping and pallor of the optic disc. Iridocorneal angle was normal on gonioscopy. He is started on a topical drug that reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The topical drug started that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow is latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog. It is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

This patient's findings of peripheral vision loss, increased intraocular pressure (IOP) with optic disc cupping, and a normal iridocorneal angle is suggestive of open-angle glaucoma.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

questions.text: 81. A researcher is studying four drugs—1, 2, 3, and 4—all of which act on the same receptor. Based on your understanding of pharmacodynamics, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The intrinsic activity of drug 1 is supramaximal
The affinity of drug 3 is zero
The intrinsic activity of drug 2 is submaximal
The affinity of drug 4 is zero

questions.solution:
The correct answer is that the intrinsic activity of drug 2 is submaximal.

The two-state model of receptor activity describes receptors existing in equilibrium between an active (Ra) and inactive (Ri) state, contributing to basal (constitutive) activity. The y axis (e.g., 100, 200, etc.) indicates the degree of receptor response based on ligand binding. In the absence of any ligand, the receptor maintains a basal (constitutive) activity level, set arbitrarily at 100 units (because even without an agonist, some receptors are in the Ra (active) state and producing a response).

The affinity of a drug determines the concentration needed to form a specific number of drug-receptor associations. A higher affinity means less concentration is required compared to a drug with a lower affinity. In contrast, intrinsic activity refers to the drug's ability to induce functional changes in the receptor.

* Agonists have both affinity and maximal intrinsic activity (IA = 1), like adrenaline, histamine, and morphine (but there is no concept of "supramaximal IA", as no drug can exceed a receptor's maximum capacity). Full agonists shift the equilibrium toward Ra, increasing activity significantly (e.g., 200 units).

* Partial agonists have affinity with submaximal intrinsic activity (IA between 0 and 1); examples include dichloroisoproterenol (β-adrenergic receptor) and buspirone (5-HT1A receptor). Partial agonists also shift the balance toward Ra, but to a lesser extent (e.g., 150 units).

* Competitive antagonists, such as propranolol, atropine, and naloxone, have affinity but no intrinsic activity (IA = 0). These bind equally to Ra and Ri, maintaining the basal activity at 100 without increasing or decreasing it.

* Inverse agonists bind to a receptor and reduce its basal activity (IA between 0 and -1). Unlike antagonists, which only block receptor activity, inverse agonists actively suppress it. These selectively bind Ri (inactive state), shifting the equilibrium left and reducing the receptor’s constitutive activity.

questions.text: 82. A couple comes to a gynecologist to seek a natural method of contraception. The doctor explains Billing’s method of contraception. This method of contraception refers to:
questions.solution:
Billing’s method for contraception refers to the cervical mucus method.

In the mucus method (Billings or ovulation method), the woman predicts the fertile period by feeling the consistency of cervical mucus. Under the influence of estrogen, there is an increased amount of mucus which becomes progressively more slippery and elastic until a peak is reached. Under the influence of progesterone, the mucus becomes scanty, thicker, and dry until the onset of menses.

The days considered safe for intercourse are the dry days, immediately after the menses until mucus is detected. The couple must abstain for four days after the peak day.

The image given below shows mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle:



Other options:

Option A: The symptothermal method employs the combined use of the temperature, cervical mucus, and calendar techniques for identifying the fertile period. The use of multiple methods makes it more effective.

Option C: Also known as the "calendar method", the rhythm method is based on calculating the fertile period of the female. The calculations are as follows :

* First day of fertile period: Shortest cycle - 18 days

* Last day of fertile period: Longest cycle - 10 days

Intercourse is then avoided during this fertile period.

Option D: In Coitus interruptus, no costs or appliances are required and is practiced by the withdrawal of the penis right before ejaculation. This prevents the deposition of semen in the vagina. This method of contraception has a high rate of failure (up to 25%) where the major drawbacks are that precoital secretions may contain sperm and that even a drop of semen might be adequate to cause conception. Poorly timed withdrawal might also lead to pregnancy.

questions.text:
83. Observe the following image and choose the correct statements about the drug X.

* It is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase 

* Patients with multiple sclerosis who are administered this drug will experience hyperkalemia

* Tachycardia is a common cardiac dysrhythmia seen in children

* History of malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication to its use

* Sugammadex reverses the effect of this drug
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct regarding the above image. The image shows the train-of-four stimulation (TOF). The image shows that following the administration of a muscle relaxant, the amplitude of all twitches has reduced to a similar extent. This is the pattern of depolarizing muscular block, which is seen characteristically in succinylcholine. 

TOF is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade. It consists of four supramaximal stimuli delivered no more than 10 seconds apart. It is calculated by dividing the amplitude of the fourth response by the amplitude of the first response and requires an objective measure of the response to stimulation. The TOF count denotes the number of detectable evoked responses, and it correlates to the degree of neuromuscular block

With a depolarizing block, as in SCh, phase 1 will show a decrease in amplitude in all four twitches simultaneously but no progressive decline in amplitude. If repeated doses or a prolonged infusion are given, phase 2 blockade will show a gradual decrease in amplitude.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It acts by depolarizing the muscle similar to the action of acetylcholine. However, compared to acetylcholine, it acts for a longer duration and causes flaccid paralysis. It has a faster onset and shortest duration. It is administered intravenously. If there is no access to veins, it can also be administered intramuscularly.

The drug is broken down by butyrylcholinesterase (also known as pseudocholinesterase/ plasma cholinesterase). Patients with a deficiency of this enzyme may experience delayed recovery from this agent.

It is extensively used in the clinical setting for rapid sequence intubation due to its short onset of action.

Important side effects of these drugs are malignant hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, fasciculations, bradycardia, and hyperkalemia. Conditions like neuromuscular diseases involving denervation like multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy, stroke, rhabdomyolysis, burns, and pre-existing hyperkalemia can further aggravate hyperkalemia.

Succinylcholine is absolutely contraindicated in patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia. 

Sugammadex does not reverse the effect of succinylcholine.
