questions.text: 84. A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The parents have noticed a pinkish-red patch, as shown below, which becomes more prominent when the baby cries. The lesion blanches with pressure and has been present since birth. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

choices.text: It is unilateral and permanent, often associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome
It is associated with a family history of vascular malformations
It is also found on the face and usually resolves on it's own

questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the image is a stork bite or nevus simplex. These lesions are also found on the face and usually resolve on their own.

Nevus simplex is a common, pale pink vascular macule seen in newborns, typically on the glabella (salmon patches), eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. These lesions become more visible with crying or temperature changes and usually fade over time, though those on the posterior neck (stork bites)often persist. Nevus simplex does not have a familial predisposition, nor does it require any surgical intervention (Option B and C).

Treatment is not required, but pulsed dye laser therapy can be used for persistent, cosmetically bothersome cases. Midline lumbosacral lesions with additional abnormalities (sinus, patch of hair, or pit) require imaging for spinal dysraphism. Nevus simplex is symmetrical and should not be mistaken for a port wine stain, which is unilateral and permanent, often associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome. (option A)

questions.text: 85. In a study group of 200 people, the mean value of haemoglobin obtained is 12g/dL with a standard deviation of 1g/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, how many people will have haemoglobin between 10 to 11g/dl?
questions.solution:
27 people will have haemoglobin between 10g/dl and 11g/dl.

Assuming normal distribution -  Mean (μ) = 12 g/dL Standard Deviation (σ) = 1 g/dL 11g/dL corresponds to -1 standard deviation  10g/dL corresponds  to -2 standard deviation



In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

* 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean.

* 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean.

* 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

The percentage of individuals between -1 standard deviation and -2 standard deviation is 95%-68% divided by 2 which is 13.5 percent. 13.5 percent of 200 is 27. So, 27 people have hemoglobin between 10g/dl and 11g/dl.

Pearl PM1007: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.



Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

* Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation

* Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

* Mean = median = mode

* Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak

* Total area under the curve is 1

* Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails

* No skew in the curve

* Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution

* The empirical rule of a normal distribution:

* Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)

* Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)

* Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: 86. The mean arterial pressure is calculated as _______
questions.solution:
* The mean arterial pressure is the average of the arterial pressures measured millisecond by millisecond over a period of time.

* It is not equal to the average of systolic and diastolic pressure because the arterial pressure remains nearer to diastolic pressure than to systolic pressure during the greater part of the cardiac cycle.

* The mean arterial pressure = DBP + 1/3 Pulse pressure = DBP + 1/3 (SBP-DBP) = (3DBP + SBP – DBP)/3 = 2/3 DBP + 1/3 SBP = (SBP + 2DBP)/3

* The mean arterial pressure is (SBP + 2DBP)/3.

questions.text: 87. A 60 year old male patient who previously underwent surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm, now complains of severe abdominal pain with bloody diarrhoea. On examination, his BP is 90/60 and guarding is noted. Ischemia of the large bowel is suspected. Which of the following signs is likely to be seen on an abdominal radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with an acute abdomen, bloody diarrhoea and hypotension in the background of abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, is suggestive of ischemic colitis. Thumbprinting sign, which occurs due to mucosal edema and submucosal hemorrhage, is characteristic on plain abdominal radiograph.



Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is a well-known risk factor for developing ischemic colitis, due to possible compromise of the inferior mesenteric artery.

Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure (Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery which connect the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) in these locations.



Other options:

Option A: Cupola sign is a sign of pneumoperitoneum wherein accumulation of air under the central tendon of the diaphragm is noted on plain x-ray.



Option B: Coffee-bean sign or omega sign on plain x-ray is seen in sigmoid volvulus when the sigmoid colon is twisted about its axis.



Option D: Stepladder sign is seen in small bowel obstruction due to the presence of air in the bowel causing the valvulae conniventes of the jejunum to be seen clearly, appearing to show a laddering effect.

questions.text:
88. A patient presented with features shown in the image. Genetic testing reveals an ABCA1 mutation. Which of the following would most likely be seen in his lab report?

HDL - High density lipoprotein

VLDL - Very low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The presence of orange tonsils in conjunction with an ABCA1 mutation indicates a potential diagnosis of Tangier's disease, characterized by significantly reduced levels of apo A1 in the patient's lipid profile. Normal or low cholesterol may be seen in patients with Tangiers but is not specific to the disease.

In the human body, apo A1 increases the levels of ABCA1 and ABCA1 in turn helps in the stabilization of the Apo A1. Apo A1 functions to activate LCAT which helps in the incorporation of cholesterol into the HDL. A mutation in ABCA1 would lead to increased catabolism of Apo A1 (low levels) which would lead to low incorporation of cholesterol into HDL. The various manifestations of the disease is due to the accumulation of cholesterol in the cells ie. defective clearance by HDL.

The lipid profile of a patient with Tangier's is most likely going to be :

HDL (Option C) ↓ ↓ 
LDL (Option D) ↓ 
TAG ↑ 
Total Cholesterol (Option B) Normal/Low
Apo A1 ↓ ↓ 


ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells to HDL. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus defective ABCA1 will lead to almost nil HDL in the blood. ABCA1 is a protein belonging to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family. ABC proteins utilize the energy derived from the breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to facilitate the transportation of various substances, such as lipids, across cellular membranes and intracellular compartments.

Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive  disease that can present as one of the following:

* Asymmetric multiple neuropathies

* A slowly progressive symmetric polyneuropathy

* A pseudo-syringomyelia pattern with dissociated sensory loss

* Corneal opacities

* Premature atherosclerosis 

* Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia

* Skin ulcers, scalds and burns 

In this condition, the tonsils may appear yellowish-orange and there may be a splenomegaly with lymphadenopathy.

Differential Diagnosis of Tangier Disease : 

* Apo A-I deficiency

* LCAT deficiency

* Fish eye disease

Tangier disease management involves low-fat diet changes, injury prevention, and management of cardiac problems. The utilisation of Dalcetrapib, a Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitor, in conjunction with reconstituted HDL, could be considered as an interim therapeutic approach until more advanced treatments are produced.

questions.text: 89. A patient with respiratory failure is found to have a normal P(A-a)O2. Which of the following diseases would lead to this finding and what is the mechanism behind the finding?
questions.solution:
Respiratory failure with a normal P(A-a)O2 gradient is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by ventilation defects. The findings include:

* PaO2- decreased

* PaCO2- increased

* P(A-a)O2- normal

Examples are-

* Myasthenia gravis

* Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

* Guillain-Barre syndrome

* Cervical cord injury

* Myopathy

Type I (Hypoxemic) Respiratory Failure results from V/Q mismatch or shunting, causing low oxygen (PaO₂↓) with an increased P(A-a)O₂ gradient. Common causes include pulmonary edema, pneumonia, and ARDS, managed with oxygen, PEEP, and lung-protective ventilation.

Type II (Hypercapnic) Respiratory Failure is due to alveolar hypoventilation, leading to CO₂ retention (PaCO₂↑) with a normal P(A-a)O₂. Causes include CNS depression, neuromuscular disorders, and airway obstruction, treated with NIPPV and addressing the cause. Type III (Atelectasis) and Type IV (Metabolic) occur post-surgery and in shock states, respectively, requiring lung recruitment strategies and circulatory support.

questions.text: 90. A 60-year-old man presents with difficulty maintaining balance while walking. On examination, he has truncal ataxia and struggles to keep his gaze steady when looking to the side. His limb coordination remains intact. Which cerebellar nucleus is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation suggests cerebellar degeneration. The fastigial nucleus is most likely affected in this patient as he has truncal ataxia, difficulty maintaining balance, and impaired gaze stabilization.

The cerebellar nuclei are arranged from lateral to medial in the following order: Dentate → Emboliform → Globose → Fastigial.

This arrangement reflects their respective functions, with lateral nuclei handling fine, voluntary limb movements and medial nuclei focusing on axial and postural control.



Functions of Cerebellar Nuclei are:

* Dentate nucleus – Coordinates fine voluntary movements, especially of the limbs.

* Emboliform nucleus – Regulates limb movements, particularly during ongoing motion.

* Globose nucleus – Helps coordinate proximal limb movements and maintain muscle tone.

* Fastigial nucleus – Maintains truncal stability, balance, and gaze control.

* Floccular nucleus – Controls eye movement and smooth pursuit.

Lobes: Whole anterior lobe (except Lingula), Pyramid and Uvula

Main connection: Spino-cerebellar

Nuclei: Interposed (Globose and Emboliform) 

Function: Maintenance of muscle tone and finer control of movements
Neocerebellum (most recent part)

Whole posterior lobe except Pyramid and Uvula

Main connection:  Cortico-ponto-cerebellar

Nuclei: Dentate

questions.text: 92. A 36-year-old female patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with decreased hearing in both ears, often associated with a ringing sensation for the past few years. The Rinne test was negative and the Schwartze sign is seen on otoscopy. Which of the following will be seen in her tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical history, negative Rinne test and positive Schwartze sign is seen in active otosclerosis. Tympanometry will show low compliance near ambient air pressure (As) graph in this case.

Tympanogram is a measure of the Tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to change in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:

* A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in the general population. 

* As: Seen in otosclerosis/Thick TM.

* Ad: Seen in ossicular discontinuity/Thin TM.

* B: Seen in perforation of TM

* C: Eustachian tube Obstruction

Otosclerosis is bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, menopause.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).

Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicates that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz knows as Carhart's notch. 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Stapedial reflex: As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.



A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

questions.text: 93. Which of the following is seen in the lag phase of the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
Maximum cell size is seen in the lag phase of the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

* Lag phase: Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size (option C) is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.

* Log phase or exponential phase: In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 

* Stationary phase: Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells formed equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation (option A) occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins (option B) and antibiotics.

* Phase of decline: In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms (option D) are common.

questions.text: 94. During the examination of a meniscal tear case in the orthopedics ward, you observe the patient cannot extend his right knee fully owing to pathological locking of the joint. What is this type of joint?
questions.solution:
Locking and unlocking of joints observed in this patient. This type of movement is exhibited by bicondylar joints.  

Bicondylar joints are a type of uniaxial hinge joint that includes two additional condyles, allowing movement in a second plane perpendicular to the primary one. Bicondylar joints are seen in the knee (both the condyles are inside a single fibrous capsule) and temporomandibular joint (each condyle has its own fibrous capsule).

Other Options: Option A: Pivot joint is a type of uniaxial joint characterized by a twisting kind of movement of pivot around the osteoligamentous ring (like radial head in annular ligament and ulnar notch) or ring around the pivot (like atlas around dens of axis).

Option B: The hinge joint is a synovial joint where movement occurs in a single stationary plane like in the case of interphalangeal joints and humeroulnar joints. Although the knee joint is sometimes considered a modified hinge joint, the bicondylar joint (C) is the better answer among the options.

Option D: The ball and socket joint is a multiaxial joint that involves a globoid/oval head that articulates inside a bony socket. Examples include - Hip and shoulder joints.

questions.text: 95. A 35-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. A barium swallow image is shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with hiatus hernia
Most commonly seen in middle third of esophagus

questions.solution:
The given barium swallow showing a thin submucosal circumferential ring at the squamocolumnar junction is suggestive of Schatzki's ring. The true statement regarding the condition is, that it is associated with hiatus hernia.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. Schatzki's ring is a non-malignant condition and is often associated with a hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

questions.text: 96. Which of the following is not a fundus examination finding of Stargardt's disease?
questions.solution:
Bone spicule retinal pigmentation is not seen on fundus examination of Stargardt’s disease. It is seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa.

Stargardt’s disease is an inherited retinal degeneration that develops in adolescence and is the most common cause of inherited macular dystrophy in children and adults. The most common variety presents as an autosomal recessive mutation in the ABCA4 gene on Chromosome 1p, which causes difficulties in the retinal recycling of 11-cis-retinal. 

The clinical presentation is of a child or adolescent with deteriorating central vision. Once the visual acuity goes below 6/12, there is rapid loss of vision and prognosis is poor. On Fundus examination the following patterns are noted:

* Non-specific mottling in the macula

* Snail-slime maculopathy surrounded by flecks(Option A)

* Beaten bronze appearance(paramacular)(Option C)

* Bull’s eye maculopathy(Option B)

* Geographic atrophy 

* Posterior pole flecks

Investigatory findings in Stargardt disease include a dark choroid in fundus fluorescein angiogram(FFA) due to blockage of background fluorescence by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) with mixed hyper and hypofluorescence in the macula. OCT shows outer retinal atrophy and ERG may be subnormal. Fundus flavimaculatus is considered a variant of this condition.

Treatment involves avoidance of Vitamin A supplementation(which increases lipofuscin accumulation) and avoidance of exposure to high energy light.

The below images show a Normal choroid in FFA,  followed by the FFA image in Stargardt's disease showing the dark choroid/silent choroid sign.





Other Options:

Option D: Bone spicute pigmentation of the retina is characteristic of Retinitis pigmentosa.

questions.text: 97. Activated charcoal is a:
questions.solution:
Activated charcoal acts as a mechanical antidote.

Mechanical antidotes- They neutralise poisons by mechanical action or prevention of their absorption.

* Activated charcoal- It acts mechanically by adsorbing and retaining organic and mineral poisons within its pores and thus delays the absorption from the stomach.

* Demulcents- substances that coat the gastric mucous membrane and thus do not permit the poisons to    cause any damage, e.g. milk, starch, egg-white, mineral oil, milk of magnesia, aluminium hydroxide gel, etc

* Bulky food is the mechanical antidote to glass powder, wherein it acts by imprisoning its particles within its meshes.

Chemical antidotes- They neutralise poison by forming harmless or insoluble compounds or by oxidation when it is brought in contact with them.

* Common salt decomposes silver nitrate, forming the insoluble silver chloride.

* Potassium permanganate has oxidising properties. 1:5000 solution is used in opium poisoning.

Chelating agents (metal complexing agents) are used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. The metal-agent complex is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex.

questions.text: 98. A 36-year-old male, who was admitted to the ICU following a road traffic accident (RTA) three days ago, underwent an MRI of the brain which revealed an injury in the ventral region of the medulla. Based on the location of the injury, which of the following is the most likely expected finding in this patient's breathing pattern?

choices.text: Increase in the depth of inspiration
Long pauses of breathing during sleep

questions.solution:
The most likely expected finding in this patient's breathing pattern is irregular respiratory rhythm.

The ventral respiratory group (VRG) of neurons, located in the ventral medulla, plays a critical role in forced or active respiration, particularly during increased respiratory demand (e.g., exercise or stress). While the VRG is mostly inactive during quiet breathing, it becomes essential for generating strong expiratory signals during heavy breathing and contributes to inspiratory signals when respiratory drive is high.

If the VRG is damaged, the patient may lose the ability to increase respiratory effort during periods of high demand. This can lead to irregular breathing patterns and respiratory failure, especially under stress or when the body requires increased ventilation.

Other options: 

Option B: Increase in the depth of inspiration: This is controlled by the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) and the pneumotaxic center, not the VRG. Damage to the VRG would not directly affect the depth of inspiration.

Option C: Shallow, slow, and regular breathing: It suggests metabolic or drug-induced depression of the medullary respiratory centers. It is not directly related to VRG damage.

Option D: Long pauses of breathing during sleep: It is seen in Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA). It is characterized by repeated episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep, leading to pauses in breathing and disrupted sleep. It is primarily a disorder of upper airway mechanics and neuromuscular control, not directly related to VRG damage.

questions.text: 100. A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd September. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days in a calendar as shown below when he is supposed to take the vaccine. Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?
questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Essen regimen which is intramuscular.

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which one dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each (1,1,1,1,1). It is an intramuscular regimen, and in this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds. Rabies Immunoglobulin for passive immunisation is given locally, preferably on the first day of post-exposure prophylaxis and not beyond the seventh day after the first dose.

Thai Red Cross regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each. (2-2-2-0-2). It is an intradermal regimen, and in this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each. Rabies Immunoglobulin for passive immunisation is given locally, preferably on the first day of post-exposure prophylaxis and not beyond the seventh day after the first dose.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

* Cleansing- The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimises the contraction of rabies.

* Chemical treatment- Irrigation of the wound should be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.

* Suturing- Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.

* Other measures- Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoids should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound


Pearl PM1725: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:



WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted). There are no contraindications to post-exposure prophylaxis for rabies. It can be safely administered to pregnant women, infants, and immunocompromised individuals.

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

* Passive immunization

* Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine

* Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight

* Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.

* Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

* RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.

* The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.

* RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

* Multiple bites

* Deep wounds

* Bites to head, neck, and hands

* Patients with severe immunodeficiency

* Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal

* Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

* High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.

* Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult

* Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year

* Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

* Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm

* Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.

* Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

* High-risk individuals who receive pre-exposure prophylaxis should have their neutralising antibody titres checked every six months during the first 2 years following immunisation, and every 2 years thereafter. If the levels fall below 0.5 IU/ml, a booster dose of vaccine is recommended. 

Management of re-exposure to rabies virus

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

* Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency

* Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment 

For any exposed or re-exposed patient who has received and can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP:

* Proper wound management

* One site ID / IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3

* RIG not given

Only in case of exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP within the last three months, adequate wound washing alone is required.

questions.text: 101. Which of the following does not indicate chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI)?
questions.solution:
Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) includes ischemic rest pain, ulceration and gangrene, and ABPI <0.4. Chronic limb ischemia usually does not produce paralysis.

Chronic arterial occlusion in the legs presents as intermittent claudication. This is a cramp-like pain that is brought on by walking some distance and relieved by rest, usually within 5 minutes. The pain of intermittent claudication is absent on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis), but is brought on as the patient walks some distance. The distance that the patient is able to walk comfortably — known as claudication distance — decreases as the disease progresses.

At some point, the perfusion to the leg is so severely compromised that there's inadequate oxygen delivery even at rest. This stage is known as rest pain. This kind of pain is worse on lying down or elevation of the foot, because the perfusion is further compromised when the effects of gravity are absent. Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene. Patients with CLTI require urgent vascular intervention. Unlike acute limb ischemia, chronic limb ischemia usually does not result in paralysis and loss of sensation.

Quantitative assessment of peripheral arterial disease can be done with ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI). It is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is the numerator, and the highest brachial systolic pressure is the denominator.

Interpretation:

* >1.4:  Calcified vessels (chronic kidney disease, diabetes)

* >0.9 to < 1.4: Normal

* <0.9: Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion

* <0.4 – CLTI

Pearl PM2294: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.


Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: 102. A 30-year-old male patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall on an outstretched hand. An X-ray of his wrist is normal. Which of the following type of cast is applied?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a fall on an outstretched hand with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox despite normal X-ray findings is suggestive of scaphoid fracture. Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a scaphoid cast applied in a glass-holding position.

Scaphoid Fracture is the most common carpal fracture. A scaphoid fracture typically occurs due to direct axial pressure or hyperextension of the wrist, often caused by falling onto an outstretched hand. Fractures usually occur in three anatomical locations: distal tubercle, waist or proximal pole.

Discomfort is typically felt along the radial side of the wrist, just below the base of the thumb, and may be accompanied by with swelling that may not be apparent. Pain and fullness of anatomical snuff box is characteristic. Wrist movement maybe painful.

Whenever fracture is suspected, an oblique view of the wrist, in addition to the anteroposterior and lateral views, is essential. But x-ray of the wrist has a high false-negative rate. Hence empiric splinting or MRI is recommended as the next step in such cases where clinical suspicion exists but X-ray findings are normal. Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a scaphoid cast applied in a glass-holding position. In displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation with compression screw (Herbert's screw) is preferred.

The common complications of scaphoid fracture include:

* Non-union and delayed union

* Avascular necrosis

* Wrist osteoarthritis



Option (A) Colle’s cast (handshaking) is done in case of fracture of distal end of radius, at cortico-cancellous junction.

Option (B) and (D) Hanging cast and U-slab is applied in case of fracture of humerus.

Pearl PM2033: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.



 

Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.

 



 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.



 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.



 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: 103. A 55-year-old male, who is a known case of chronic kidney disease and diabetes mellitus, undergoes dialysis. During the session, he became drowsy and his BP was found to be 90/70 mmHg. Which of the following is not beneficial in preventing intradialytic hypotension?

choices.text: Rapid fluid removal (>13 mL/kg per h)

questions.solution:
Intradialytic hypotension (IDH) is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus. Excessively rapid fluid removal (>13 mL/kg per h) should be avoided, as rapid fluid removal has been associated with adverse outcomes, including cardiovascular deaths.

Numerous factors appear to increase the risk of hypotension, including excessive ultrafiltration with inadequate compensatory vascular filling, impaired autonomic responses and overzealous use of antihypertensive agents.

The management of hypotension during dialysis consists of discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline or the administration of salt-poor albumin.

Hypotension during dialysis can frequently be prevented by ultrafiltration modelling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis procedure. Increasing the dialysis frequency (short-daily dialysis), sequential ultrafiltration, cooling of the dialysate, avoiding heavy meals during dialysis and individualized dialysate sodium prescription can also help prevent intradialytic hypotension

Anaphylactoid reactions to the dialyzer and muscle cramps are other complications associated with hemodialysis.

questions.text:
104. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which sFlt-1 contributes to the pathophysiology of preeclampsia?

sFlt-1 - Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1  VEGF- Vascular endothelial growth factor  PIGF - Placental growth factor TNF-α - Tumor necrosis factor-alpha PGI2 - Prostaglandin I2

choices.text: It inactivates VEGF & PlGF, preventing their interaction with endothelial receptors
It increases TNF-α and interleukins contributing to systemic oxidative stress
It directly binds to endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), reducing nitric oxide (NO) production
It upregulates endothelin-1 and thromboxane A2 production & downregulates PGI2

questions.solution:
sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1) is an anti-angiogenic factor secreted in excess by the placenta in preeclampsia and it inactivates VEGF & PlGF, preventing their interaction with endothelial receptors.

It acts as a soluble decoy receptor that binds to VEGF and PlGF, preventing them from interacting with their receptors (VEGFR-1, VEGFR-2) on endothelial cells. Elevated maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and reduce circulating PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction. High levels of sFlt-1 in the second trimester are associated with a much higher risk for preeclampsia development.

Other options:

Option B: While inflammation and oxidative stress play a role in preeclampsia, sFlt-1 does not directly mediate TNF-α or interleukin upregulation. Instead, the primary mechanism is VEGF and PlGF inhibition leading to endothelial dysfunction.

Option C: sFlt-1 does not directly bind to eNOS, but it indirectly reduces NO production by inhibiting VEGF signaling, which normally activates eNOS to maintain vascular homeostasis.

Option D: Endothelin-1 and thromboxane A2 are elevated in preeclampsia, but this is not directly caused by sFlt-1. Instead, sFlt-1 induces endothelial dysfunction, which secondarily leads to increased endothelin-1 and thromboxane A2 levels.

questions.text: 105. A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. Which of the following liver enzyme profiles can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
AST: ALT ratio of < 1 will be seen in this patient with chronic hepatitis B (chronic viral hepatitis).

The AST: ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

Chronic viral hepatitis, Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease

>2:1 Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1
Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: 106. A middle-aged man presents with complaints of upper abdominal discomfort, nausea, and bloating for the past 2 weeks. The decision to start on omeprazole was made after an assessment of his symptoms. The patient has also been taking voriconazole for the last 2 months. Taking his drug history into consideration what changes will you make to his current prescription?

choices.text: Decrease omeprazole dose due to CYP2D6 inhibition
Increase omeprazole dose due to CYP2D6 induction
Decrease omeprazole dose due to CYP2C19 inhibiton
Increase omeprazole dose due to CYP2C19 induction

questions.solution:
Omeprazole dose has to be decreased due to CYP2C19 inhibition by Voriconazole. Voriconazole is a strong inhibitor and substrate of CYP2C19. Concomitant omeprazole administration can result in increased omeprazole levels because of inhibition of metabolism.

In a patient on omeprazole 40 mg/day, the dose of omeprazole should be reduced to half when voriconazole is initiated. Additionally, higher levels of omeprazole can also interfere in voriconazole metabolism as omeprazole also inhibits CYP2C19.

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19.

CYP2C19: Common drugs that are metabolized include omeprazole, phenytoin, diazepam, and propanolol. Inducers of the CYP2C subfamily are rifampicin and carbamazepine. Omeprazole is an inhibitor.

CYP2D6: Drugs metabolized include SSRIs,  tricyclic antidepressants, antiarrhythmic drugs, beta-blockers, and opiates. It is inhibited by quinidine and it will prevent the formation of morphine from codeine. Hence quinidine decreases the analgesic effect of codeine.

Following drugs are metabolized by CYP2C19 :-

* Omeprazole

* Clopidogrel

* Voriconazole

* Mephenytoin

* Proguanil

* Hexobarbital

questions.text:
107. Match the physiological functions with their hormones or enzymes.

1. Completion of ovulation a. FSH
2. Implantation b. Hyaluronidase
3. Penetration of Zona pellucida c. LH
4. Spermatogenesis d. Progesterone
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a.

1. Completion of ovulation c. LH
2. Implantation d. Progesterone
3. Penetration of Zona pellucida b. Hyaluronidase
4. Spermatogenesis a. FSH


The LH surge triggers ovulation. Prior to ovulation, oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis. The LH surge causes the final maturation of the oocyte, triggering the completion of meiosis I (reduction division) and the progression of the oocyte to metaphase II. This is the stage at which the oocyte is released from the ovary during ovulation. Thus, the LH surge is crucial for both the completion of oocyte maturation and ovulation.

Progesterone plays a critical role in preparing the decidua for implantation. It is produced by the corpus luteum after ovulation and maintains the uterine lining, ensuring it is receptive for the blastocyst to implant. Progesterone inhibits uterine contractions, allowing the blastocyst to stay securely in place. At 6–8 weeks, the corpus luteum's functions are transferred to the placenta. 

Sperm undergoes the acrosome reaction, which releases hyaluronidase from its acrosome, which helps it penetrate the zona pellucida.

The anterior pituitary secretes FSH, which plays a crucial role in stimulating spermatogenesis. FSH enhances the activity of Sertoli cells, which also secrete inhibin. Inhibin negatively regulates FSH production via feedback.

questions.text: 108. A 65-year-old male patient presents with a history of a feeling of fullness in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, along with night sweats, fatigue, and weight loss for the last 1 month. On examination, the spleen was palpable, and marrow aspirate revealed a dry tap. The peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient gives a history of night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, and a clinically palpable spleen, which indicates massive splenomegaly due to secondary hematopoiesis. Marrow aspirate showing dry tap signifies extensive marrow fibrosis. This points to the diagnosis of Primary Myelofibrosis.

A peripheral smear of the patient shows tear-shaped RBCs called dacrocytes along with nucleated erythroid precursors.



Primary myelofibrosis is most commonly seen in the elderly age group and the most common genetic mutation seen is the JAK2 mutation.

The characteristic feature is extensive deposition of collagen in the marrow, and the two factors responsible are TGF beta and PDGF, which are synthesised by the neoplastic megakaryocytes. Fibrotic obliteration of marrow causes secondary hematopoiesis, which leads to splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy may also show clustered atypical megakaryocytes (cloud-like).

The disease usually presents in the elderly with normocytic normochromic anaemia. Hyperuricemia and secondary gout may also be seen in the early course due to the high cell turnover rate.

The stain used in the bone marrow biopsy is the reticulin stain used to stain reticulin fibres. Myelofibrosis is diagnosed by the presence of fibrosis in the bone marrow.



Other options:

Option A: Chronic myeloid leukaemia is characterised by leukocytosis. The peripheral blood smear shows mature neutrophils, metamyelocytes, and myelocytes.

Option C: Essential thrombocytosis presents with thrombosis and haemorrhage. There is an absence of marrow fibrosis. Peripheral smear shows abnormally large platelets with mild leucocytosis.

Option D: Acute myeloid leukaemia presents with fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding. The peripheral smear shows myeloblasts which contain auer rods.

questions.text: 109. A clinician is using the Matzke nomogram to guide the administration of vancomycin in a hospital setting. Which of the following parameters should be plotted on the x-axis?
questions.solution:
Creatinine clearance should be used on the x-axis in the Matzke nomogram.

The Matzke nomogram provides dosing intervals ranging from 0.5 to 12 days based on creatinine clearance. Each creatinine clearance value on the x-axis corresponds to a specific dose on the y-axis that should be followed to minimize the risk of nephrotoxicity.



It is designed to guide the determination of the initial empiric dose and interval of intravenous (IV) Vancomycin in hospitalized adults who are not receiving hemodialysis. The nomogram does not apply to patients who exhibit highly variable vancomycin pharmacokinetics. These patients include the critically ill, those with burn injuries affecting more than 20 percent of their body surface, patients with rapidly changing renal function, pregnant women, those with liver failure/ascites, individuals at the extremes of weight, acutely post-transplant patients, and those with cystic fibrosis.

Other nomograms are Sasich and Zaske’s model, which is based on first-order elimination kinetics, and Bayesian software, which is based on population pharmacodynamics.

questions.text: 110. ‘X’ is an anti–epileptic drug given for treatment of partial/focal seizures and West syndrome. This is preferred in patients with a previous history of tuberous sclerosis. This drug has been given a black box warning as it can cause permanent visual loss. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The anti–epileptic drug with severe black–box warning causing the permanent visual loss is Vigabatrin and it acts by irreversibly blocking the GABA transaminase to increase GABA action. It is used in the treatment of focal seizures and infantile spasms. 

Vigabatrin causes an increase in retinal thickness and directly damages the central retina. The other side effects of the drug include:

* Dizziness

* Tremors

* Weight gain

* Memory disturbances

* myalgia

The other anti-epileptic drugs with visual effects include the following:

S.NO NAME OF THE DRUG MECHANISM OF ACTION NOTES
1.       Topiramate Blocks the sodium channel to increase GABA action Can cause angle closure glaucoma but no black box warning issued. Used in migraine prophylaxis
2.       Phenytoin Zero order kinetics and is a Na+ channel blocker

Diplopia.

DOC for recurrent seizure prophylaxis
3.       Gabapentin Clearly not studied

Macular oedema

used in post – herpetic pain


The drug of choice for infantile spasms is ACTH.

The drug of choice for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabatrin.

Infantile spasm (IS) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).Their occurrence is almost entirely limited to infancy (the first year of life) and they are refractory to conventional anticonvulsant drugs.

West’s syndrome refers to the classic triad of:

* Infantile spasms,

* Characteristic interictal EEG showing hypsarrhythmia, 

* Neurodevelopmental regression. 

ISs are resistant to most of the conventional antiepileptic drugs. Only ACTH, corticosteroids, and vigabatrin have conclusively demonstrated effectiveness.

questions.text: 111. A tandem mass spectroscopy is done in a newborn to rule out metabolic disorders like phenylketonuria. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done in a newborn to rule out metabolic disorders like phenylketonuria is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

* Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns

* Screening of infants for phenylketonuria

* Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy

* Screening for deafness in school children

Other options:

Option A: Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Examples of prospective screening:

* Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population

* Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: 112. A 26-year-old woman presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. A glycerol test and electrocochleography were performed to diagnose her condition, and promethazine was prescribed for management. A few days later she presents with complaints of a sudden loss of tone without loss of consciousness. She states that she felt like she was pushed to the ground. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Meniere's disease with Tumarkin's otolithic crisis.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is an auditory disease characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

Variants of MD:

* Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis is not well understood.

* Lermoyez syndrome - Here, symptoms of MD are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

* Vestibular hydrops - Typical episodes of vertigo occur while cochlear function remains intact.

* Cochlear hydrops - Only cochlear functions are impaired, while vertigo episodes do not appear until later.

Other options

Tullio phenomenon - It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

questions.text: 113. A 38-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Pelvic examination is normal. Ultrasound reveals focal endometrial thickening. What is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy with biopsy will be done to confirm the diagnosis and know the cause of abnormal menstrual bleeding in this woman.

Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the endometrial cavity and targeted biopsy of abnormal areas, making it the gold standard for diagnosing focal endometrial pathology such as polyps, hyperplasia, or malignancy. It is particularly useful when ultrasound shows focal endometrial thickening, as in this case.

Other options:

Option A: Fractional curettage (Dilation & Curettage) can provide histological diagnosis but it is a blind procedure and may miss focal lesions. It is less accurate than hysteroscopy-guided biopsy in cases of focal endometrial thickening.

Option C: Endometrial aspiration biopsy is useful for evaluating global endometrial pathology but has lower sensitivity for detecting focal lesions. It may miss localized abnormalities like polyps or focal hyperplasia.

Option D: Saline infusion sonography helps in better visualization of the endometrial cavity but does not provide a histological diagnosis. It is useful for detecting structural abnormalities but must be followed by a biopsy for confirmation.

questions.text: 114. A 55-year-old male presents with episodes of dizziness, particularly during physical activity involving his left arm. He also reports occasional weakness and fatigue in the same arm. Upon examination, the left arm BP measures 100/70 mmHg, while the right arm shows 130/80 mmHg. The angiogram shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient’s dizziness and left arm fatigue during exertion, along with a significant blood pressure difference between arms, are classic for subclavian steal syndrome, making option C the correct answer.

In the left image, a plaque (red circle) is seen in the left subclavian artery, causing reduced distal blood flow (purple arrow) and an absence of contrast in the left vertebral artery, indicating retrograde flow. The right image shows a stent (green circle) placed in the left subclavian artery, resulting in improved blood flow distally (red arrow) and restored contrast filling the left vertebral artery (green arrow).

Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when a hemodynamically significant stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian (or innominate) artery leads to retrograde blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery, “stealing” blood from the brainstem and posterior circulation.

The most common cause is atherosclerosis, but other conditions such as Takayasu arteritis, giant cell arteritis, arterial thoracic outlet syndrome, congenital anomalies, or postsurgical changes can also contribute.

Clinical Features include neurologic symptoms (e.g., dizziness, vertigo, double vision, incoordination) due to brainstem ischemia, often triggered by upper extremity exertion, upper extremity symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, or ischemic pain, especially in the affected arm, and blood pressure discrepancy between arms, with the affected arm showing lower readings due to subclavian artery stenosis

Evaluation includes duplex ultrasound can detect proximal subclavian artery stenosis and retrograde vertebral artery flow. Angiography (CTA or MRA) confirms the diagnosis by visualizing the stenosis and reversed vertebral artery flow.

Treatment for subclavian steal syndrome includes medical therapy (aspirin, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors) and revascularization options like transluminal balloon angioplasty, endarterectomy, or surgical bypass grafting (e.g., common carotid-subclavian graft).

Other options:

Option A: Patent Ductus Arteriosus is a congenital condition where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. It typically presents in childhood with symptoms like heart failure, not arm-specific symptoms or BP differences. There is no association with dizziness or arm weakness in adults.

Option B: Aortic Dissection presents with sudden, severe chest or back pain and may cause unequal BP in the arms. However, it does not cause episodic dizziness or arm weakness during activity. It is a life-threatening emergency, and the patient would likely appear acutely ill.

Option D: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta, usually diagnosed in childhood. It causes hypertension in the upper extremities and weak or absent pulses in the lower extremities. It does not explain the unilateral arm symptoms or BP difference between the arms.

questions.text:
115. A 35-year-old male presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees, nail pitting and onycholysis. Which of the following statements are TRUE regarding this patient’s condition?

1) It is associated with metabolic syndrome and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. 2) The Auspitz sign is positive. 3) Koebner phenomenon is observed. 4) Topical calcineurin inhibitors are the first-line agents for the plaque variant of this disease. 5) It typically spares the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.
questions.solution:
Erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor surfaces of the elbows & knees, nail pitting, and onycholysis strongly suggest the diagnosis of Psoriasis. Statements 1, 2, and 3 (Option A) are true regarding this patient’s condition.

Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes and an overactive immune response. It results in well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, commonly seen on the extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, scalp, lower back). It can also affect the nails (causing pitting and onycholysis) and joints (leading to psoriatic arthritis). 

The Auspitz sign refers to pinpoint bleeding when psoriasis scales are scraped off. This is due to the thinning of the epidermis over elongated dermal papillae containing capillaries. Koebner phenomenon occurs when new psoriatic lesions develop at sites of skin trauma, such as scratches.

Psoriatic arthritis often involves the DIP joints, unlike rheumatoid arthritis, which spares them. Nail involvement (pitting, onycholysis) is strongly associated with DIP joint arthritis. Psoriasis is linked to metabolic syndrome, obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

First-line topical therapy (not topical calcineurin inhibitors)  for plaque psoriasis includes topical corticosteroids. The first line systemic therapy for plaque psoriasis is Methotrexate.

Pearl PM1956: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Molluscum contagiosum

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: 116. A negative appendicectomy was performed on a pregnant patient with right lower quadrant pain. The actual cause of the pain was later determined to be a structure derived from the embryonic gubernaculum ovarii that undergoes stretching in pregnancy resulting in the pain. What is the structure?
questions.solution:
The structure undergoing stretching in pregnancy resulting in pain is the Round ligament of the uterus. It is derived from the gubernaculum ovarii.

Gubernaculum ovarii is the homologous structure to gubernaculum testis in females. In males, the gubernaculum pulls the testis into its normal extra-abdominal position. In females, ovarian descent is limited and the gubernaculum ovarii transforms into ligaments.

The proximal part develops into the ligament of the ovary and the distal part develops into the round ligament of the uterus. The round ligament enters the deep inguinal ring and comes out through the superficial inguinal ring to attach near the labium majus. 

In case there is a patent inguinal canal in females, it is called the Canal of Nuck and is the tract causing indirect inguinal hernias in females.

The function of the round ligament is to act as support to the uterus and keep it in anteverted and anteflexed position. In pregnancy, due to pulling from the gravid uterus, the round ligament stretches and undergoes painful spasms known as round ligament pain.

The majority of appendicitis cases occur in the second trimester, and both conditions can present with pain in the right lower quadrant, creating confusion and increasing the rates of negative appendicectomy. A negative appendicectomy is a surgical situation where a patient has been taken up for an appendicectomy but on opening the abdomen, an inflamed appendix cannot be found, suggesting that the likely source of the pathology is elsewhere.



Other Options:

Option A)Uterosacral ligaments: Condensations of endopelvic fascia that extend from cervix to sacrum and form lateral walls of rectouterine pouch. They pull the cervix backward against the forward pull of the round ligaments and together these elements act as a couple to maintain the uterine axis.

Option B)Broad Ligaments of Uterus: Peritoneal folds, not actual ligaments which attach the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. Broad ligament contains fallopian tubes , round ligament of the uterus and ligament of the ovary, uterine and ovarian vessels, epoophoron, paroophoron, and uterovaginal plexus and lymph nodes.

Option D)Mackenrodt’s Ligament: Transverse cervical ligaments which are condensations of endopelvic fascia that connect the lateral cervical and lateral upper vaginal walls to the lateral pelvic walls. It acts as a hammock to support the uterus.

questions.text: 117. A 17-year-old married girl presents to the obstetric OPD requesting the abortion of her 9-week pregnancy. She is mentally sound and does not have any medical contraindications to the procedure. She firmly states that she does not wish to inform her parents or husband. Considering legal provisions, which of the following is the most appropriate course of action for the medical officer?

choices.text: Proceed with the abortion after obtaining written consent from the girl, as she is married and mentally sound
Refuse the abortion, as spousal consent is mandatory for termination of pregnancy in a married minor
Proceed with the abortion only after obtaining written consent from the girl's parents or legal guardian, as she is a minor
Inform the local magistrate and seek judicial permission before performing the abortion

questions.solution:
Considering legal provisions, the most appropriate course of action for the medical officer is to proceed with the abortion only after obtaining written consent from the girl's parents or legal guardian.

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 states that the consent of the woman is required before conducting abortion; however, if the woman is a minor (not attained the age of 18) or a mentally ill person, written consent of her parents or legal guardian is required. Consent of the husband is not necessary. In this scenario, because the girl is 17 years of age, she is considered a minor. The law also states that if the period of pregnancy is below 20 weeks, it can be terminated on the opinion of a single doctor. 

Option (A): Since she is a minor, she cannot provide valid medical consent under Indian law.

Option (B): Spousal consent is never required for an abortion under the MTP Act, 2021, even if the girl is a minor. 

Option (D):  As per the POCSO Act and IPC, any sexual activity involving a person below 18 years of age constitutes statutory rape, irrespective of consent. Hence, abortion service providers are required to report such cases to the authorities. However in such cases, judicial permission is not required for abortion if there is written consent of parents or legal guardian and if the pregnancy is within legal gestational limits under the MTP Act.

Pearl PM2131: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

* Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother

* Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure

* Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest

* Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

* Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.

* MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.

* The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

* Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion

* 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion

* For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

* Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations

* Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)

* At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text:
118. A middle-aged woman was diagnosed with SLE and had an abnormal RFT. The physician decided to send the patient for a renal biopsy to identify the stage of renal disease. Which autoantibody is the most ideal for identifying active lupus nephritis by immunofluorescence?

SLE: Systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Anti C1q antibodies is most ideal for identifying active lupus nephritis on immunofluorescence in SLE patients with renal involvement.

Anti Complement 1q autoantibody recognizes collagen-like determinants on the complement component C1q. It is present in over half the patients with lupus nephritis, and is associated with active lupus nephritis, especially if anti-DS-DNA is also positive. While the antibody is not specific or sensitive for SLE, its presence is highly suggestive of active nephritis and its fluctuations also correlate with the activity of the nephritis.

In SLE, the early complement proteins are often deficient. Low levels of C3, C4 and CH50  may be typically seen. Homozygous genetic deficiencies in early components of complement like  C1q,r,s, C2, C4 confer high hazard ratio for development of SLE. 

Lupus nephritis, along with infection, is the most common cause of mortality in lupus patients in the first decade. Nephritis is also usually the most serious manifestation of lupus, and initially presents as a silent asymptomatic pathology with proteinuria on urine examination.

Urinalysis is therefore mandatory in SLE, and disease is classified by renal biopsy and histopathology into six grades. Patients develop microscopic hematuria and proteinuria which progresses to nephrotic syndrome with hypertension, eventually culminating in end stage renal disease, renal failure and mortality. 

The disease is characterized by relapses and remissions, and various molecules like antiC1q, antiDS-DNA, TWEAK, NGAL, BLyS, C3 levels, MCP-1, etc are used to identify a disease flare. No single molecule can be considered confirmatory of a flare-up, hence a panel of molecules may be employed.

Other Options:

Option A: A positive serum anti-Ribosomal P is associated with depression or psychosis due to CNS Lupus.

Option C: Anti-Ro is also known as SS-A. It is associated with sicca syndrome, and predisposes to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block and subacute cutaneous lupus. Not specific to SLE.

Option D: Anti-Sm is specific for SLE. It is more common in blacks and Asians than whites.

questions.text: 119. A 65-year-old patient is being evaluated in the ward for abdominal pain 1 day after a laparoscopic abdominal surgery. Ultrasonography of the lower abdomen shows a hypoechoic mass. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: CT Scan of abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with abdominal pain 1 day after abdominal surgery with a mass in the lower abdomen that appears hypoechoic on ultrasonography most likely has acute urinary retention. The next best step in the management of this patient would be to catheterize him with a Foley catheter to relieve the retention.

There can be multiple factors for urinary retention, including anticholinergic medication, surgery, trauma, etc. It occurs due to an imbalance in the activity of the muscles of the bladder. In this case, the most likely cause of urinary retention is handling of the bladder intraoperatively which could have led to a transient hypoactivity of the bladder muscles. It could also be due to the effect of the anesthesia. The next step in management would be urgent Foley catheterization to relieve the obstruction.

If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. 

If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators. In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in the distal urethra than the proximal urethra.

Significant hematuria can result in the formation of blood clots, which can further block the urethra and cause retention. 

Other Options: Option B: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is indicated if there is a suspicion of a bladder injury or if ultrasonography findings were equivocal. But the USG here shows a large hypoechoic region indicating Urinary retention.

Option C: Urgent surgery would have been needed if there was any evidence of bladder trauma. This patient should first be catheterized to relieve the obstruction in this case of acute urinary retention.

Option D: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication that causes relaxation of the bladder muscles. It would worsen this patient's urinary retention.

questions.text: 120. A diabetic adolescent had a recent onset of difficulty in speaking with clarity along with postural instability. Neurological examination showed absence of deep tendon reflexes and extensor plantar response bilaterally with no loss of muscle tone. The cardiac assessment revealed cardiomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation of an adolescent who is diabetic and has cardiomegaly presenting with dysarthria and ataxia and neurological assessment showing absence of deep tendon reflexes(DTR), bilateral Babinski signs positive with no loss of muscle tone, most likely points to Friedreich's ataxia.

Friedreich's ataxia is the most common inherited ataxia, representing half of all hereditary ataxia cases, and occurs as a classic form or one associated with a Vitamin E deficiency syndrome. Onset is before 25 years of age. Clinical presentation, which is akin to non-compressive myelopathy, includes the following features:

* Progressive ataxia( staggering gait and frequent falls)

* Titubation(involuntary head nodding) 

* Ataxic dysarthria

* Preferential lower limb involvement

* Skeletal deformities like Scoliosis, pes cavus, pes equinovarus

* Heart problems: cardiomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathies, and conduction defects

* Early onset diabetes mellitus due to beta cell dysfunction and insulin resistance

* Neurological assessment showing absent DTR, bilateral extensor plantar response, weakness(more distal than proximal), preserved muscle tone in trunk and lower limbs

* Nystagmus and loss of fast saccadic eye movements

* Some cases may have varying degrees of mental retardation

Imaging with MRI shows spinal cord atrophy including sclerosis and degeneration of spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and posterior tracts, some atrophy of the cerebellum and cerebral gyri, and loss of large myelinated fibers in peripheral nerves.

Diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing for an abnormally high number of trinucleotide repeats " GAA" in the first intron of the Frataxin gene. Expansion of trinucleotide GAA repeats, ( normally 7-22, increased to 200-900 in disease) results in loss of function mutation in the Frataxin gene, responsible for iron homeostasis in mitochondria. Very low levels of frataxin mRNA expression cause mitochondrial iron accumulation, oxidative stress, and damage resulting in the disease.

Treatment is usually symptomatic. Vitamin E supplementation is beneficial in a small subset of patients with concomitant deficiency.

Other Options:

Option A: Syringomyelia is a cavitatory expansion of the spinal cord's central canal. It is frequently associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation and the location is usually a lower cervical level.  Clinically presents in adolescence with cervico-thoracic scoliosis, central cord syndrome with cape-like dissociative loss of sensation in upper limbs( pain and temperature lost while touch and vibration are preserved), areflexic weakness of upper limbs, muscle wasting in lower neck, shoulder and arms,  trigeminal sensory impairment, etc.

Option B: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord occurs due to Vitamin B12 deficiency and involves posterior columns and lateral spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts. Clinical features are tingling and numbness of distal extremities with eventual loss of sensation, Babinski positive and loss of reflexes. There is no diabetes or cardiomegaly. Diagnosis is confirmed by peripheral smear, CBC and vitamin B12 assays.

Option C: Acute transverse myelitis is an extensive spinal cord inflammation and demyelination resulting in sensorimotor and autonomic(bladder/bowel symptoms) spinal cord dysfunction. It occurs acutely after vaccination or infections and subacutely in multiple sclerosis patients.

questions.text: 121. Select a correct and rational drug prescription for the given hypertensive patients

A 36 year old male with migraine - Propranolol

questions.solution:

questions.text: 122. According to the 2015 Revised Jones Criteria, which joint manifestation is considered a minor criterion for acute rheumatic fever?

choices.text: Polyarthralgia in low-risk populations, Monoarthralgia in high-risk populations
Monoarthralgia in low-risk populations, Polyarthralgia in high-risk populations

questions.solution:
According to the 2015 Revised Jones Criteria, polyarthralgia in low-risk populations and monoarthralgia in high-risk populations are considered minor criteria for acute rheumatic fever.

The 2015 Revised Jones Criteria for diagnosing acute rheumatic fever (ARF) classify joint manifestations based on the patient's risk status. They are classified as:

Moderate-high-risk population:

* ARF incidence ≥2 per 100,000 per year in children aged 5–14 years or

* RHD prevalence ≥1 per 1,000 in any age group

* Common in developing countries, Indigenous populations, and underserved communities

Low-risk population:

* ARF incidence <2 per 100,000 per year in children aged 5–14 years and

* RHD prevalence <1 per 1,000 in any age group

* Typically seen in developed countries with better healthcare access

For arthritis: The major criteria include polyarthritis in low-risk populations and monoarthritis or polyarthritis in high-risk populations.

However, joint pain without objective signs of inflammation—arthralgia—can also be considered a minor criterion, but the criteria differ by risk category. Polyarthralgia is considered a minor criterion in low-risk populations, and monoarthralgia is considered a minor criterion in regions with an increased prevalence (high-risk) of ARF.

Pearl PM2066: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Minor criteria
