ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria


*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: 123. A 32-year-old P2L2 lady comes on the fifth day of unprotected sexual intercourse. What will be your advice for contraception for this lady?

choices.text: Two tablets of high dose OCP, repeated after 24 hours

questions.solution:
Copper IUCD should be advised for contraception for this lady.

Copper-IUD is an effective postcoital contraceptive method and can be inserted up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse. It is the most effective method for emergency contraceptives. The advantages of Copper-T as emergency contraception are as follows:

* It can be inserted as late as 5 days after unprotected intercourse.

* It is cheap.

* Failure rate is 0.1%.

* It can remain an ongoing contraceptive method for 3-5 years.

Contraindications for copper-IUD:

* Uterine abnormality with the distorted uterine cavity

* Acute PID, or current behavior suggesting a high risk for PID

* Postpartum endometritis or postabortal endometritis in the past 3 months

* Known or suspected uterine or cervical malignancy

* Genital bleeding of unknown etiology

* Mucopurulent cervicitis

* Wilson disease

* Allergy to copper

* A previously placed IUD that has not been removed

Other options:

Option A: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg (not 0.75 mg, single dose as in the question), i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Option B: These combined oral contraceptives (COC)-containing regimens have been approved by the FDA for use as emergency contraception. Pills should be taken within 72 hours. They may be given up to 120 hours but they are effective the sooner they are taken. The combined hormonal regimen consists of two tablets of high-dose norgestrel (250 μg)-ethinyl estradiol (50 μg), repeated 12 hours later and can be given with 50 mg dimenhydrinate initially. 

Option D: Laparoscopic tubectomy is a method of permanent contraception. It is not used as an emergency contraceptive.

questions.text: 124. A 50-year-old male presents with sudden onset painful blurred vision in his right eye. Examination reveals a mid-dilated, non-reactive pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, and a forward-bowed iris. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is markedly elevated. Gonioscopy shows 360-degree posterior synechiae. Which of the following is the most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Acute painful blurred vision, a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, a forward-bowed iris, and  360-degree posterior synechiae indicate secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to pupillary block.

Secondary Angle-Closure Glaucoma can be caused by Iris bombe, which results from 360-degree posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and lens). These adhesions prevent aqueous humor from flowing through the pupil, leading to fluid accumulation behind the iris. This forward bowing of the iris progressively narrows or closes the angle, further obstructing aqueous outflow and causing a rise in IOP.

Unlike primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG), secondary forms are triggered by an identifiable underlying pathology. Gonioscopy findings of 360-degree posterior synechiae strongly point toward a secondary etiology, differentiating it from PACG, where Peripheral anterior synechiae is present.

Other Options:

Option A: Peripheral anterior synechiae (not 360° posterior synechiae)  are seen in Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma.

Option B: Neovascular Glaucoma is caused by new blood vessel formation due to diabetic retinopathy or central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

Option D: Phacomorphic Glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure, where an intumescent (swollen) cataract pushes the iris forward. Posterior synechiae is not seen in this condition.

questions.text: 125. A 3-year-old child presents with inward deviation of both eyes noticed more while focusing on near objects. Examination reveals significant hypermetropia (+5 D). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Inward deviation of both eyes (esotropia) that is more pronounced while seeing near objects and significant hypermetropia (+5 D) is suggestive of Refractive Accommodative Esotropia.

Accommodative esotropia occurs when the eyes deviate inward while trying to focus on objects. It is of two types: refractive and non-refractive.

Refractive Accommodative Esotropia is the most common type of esotropia in children. It occurs around 2-3 years of age and is associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D). This condition occurs due to excessive accommodative convergence as the child overcomes the blurred vision caused by uncorrected hypermetropia. It is fully correctable with the correction of hypermetropia.

Non-refractive Accommodative Esotropia is caused by an abnormally high AC/A ratio (Accommodative Convergence/ Accommodation). 

Other Options:

Option A: Infantile Esotropia presents within the first 6 months of life. The angle of deviation is large (>35°). Surgical treatment is preferred for this condition.

Option C: Non-refractive Accommodative Esotropia is caused by an abnormally high AC/A ratio (Accommodative Convergence/ Accommodation). 

Option D: Sensory esotropia is caused by monocular lesions (in childhood) which either prevent the development of normal binocular vision or interfere with its maintenance. Eg: congenital cataract, optic atrophy.

questions.text: 126. A patient with dilated tortuosities in the lower limb had a Brodie Trendelenburg Test(Part 2) done which showed filling from below upwards. Fegan’s test showed multiple blowouts at various points from below the knee. Which of the following perforators is not implicated, based on the test results?
questions.solution:
Dodd’s perforator is not implicated, based on the test results as it is located above the knee. 

The given scenario where the Brodie Trendelenburg Test(Part 2) shows filling from below upwards is indicative of perforator incompetence. Fegan test is used to identify the incompetent perforators by identifying sites of blowout. Here, blowouts are present below the knee level, ruling out Dodd's perforator incompetence.

The perforators and their location is mentioned below:

PERFORATOR LOCATION
Hunterian perforator Adductor canal of the thigh
Dodd's perforator Just above knee
Boyd's perforator Just below knee
Cockett's perforator Medial side of calf
May and Kuster's perforator Below medial malleolus


Below is given an image of the perforators :



Brodie Trendelenburg test has 2 parts. Part 1 is used to identify saphenofemoral incompetence and Part 2 is used to identify perforator incompetence. In part 1, the leg is thoroughly milked and raised, and a tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction(SFJ) the leg is brought to a normal position and the tourniquet is released. Rapid filling from above downwards indicates incompetent SFJ.

In part 2, the tourniquet is not released when the leg is brought down. Slow filling from below upwards indicates perforator incompetence.

In Fegan’s test, the site of dilations is marked and the patient is made to lie down and the leg is raised. Button-like depression is felt at the marked sites indicating perforator incompetence.

questions.text:
128. Match the following techniques with their application:

1) Microarray Analysis

  a) Detection of specific DNA sequences and mutations
2) Southern Blotting b) Amplification of a specific DNA sequence
3) Line Probe Assay c) Detection and analysis of specific DNA fragments
4) Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) d) Study variation in gene expression
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1–d, 2–c, 3–a, 4–b (Option A).

1) Microarray Analysis d) Study variation in gene expression
2) Southern Blotting c) Detection and analysis of specific DNA fragments
3) Line Probe Assay a) Detection of specific DNA sequences and mutations
4) Polymerase Chain Reaction b) Amplification of a specific DNA sequence


Microarray Analysis can be used to study unknown DNA mutations and variations in gene expression. It is based on the principle of comparative genomic hybridization where the test DNA is compared to a normal (reference) DNA.

Southern blotting technique can be used to detect specific sequences of DNA. Line Probe Assay (LPA) is a molecular technique used for the rapid detection of specific DNA sequences, including mutations, mainly in tuberculosis (TB) and drug resistance testing.

Polymerase chain reaction is a technique used to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It can be used to synthesize millions of copies of the selected DNA sequence in a few hours, enabling the detection of even trace amounts of DNA in a sample.

questions.text: 129. A male patient is brought into the emergency after a road traffic accident in which he has sustained injuries on the face. You note excessive mobility of the maxilla but no mobility of the nose. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the lower part of the nasal septum, maxillary antrum, and pterygoid plates. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. 

Le Fort Type 1 fractures generally occur on the horizontal plane at the level of the nose base. It is caused due to downward directed force onto the lower part of the maxillary rim.

It involves the three walls of the maxillary sinus as well as the pterygoid processes, extending around the maxillary antrum, nasal septum, and pterygoid plate. This leads to the separation of the palate and face. There is no involvement of the glabella or zygoma in this case. 

Clinically, patients present with swollen upper lip, anterior open bite malocclusion, maxillary buccal vestibule, palate ecchymosis, and mobility of the maxilla.

Diagnosis is made with X-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan. They help to understand the full extent of injuries. 

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.



Pearl PM0946: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla

* Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates

* It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate

* Also called Guerin’s fracture. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates

* X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla

* It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates

* It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: 131. An immunocompromised patient with a history of trauma to the foot presented with a chronic non-healing ulcer for which he had been evaluated and given fluconazole a few weeks back. Discharge from the non-healing ulcer was now taken and sent for microscopy followed by culture on CHROMagar where pinkish colonies were noted. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The organism is Candida krusei. Based on the clinical scenario of an immunocompromised patient with a non-healing ulcer which did not improve with treatment using fluconazole and discharge cultured on CHROMagar is indicative of drug-resistant Candidiasis.

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to most azoles, especially Fluconazole. Hence it is important to identify this organism and change the treatment. Candida krusei is a non-albicans Candida implicated in the development of candidal infections in immunocompromised individuals and those with hematological malignancies. Specific features aiding in its identification include:

* Pinkish colonies on CHROMagar.

* Disc diffusion testing for fluconazole shows resistance.

* Other tests like sugar fermentation and assimilation may also be used to aid in diagnosis.

The treatment of choice for C.krusei is echinocandins like Caspofungin and Anidulafungin. Other drugs that can be used are Flucytosine, Amphotericin B, etc. It is important to note that C. glabrata is also resistant to fluconazole.

CHROMAgar is a special differential medium used to identify different Candida species, each of which shows a different color on the Agar. Specimens are incubated for 1-4 days before color develops. Candida Species and Colour on CHROMagar:

Option A: Candida tropicalis shows blue colonies on CHROMAgar. It can be treated with Caspofungin.

Option B and D: Cladophialophora and Phialophora are dematiaceous fungi (pigmented)that are responsible for Chromoblastomycosis, a subcutaneous mycosis presenting as chronic granulomatous lesions after traumatic impaction of soil or vegetable matter on the skin. Copper penny bodies/sclerotic bodies/medlar bodies are seen on microscopy. Treatment may be with Itraconazole or flucytosine.

questions.text: 132. Which of the following visual field defects demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe?
questions.solution:
Image 3 (Superior quadrantanopia) demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe.

Superior quadrantanopia in image 3 (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations, which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop.

Image 1: Bilateral hemianopia occurs due to a defect in the optic tract.

Image 2: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) defect is due to the involvement of superior fibers of the optic radiations – Baum’s loop. It is seen in parietal lobe lesions.

Image 4: Right contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to a defect in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Pearl PM1950: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

* The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.

* A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.

* Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.

* A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).

* Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: 134. A patient was diagnosed with a rare type of hemolytic anaemia that developed after a viral infection. Blood investigations show the presence of Donath-Landsteiner antibodies. Which blood group system is targeted in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition of rare hemolytic anaemia developed after a viral infection and positive Donath-Landsteiner antibody are suggestive of Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) which is directed against the P blood group system.

PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies (Donath Landsteiner antibodies) directed against the P blood group antigen and brings about complement-mediated hemolysis. It presents as intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria and most cases are seen in children following viral infections. It may be seen in association with tertiary syphilis or as a complication of certain infections such as Mycoplasma pneumonia, flu, measles, and mumps.

In PCH, the direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test will be positive for complement only. It is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

It is a self-limiting condition (recover within 1 month) but blood transfusion is required for the control of anemia.

questions.text: 135. The peripheral smear of a patient with CLL shows the following characteristic cells. These are produced due to _________.

choices.text: Accumulation of immunoglobulin chains within the cell
Accumulation of eosinophilic material within the cell
Accumulation of GAG within the cell

questions.solution:
The given image shows smudge cells in CLL, and these are produced due to tumor cell disruption during smearing.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL):

CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. The median age of diagnosis is 60 years. The most common genetic anomalies seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p and trisomy 12q. Loss of tumor-suppressor genes in chromosome 13 results in overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL2.

The growth of CLL/SLL cells is confined to the proliferation centers (pathognomonic for CLL/SLL), where the tumor cells receive critical factors from the surrounding environments, such as NF-κB for cell survival, MYC for cell growth, and Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) signaling pathway.

The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. Smudge cells are also characteristic of CLL. Clinical features include easy fatiguability, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and hemolytic anemia. CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL); this is called Richter syndrome.

The peripheral smear in CLL shows small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

questions.text: 136. A patient is brought to the emergency following a road traffic accident with a cervical collar. Jefferson's fracture is suspected. Which among the following view is best to see the fracture?
questions.solution:
Jefferson's fracture is a burst fracture of the ring of the atlas (C1). It occurs due to axial forces that result in a fracture of the C1 ring. The open-mouth view is used to diagnose Jefferson fracture, odontoid fracture, and basilar invagination.



Jefferson's fracture is identified in an open-mouth X-ray view (odontoid view). The displacement of the lateral process of C1 over C2 is checked in this X-ray to evaluate if the transverse ligament is torn.

Rule of Spence: If the total displacement (sum of displacement on both sides) of C1 lateral masses relative to C2 is more than 6.9 mm, the transverse ligament is likely to be damaged. If the transverse ligament is injured, it is classified as an unstable fracture.

questions.text:
137. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the physiology of lactation?

* High levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy make the breast tissue unresponsive to the prolactin hormone.

* Insulin, thyroxine, and growth hormone play an important role in lactogenesis.

* Prolactin is the major galactokinetic hormone.

* Oxytocin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone.

* The drug metoclopramide improves milk production by increasing prolactin levels.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 5 represent the correct statements.

High levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy make the breast tissue unresponsive to the prolactin hormone. When these hormonal levels start falling after the delivery of the baby, the prolactin hormone starts acting on the mammary glands to produce milk (lactogenesis).

Insulin, thyroxine and growth hormone also play an important role in lactogenesis.

The ejection of milk is referred to as galactokinesis. Oxytocin is the major hormone that is responsible for the process of milk ejection.

Prolactin is the single most important hormone responsible for the maintenance of lactation (galactopoiesis). 

Galactagogues like metoclopramide, sulpiride and domperidone (dopamine antagonists) improve milk production by increasing prolactin levels.

questions.text: 138. A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive conductive hearing loss, frequent ear infections, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane. A CT scan of the temporal bone shows bone erosion of the ossicles and mastoid air cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presentation suggests cholesteatoma. 

Cholesteatoma is an abnormal collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear or mastoid that leads to bone destruction. It can be congenital or acquired, with acquired cases arising from tympanic membrane retraction or epithelial migration through a perforation. The expanding mass erodes nearby structures, potentially causing serious complications.

Patients present with progressive conductive hearing loss, recurrent ear infections, ear fullness, and foul-smelling otorrhea. An otoscopic exam may show a retraction pocket or attic perforation. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis, revealing ossicular and mastoid bone erosion. Advanced cases can result in facial nerve palsy, labyrinthine fistulas, or intracranial infections. Treatment is surgical removal via tympanomastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Tympanosclerosis involves calcification and fibrosis of the tympanic membrane, usually following chronic otitis media. It does not cause bone erosion or a retraction pocket.

Option C: While chronic otitis media can cause hearing loss and recurrent infections, it typically presents with a perforation, not a retraction pocket or bone erosion.  

Option D: A Cholesterol granuloma is a mass of granulation tissue with giant foreign body cells surrounding cholesterol crystals resulting from prolonged secretion retention or hemorrhage. It typically presents with a blue eardrum mass rather than a retraction pocket or bone erosion.

Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.

The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated subclinical infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.

questions.text: 140. An elderly male patient with a long-term history of gastritis came with a 6-month history of weight loss and intermittent fever. Endoscopy revealed diffuse mucosal thickening with ulceration in the stomach. The biopsy showed lymphoepithelial lesions and dense lymphocytic infiltration of gastric glands. Cytogenetic studies reveal t(11;18) mutation. Which of the following is likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and biopsy showing dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands and cytogenetics study showing t(11;18) are suggestive of gastric MALToma. It likely associated with Helicobacter pylori infection.

MALToma is a lymphoma arising from mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is actually extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of gut mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is usually primary GI lymphoma (4% of gastric lymphoma); of non-Hodgkin’s B cell type. The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in MALT lymphomas is t(11;18). The most common site is the stomach. MALToma can be associated with Type B symptoms like fever, night sweats and weight loss.

Histologically, MALTomas show dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create lymphoepithelial lesions. MALTomas express B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, but not CD5 or CD10.

On endoscopy, MALToma shows diffuse mucosal thickening which may ulcerate.

Primary gastric lymphoma treatment varies: surgery for localized disease, chemotherapy for systemic involvement. Early gastric lymphomas linked to Helicobacter infection may regress with antibiotic treatment. Rapid tumor regression from chemotherapy can cause bleeding or perforation, often requiring gastrectomy.

Other options

Gastric neuroendocrine neoplasms are seen associated with  autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis (option B), MEN1, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (option D).

Gastric endocrine and enterochromaffin-like cell hyperplasia are seen to be associated with proton pump inhibitor therapy (option C).

questions.text:
141. A 28-year-old female with lupus nephritis is planning pregnancy. She is currently taking Mycophenolate mofetil, Hydroxychloroquine & Prednisolone. Her serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dl, serum albumin is 2.6 gm/dl. She is ANA and Anti ds-DNA positive. Which is the most appropriate next step?

ANA- Antinuclear Antibodies

choices.text: Continue current medications and attempt conception
Stop MMF and switch to azathioprine before conception
Continue only hydroxychloroquine and attempt conception
Continue current medications and delay pregnancy

questions.solution:
Continue current medications and delay pregnancy because pregnancy in lupus nephritis is high-risk, and poor preconception renal function significantly increases the risk of adverse maternal and fetal outcomes.

This patient has:

* Elevated serum creatinine (1.9 mg/dL) → High risk of worsening renal function during pregnancy

* Hypoalbuminemia (2.6 g/dL) → Indicates ongoing proteinuria & active disease

* Positive anti-dsDNA → Suggests active lupus

Hence, pregnancy should be delayed. 

Other options:

Option A: Continue current medications and attempt conception. The disease is not well controlled, increasing the risk of preeclampsia, preterm birth, and worsening lupus nephritis, so conception should be delayed.

Option B: Stop MMF and switch to azathioprine before conception. MMF must be replaced with azathioprine (safer in pregnancy), but her disease is still active. Pregnancy should be delayed until remission is achieved.

Option C: Continue only hydroxychloroquine and attempt conception is incorrect. The disease is not well controlled, increasing the risk of preeclampsia, preterm birth, and worsening lupus nephritis, so conception should be delayed. Hydroxychloroquine should be continued during pregnancy as it reduces flare risk.

questions.text:
142. A 16-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea and has secondary sexual characteristics, including breast development and pubic hair growth at Tanner stage 2. The patient's lab investigations are given below. A pelvic ultrasound reveals vestigial ovaries. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Serum FSH=95 mIU/ml (Normal= 3–10 mIU/mL)

Serum LH=110 mIU/ml (Normal= 2–15 mIU/mL)
questions.solution:
The given patient with primary amenorrhea and underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and vestigial ovaries on USG, suggests Turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome (45, XO) results from the loss or structural abnormality of one X chromosome in females, leading to gonadal dysgenesis (non-functional ovaries). It is characterized by short stature, webbed neck, broad chest, and skeletal abnormalities. Complications include cardiac defects (bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta), hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disorders, and celiac disease.

The syndrome leads to primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) due to streak gonads, causing delayed puberty, infertility, and high FSH/LH levels. However, the uterus and vagina develop normally, allowing for hormone-induced puberty and potential conception through assisted reproductive technology (ART).



Other options:

Option A: Mullerian agenesis refers to the congenital absence or underdevelopment of the Mullerian duct derivatives, which include the uterus, cervix, and upper two-thirds of the vagina. In this condition, patients typically have secondary sexual characteristics and normal ovarian function, but they lack a uterus or have an underdeveloped uterus.

Option B: Androgen insensitivity syndrome patients develop female external genitalia but lack a uterus and have no menstruation due to the inability to respond to androgens. 

Option C: Hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs due to insufficient gonadotropin secretion (FSH and LH), often triggered by factors such as stress, malnutrition, or excessive exercise. Pelvic ultrasound would usually show normal ovaries and a normal-sized uterus.

questions.text: 143. A 25-year-old woman presented with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. She delivered her first baby six weeks back. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse. Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus. The patient may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. Prolapse is aggravated by straining so the bulge increases on sneezing and coughing. It reduces on lying down, or by manual reduction. It may be accompanied by micturition disturbances like difficulty in initiating micturition or frequency of micturition. Rectal symptoms and coital difficulties can be present depending on the degree of prolapse.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-6 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months.

If the complaints persist beyond 6 months, surgical repair can be done depending on the type of prolapse:

* Sling operation for patients who are desirous of retaining their childbearing and menstrual functions, and they are best suited for nulliparous women

* Surgery for anterior vaginal wall prolapse- Anterior colporrhaphy 

* Surgery for posterior vaginal wall prolapse- Posterior colporrhaphy 

* Surgery for prolapse of the uterus in young women- Manchester's operation



Option A: Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.



Option B: Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline. It may also lead to stress incontinence.

Option D: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

questions.text: 144. A patient came with a positive urinary pregnancy test after 6 weeks of amenorrhea. The patient’s serum β hCG is 2400 IU/L, but the transvaginal ultrasound showed an empty uterine cavity and was inconclusive. The patient was advised a repeat serum β hCG after 48 hours, which was 3200 IU/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation indicates ectopic pregnancy.

In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, β-hCG should double every 48 hours, but in this case, it has only increased from 2400 to 3200 IU/L (~33% increase), which is below the expected doubling rate. This slow rise raises concern for an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy. Additionally, the empty uterine cavity on transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS)at a β-hCG level where a gestational sac should be visible suggests that the pregnancy is not intrauterine.

Ectopic pregnancies can present with positive pregnancy tests and elevated β-hCG levels, but the rise in β-hCG is often slower than in a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Molar pregnancy is characterized by very high β-hCG levels (often >100,000 IU/L) and a "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound, not an empty uterine cavity.

Option B: A missed abortion refers to the intrauterine death of an embryo or fetus that is retained within the uterus for an extended period without spontaneous expulsion. There will be declining β-hCG levels rather than a slow rise. 

Option D: A heterotopic pregnancy is a rare form of multiple gestation in which one embryo implants normally within the uterus, while the other implants ectopically, most commonly in the fallopian tube.  This diagnosis is typically seen in patients who have undergone fertility treatments and are at a higher risk of having multiple pregnancies. But since the patient has an empty uterus and a slow rise in β-hCG, heterotopic pregnancy is unlikely in this case.

Doubles every 2 days

          ⇓

Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)

          ⇓

Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks

          ⇓

Plateau at 16 weeks till term

 

* Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.

* Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

1) Complex 2  a) Rotenone
2) Complex 3 b) Carboxin
3) Complex 4 c) Cyanide
4) Complex 1 d) BAL (British anti-lewisite)
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1- b, 2- d, 3- c, 4- a.

1) Complex 2 b) Carboxin
2) Complex 3 d) BAL (British anti-lewisite)
3) Complex 4 c) Cyanide
4) Complex 1 a) Rotenone


The electron transport chain (ETC) represents the final pathway through which electrons, originating from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids, are channelled toward a final reaction with oxygen to produce water and ATP. The ETC complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

Several drugs and poisons can inhibit oxidative phosphorylation, and this can have dire consequences for the body. These inhibitors interfere with various components of the process, disrupting the production of ATP and leading to severe physiological effects, often resulting in death if exposure is prolonged or the dose is high.

Uncouplers may act as poisons by dissociating oxidation via the respiratory chain from oxidative phosphorylation but may also have a physiological role in generating body heat.

questions.text: 146. A 35-year-old male with a history of childhood trauma presents with persistent low mood, anhedonia, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating for the past six months. He also reports chronic stress due to work pressure. MRI reveals decreased volume of the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus. Dysregulation of which of the following is most likely contributing to his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with symptoms of persistent low mood, anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and chronic stress, which suggests major depressive disorder. Chronic stress and depression is associated with a decrease in Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).

Chronic stress and childhood trauma are known to reduce BDNF activity, which plays a critical role in neuronal growth, survival, and synaptic plasticity. A decrease in BDNF leads to hippocampal atrophy, prefrontal cortex volume loss, and impaired neurogenesis, all of which are seen in depression. 

Other options:

Option B: Chronic stress and depression are associated with decreased (not increased) glucocorticoid receptor sensitivity, leading to persistent hypercortisolism due to impaired negative feedback on the HPA axis.

Option C: Synaptic plasticity is reduced, not upregulated, in chronic stress and depression. Decreased BDNF contributes to neuronal atrophy and impaired synaptic function rather than promoting plasticity.

Option D: Depression is linked to increased HPA axis activity, with excessive cortisol secretion. The dexamethasone suppression test (DST) often shows no cortisol suppression, indicating hyperactivity rather than decreased HPA function.

questions.text: 147. What is the finding seen on this X-ray?

choices.text: Periarticular erosions with over hanging edges

questions.solution:
The image shows Martel’s sign which is characteristic of gouty lesions with punched out lesions and periarticular erosions with overhanging margins.

* During acute attack x rays show only soft tissue swelling.

* Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary osteoarthritis.

* Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel's sign or G sign).

* These well defined erosions are larger and slightly further from the joint margin than typical rheumatoid arthritis erosions.

Other Options:

Option B: Bony ankylosis is not usually seen in gouty arthritis. Ankylosis refers to an abnormal rigidity of a joint bought about by a pathological process that results in destruction of the normal joint architecture. This ankylosis may be osseous or fibrous. A commonly seen condition with bony ankylosis is vertebral joints in Ankylosing spondylitis. Below is shown an image of ankylosis of hand joints in longstanding Rheumatoid Arthritis:



Option C: Osteolysis refers to the destruction of bony tissue due to some pathological process, such as inflammation. An example of osteolysis is that seen in the arthritis multilans of Psoriatic arthritis patients as shown in the image below:



Option D: Periarticular osteoporosis refers to the reduction in bone mineral density around an inflamed joint, and is one of the earliest radiological findings in Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: 148. The transmission cycle of an arbovirus is given below. Which of the following vaccine can prevent infection with this virus?
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. SA 14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India to prevent infection.

JE follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India).

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Vaccine:

* Inactivated Vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule.

* A formalin-inactivated mouse brain vaccine using the Nakayama strain has been used successfully for immunization. Two doses at two weeks intervals followed by a booster 6-12 months later constitute a full course. The immunity produced by the vaccine is short-lived.

Other options:

Option A: Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Pediculus humanus corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen. 

Option B: 17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered to prevent yellow fever. It is administered through the subcutaneous route. Vaccination is mandatory for travel to or from endemic areas.

Option D: Jeryl Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs.

questions.text:
149. You are asked to assist in a highly selective vagotomy.The surgeon asks you to trace the pathway of the major nerve supply to the pyloric antrum. What is the correct sequence?

1-Left Vagus nerve

2-Right Vagus nerve

3-Anterior Nerve of Latarjet

4-Posterior Nerve of Latarjet

5-Crow feet
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 1-3-5.

The stomach is primarily supplied by the Left vagus nerve. The majority of nerve supply to the pyloric antrum is derived from the anterior branch of this left vagus nerve, which gives off the Anterior nerve of Latarjet. Based on these facts, the correct sequence of innervation of the antrum is: Left Vagus nerve-> Anterior division->Anterior nerve of Latarjet->Crow feet.

The anterior nerve of Latarjet goes along the lesser curvature and terminates at the incisura angularis by forming small end branches called crow feet. It supplies the anterior aspect of the stomach, lesser curvature, fundus, and pyloric antrum. The pyloric sphincter receives a direct branch from the anterior division. 

The posterior division and its branch, the Posterior nerve of Latarjet, supplies the greater curvature and posterior aspect of the stomach. Its terminal branches(crow feet) do not usually reach until the antrum. The criminal nerve of Grassi represents a very proximal branch of the posterior trunk of the vagus, and great attention is needed to avoid missing this branch in the division process because it is frequently cited as a factor predisposing for ulcer recurrence if left intact.

Crow's feet are the small terminal branches of the anterior and posterior nerves which supply the stomach. They are called crow feet because they resemble the foot of a crow.

Understanding the nerve supply of the stomach is important before doing vagotomies, where some part of the vagal innervation is cut off to reduce the acetylcholine-mediated acid secretion as a treatment for peptic ulcer disease. The level at which the vagus is cut and the respective procedure is shown below:

 PROCEDURE  LEVEL AT WHICH IT IS CUT
Truncal Vagotomy Above the Hepatic and coeliac branches from the vagus. Rarely performed nowadays.
Selective Vagotomy Below hepatic and coeliac branches -usually one branch(anterior/posterior). Not performed nowadays.
Highly Selective Vagotomy Crow feet to proximal stomach cut while antro-pyloric innervation preserved. Uncommonly done nowadays.


A truncal or selective vagotomy that deinnervates the pyloric musculature requires a draining procedure surpassing the pylorus such as a pyloroplasty.

Given below is a diagram of highly selective vagotomy which also shows the antral nerve supply from the left vagus-> anterior nerve of Latarjet-> crow feet.

questions.text: 150. Which of the following statements about the countercurrent mechanism is not correct?

choices.text: The countercurrent multiplier in the loop of Henle is an active process
The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water
Urea contributes to the medullary interstitial gradient
High medullary blood flow helps in the countercurrent mechanism

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is "High medullary blood flow helps in the countercurrent mechanism" as high medullary blood flow reduces the concentration ability by washing out the solutes.

The kidney's ability to concentrate urine depends not only on antidiuretic hormone (ADH) but also on the hyperosmolarity of the renal medulla. This hyperosmolarity is critical for the counter-current multiplication mechanism, which allows water to be reabsorbed from the collecting ducts under the influence of ADH.

If medullary blood flow increases excessively, it can "wash out" the solutes that create the osmotic gradient in the medullary interstitium. This reduces the osmolarity of the medulla, impairing the kidney's ability to reabsorb water effectively. Consequently, the counter-current mechanism becomes less efficient, leading to a decreased ability to concentrate urine.

Other options:

Option A: The countercurrent multiplier in the loop of Henle is an active process. The descending and ascending limbs have selective permeabilities for water & solutes and are responsible for establishing an osmotic gradient. The movement of Na+ and Cl− out of the thick ascending limb is through active transport.

Option B: The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports Na⁺, K⁺, and Cl⁻ into the medullary interstitium. This helps generate the osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

Option C: Recirculation of urea plays an important role in maintaining the medullary interstitial gradient  Urea moves from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium via facilitated diffusion.

questions.text:
151. A 54-year-old male with hypertension and diabetes mellitus is prescribed a lipophilic beta-blocker for better CNS penetration. The drug must cross the BBB via passive diffusion. According to Fick’s law of diffusion, which of the following modifications would increase the rate of drug diffusion across the BBB?

BBB: blood-brain barrier

choices.text: Increasing the drug concentration in plasma
Increasing the thickness of the BBB

questions.solution:
Increasing the drug concentration in plasma would increase the rate of drug diffusion across the BBB.

Fick’s law of diffusion states that the rate of diffusion (J) is directly proportional to the diffusion coefficient (D), the cross-sectional area (A), and the concentration gradient (Δc/Δx) while being inversely proportional to the thickness of the boundary. 

J = –DA (Δc/Δx) (where the negative sign indicates movement from higher to lower concentration).

Factors increasing rate of diffusion:

* Increased Lipid Solubility

* Increased Temperature

* Increased Area of the Membrane

* Increased drug concentration

Factors decreasing rate of diffusion:

* Increased molecular weight 

* Decreased lipid solubility 

* Increased thickness of membrane

Pearl PM0437: Factors influencing the rate of net diffusion of a substance across a membrane

Fick’s Law of Diffusion → J = -DA (Δc/Δx)

where,

J is the net rate of diffusion,

D is the diffusion coefficient,

A is the area, and

Δc/Δx is the concentration gradient.

Factors Effect on diffusion
↑ Thickness of the membrane ↓
↑ Lipid Solubility ↑
↑ Temperature ↑
↑  Size of the molecule ↓
↑  Area of the Membrane ↑

questions.text: 152. An elderly woman presented with complaints of mole on her face, as shown in the image below. Which of the following features would be suspicious for a malignant mole?

choices.text: Homogenous brown color of the mole
Itching or tenderness in the region of mole

questions.solution:
The image shows a case of malignant melanoma. Development of symptoms such as itching or pain is suspicious of malignant transformation.

Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction but may also originate from mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx, nasopharynx, eyes, proximal esophagus, anorectal, and female genitalia. The most important risk factor for the development of melanoma is exposure to UV radiation.

Only 10–20% of malignant melanomas form in pre-existing naevi, with the remainder arising de novo in previously normally pigmented skin. The most important warning signs that signifies malignant transformation of naevi to melanoma are called as ABCDEs of melanoma.

It consists of

* Asymmetry

* Border irregularity 

* Color variegation (option A)

* Diameter of more than 6 mm (option C)

* Evolution or change such as change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of the mole

Other warning signs include spread of the pigment into the surrounding area, known as satellite lesions. Late signs may include tingling, itching, or serosanguineous discharge in the region of mole.

Common variants of malignant melanoma include superficial spreading (most common), lentigo maligna, acral lentiginous, and nodular. Amelanotic and desmoplastic melanoma are also some rare variants.

Immunohistochemical markers for melanoma include:

* S100

* MELAN-A

* HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45

Biopsy and pathological examination are essential for staging melanoma. The Breslow thickness is the key prognostic indicator without lymph node metastases. The AJCC staging system incorporates lymph node involvement, distant metastases, and evidence-based prognostic factors to guide optimal care for melanoma.

Pearl PM0391: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:



A : Asymmetry

* Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

* Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

* The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

* Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

* There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: 153. A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. The X-ray image is given below. CT scan of the chest reveals metastasis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the sunburst appearance of the tumor at the metaphyseal end of a long bone, which is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

Other options:

Option A - Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

* Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis

* Soap bubble appearance

* Periosteal new bone formation is absent.



Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.



Option D - Secondary metastasis from the prostate is typically densely osteosclerotic, in contrast to osteolytic renal and thyroid lesions. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Local and distal staging includes X-rays and MRI of the whole affected bone, bone scintigraphy, and CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. The most sensitive imaging modality for identifying metastases is the whole-body MRI.

questions.text: 154. A 25-year-old male patient presented with itching and a rash on his torso. He also complains of a chronic cough with sputum production and mucoid diarrhea. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. Blood investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia and raised serum IgE levels. Larva currens is suspected. What is the preferred treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple erythematous tracts in the skin is suggestive of larva currens caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. The preferred treatment for this condition is ivermectin.

S. stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. It has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil by feeding on bacteria. 

Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. From here, they enter the venous circulation and travel to the right side of the heart and the lungs. Within the lungs, they traverse the capillaries, enter the larynx, migrate up, and are swallowed in the pharynx. Ultimately, they end up in the gastrointestinal tract. 

The female worms lay eggs in the mucosa leading to the release of rhabditiform larva. The larvae then migrate to the lumen of the intestine and are released in feces. They may transform into filariform larvae while transiting through the gastrointestinal tract which then penetrates the mucosa leading to autoinfection. 

The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.



Clinical manifestations can be grouped as follows: 

* Cutaneous manifestations: 

* Dermatitis is characterized by pruritus and erythema. This occurs at the site where the larvae penetrate the skin. 

* Larva currens or racing larvae are characterized by multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae

* Pulmonary manifestations are characterized by bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma. 

* Intestinal manifestations are characterized by mucoid diarrhea, protein-losing enteropathy, and paralytic ileus. 

* Hyperinfection occurs in immunocompromised individuals due to extensive autoinfection and worm load. 

Diagnosis of Strongyloides infection is by the wet mount of stool showing rhabditiform larvae or aspirates of sputum, jejunum, or duodenum. Peripheral eosinophilia and IgE may be raised. 

The image given below shows the rhabditiform larvae.



Treatment involves ivermectin (200 mcg/kg/day for 2 days) or albendazole (400 mg/day for 3 days).

questions.text: 155. A patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of dyspnea. On examination, there was elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting type of pedal edema, and crepitations in the lungs. After a detailed evaluation, he was diagnosed to be the case of heart failure and was started on digoxin. Which other medication if added to this patient can lead to digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Furosemide, if given along with digoxin can cause hypokalemia and lead to digoxin-induced arrhythmias. Hence, they should not be given together. Combination with other drugs does not cause life-threatening side effects.

Digoxin is the cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity are ventricular tachycardia, partial to complete A-V block, severe bradycardia, and atrial fibrillation/flutter. Gastrointestinal side effects, headache, fatigue, and sleeplessness may also be present.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

* Hypokalemia - It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 

* Drugs causing hypokalemia- diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids

* Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein) like quinidine

* Renal/hepatic failure

* Thyrotoxicosis

Digoxin should be discontinued whenever toxicity is suspected. An effective antidote for digoxin toxicity is digibind, which is an antidigoxin antibody.

Other options:

Option A: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist. It irreversibly binds to H2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of parietal cells. Other available H2 receptor antagonists are cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine, and nizatidine. It does not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

Option B: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor. The important side effect is hypotension. Combining this with digoxin will not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

Option C: Nesiritide is a human recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide. It inhibits sodium transport in the proximal and distal tubule and promotes natriuresis. The important side effect is hypotension. It does not potentiate digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: 156. A pet bird shop owner presents with dyspnea and cough for the last 3 weeks. HRCT finding is shown below. Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the CD4+/CD8+ ratio is found to be 1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A pet bird shop owner with cough and dyspnea for the last 3 weeks, with diffuse ground glass opacities on HRCT, CD4+/CD8+ ratio < 1 is likely suggestive is hypersensitivity pneumonitis. 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) occurs due to inhalational exposure to a number of antigens, causing inflammation of the alveoli and the small airways. The cause of the inflammation is dysregulated Th1 and Th17 immune response (type IV hypersensitivity). Antigens derived from fungal, bacterial, mycobacterial, bird-derived, and chemical sources have all been implicated in causing HP. Bird fancier’s lung must be considered in patients with history of pet birds and is precipitated by exposure to antigens derived from feathers, droppings, and serum proteins. 

HP has been divided into 3 forms depending on the clinical manifestations:

* Acute HP manifests within 8 hours of exposure to the antigen. The symptoms include fever with chills, malaise, and dyspnea. There is complete resolution of the symptoms within hours to days if there is no further exposure to the antigen. 

* In subacute HP, the systemic and pulmonary symptoms develop insidiously over a few weeks, like in this patient. Complete resolution of symptoms is seen here as well, but it takes a longer time. 

* Chronic HP presents with an even slower course — with cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and clubbing of digits. Unlike other forms, there is permanent impairment of the airways to some extent in chronic HP. This is irreversible and does not respond to the removal of inciting agents from the patient's environment. 

In subacute HP, HRCT shows poorly defined centrilobular nodules, background ground-glass opacification and lobular areas of air trapping. In chronic HP, ancillary findings such as coexisting areas of mosaic attenuation and air trapping. Furthermore, fibrosis can manifest as reticular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing. Although subpleural honeycombing may be observed, unlike idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the bases of the lungs are typically spared. Either obstructive or restrictive patterns may be seen on pulmonary function testing. Detection of IgG antibodies against specific antigens is an adjunctive investigation in the diagnosis of HP.

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage shows a CD4+/CD8+ lymphocyte ratio < 1 in most cases of HP. Lung biopsy shows the formation of noncaseating granulomas, but they are poorly defined.

The mainstay of treatment of HP is avoidance of the offending antigen. However, in subacute and chronic forms of the disease, there is a role of steroids as well. 

Other options:

Option A: Sarcoidosis is characterized by well-defined noncaseating granulomas, and CD4+/CD8+ ratio of >1 in BAL. Furthermore, the presence of a clear-cut risk factor (exposure to birds) in this patient makes the diagnosis more likely to be HP.

Option B: Tuberculosis will present as upper lobe infiltrates with cavitation on CT scan. The sputum smear microscopy will be positive for acid-fast bacilli and nucleic acid amplification test.

Option D: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is characterized by a necrotizing granulomatous small vessel vasculitis with a history of bronchial asthma and peripheral eosinophilia. CT findings typically include bilateral peripheral parenchymal opacification (shown in image below), bronchial wall thickening and pulmonary nodules.

questions.text: 157. A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mention that the bilateral 8th cranial nerves were severed during the surgery. Which of the following can be considered for further management?
questions.solution:
Auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is considered for management when bilateral 8th cranial nerves are severed as it directly stimulates the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem.

Auditory brainstem implants are modified cochlear implants designed to bypass the 8th nerve and directly stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex. Such damage to the 8th cranial nerve can occur during surgery for bilateral vestibular schwannomas. In the case of unilateral acoustic neuromas and subsequent nerve damage, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side. 

Other options: All the other options bypass different parts of the external and middle ear to reach the cochlea and require an intact 8th nerve for further transmitting signals. Thus they are not useful in this case.

Option A: Vibrant Soundbridge Device is a semi-implantable hearing aid that picks up sound from the environment and transmits it to the ossicles of the middle ear and then the cochlea. It is used in patients older than 18 years with moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss.

Option B: A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti. When the hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve is a prerequisite for cochlear implant surgery and cannot be used in this case.

Option C: Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) works through bone conduction to bypass the external and middle ear and transmit signals directly to the cochlea. It is primarily used for cases of conductive hearing loss.

Pearl PM1817: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:



Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC). The electrodes of the cochlear implant are placed in the scala tympani and are passed through the round window from the middle ear.

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

* Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)

* Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: 158. An elderly male who is a chronic smoker presents with painless gross hematuria with no flank pain or palpable mass. An ultrasound done shows no abnormality. Urine cytology is pending. Which of the following is the most important diagnostic investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggests a possible diagnosis of bladder cancer. Negative ultrasound findings do not rule out bladder cancer. Hence, the most important diagnostic investigation for this patient is cystourethroscopy.

It facilitates the visualization of any abnormality on the surface of the bladder and aids in taking biopsy samples. It is also used for transurethral resection of bladder tumors (TURBT) and to follow up on patients with carcinoma in situ.

Bladder carcinoma is characterized by painless, gross hematuria, which is the most important symptom. It might lead to the formation of clots and subsequent urinary retention. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may also be seen. Bladder carcinoma can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain due to nerve involvement.

Smoking and exposure to urothelial carcinogens such as benzidine and naphthylamine are some of the most important risk factors. Bladder cancer is also increasingly prevalent in people working in the textile, leather, and dye industries.  

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is classified into 3 types:

* Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70%) are exophytic tumors that grow into the bladder cavity.

* Muscle-invasive bladder cancers are large irregular ulcers with a broad base.

* Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ is characterized by the presence of irregularly arranged cells that have large nuclei.

Urine cytology that shows the presence of malignant cells is highly sensitive. Complete urinary tract imaging with CT and MRI is used to assess extravesical spread and metastasis. This helps determine the stage of the tumor and its appropriate treatment plan.

Management:

* Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: Intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)

* Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection, with/without neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options:

Option A: A bimanual examination is performed before and after TURBT to ensure the complete removal of the tumor. Not for initial diagnosis.

Option B: Non-contrast CT and MRI are used for the clinical staging of the disease prior to treatment options like TURBT. It can also be used to detect renal cancer, but it is unlikely as there is no palpable mass, no flank pain, and no USG masses.

Option D: Intravenous urography studies show a filling defect. However, they have been largely replaced by non-contrast CT and MRI studies.

questions.text:
159. A 56-year-old female presents with a fracture. A DEXA scan was performed, which revealed a T value of -3 SD. Routine investigations findings are as shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be given as a treatment?

Serum Ca²⁺: 12.0 mg/dL Serum ALP: 400 IU
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is suggestive of severe osteoporosis, and Teriparatide should not be given in this case in the setting of hypercalcemia and raised ALP levels as it worsens hypercalcemia.

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH 1-34) used primarily to treat severe osteoporosis. It mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, which, in low doses, stimulates osteoblast activity, leading to bone formation and increased bone density.

Teriparatide is given in males or postmenopausal females with very high risk of fractures (T score of -3 SD in absence of fracture or <-2.5 SD with fractures), intolerant to other osteoporosis therapy or are unable to tolerate bisphosphonates. It is given once daily as a subcutaneous injection.

Adverse effects include muscle pain, hypercalcemia, exacerbation of nephrolithiasis, and elevated serum uric acid levels. Increased risk of osteosarcoma is a concern with Teriparatide, therefore, current guidelines recommend a maximum lifetime use of less than 2 years for teriparatide.

Other options:

Option A: Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption and preventing calcium release.

Option C: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody used in osteoporosis that inhibits RANKL, preventing osteoclast formation and lowering calcium levels.

Option D: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen modulator (SERM) that reduces bone resorption and increases bone density. It does not raise calcium levels, hence safe to use in this patient.

questions.text:
160. An individual presented with loss of function of both the MLF and the PPRF on the left side. He was diagnosed with a horizontal gaze palsy termed as " One and a Half Syndrome". Which of the following horizontal gaze movements of the eyes are preserved in this condition?

MLF: Medial longitudinal fasciculus

PPRF: Parapontine reticular formation

choices.text: Left eye adduction component in right gaze
Left eye abduction component in left gaze
Right eye adduction component in left gaze
Right eye abduction component in right gaze

questions.solution:
Right eye abduction component in right gaze is preserved. It is the only residual movement seen in One and a Half Syndrome.

The left MLF is lost, which means the left medial rectus cannot function. The left PPRF is lost, which means the left lateral rectus and the right medial rectus cannot function. Hence the only functioning muscle of horizontal gaze preserved is the right lateral rectus which causes abduction on the right side.

Gaze can be either horizontal or vertical. Horizontal gaze is controlled by 3 structures:

* Frontal eye field

* PPRF

* MLF

Ipsilateral Frontal eye field controls contralateral gaze. Ipsilateral PPRF controls ipsilateral lateral rectus(LR) and contralateral medial rectus(via contralateral MLF). Ipsilateral MLF controls ipsilateral medial rectus(MR).

In One and a Half Syndrome, there is ipsilateral Gaze palsy with internuclear ophthalmoplegia. This results in only one movement, contralateral abduction nystagmus preserved in contralateral gaze. Here, left side PPRF+MLF palsy results in left MR, LR, and right MR palsy.

The lesions and consequent gaze defect are explained below:

Ipsilateral PPRF Ipsilateral LR and contralateral MR(Ipsilateral gaze palsy) Right PPRF lesion causes right gaze palsy
Ipsilateral MLF Ipsilateral MR lost(Contralateral gaze defect) Right MLF lesion causes left gaze defect where right MR cannot adduct while left LR exhibits abduction nystagmus.

questions.text: 161. A 42-year-old patient is undergoing focused parathyroidectomy. After removal of parathyroid adenoma, the surgeon can confirm that there are no hyperactive parathyroid tissue left if the intraoperative PTH shows:
questions.solution:
An intraoperative PTH level decline of >50% as compared to the preoperative PTH in 10 minutes suggests a single-gland disease. This is known as the Miami criteria.

About 80% of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should show a decline of >50% compared to the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes.

However, if there is no significant drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration. 162. A 5-day-old infant presents with yellowish discoloration of skin, refusal to feed, and poor arousal. The mother says that the child is exclusively breastfed. On systemic examination, there is hepatomegaly, and the eyes show an oil drop cataract. Which of the following is true?

Assertion (A): Breast milk is completely contraindicated in this patient, but the child can consume conventional formula feeds.

Reason (R): The deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase leads to intolerance of breast milk.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation for assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.solution:
The assertion is false, but the reason is true.

The assertion is an incorrect statement since conventional formula feeds contain lactose or galactose as their component. This patient is a case of classical galactosemia, where there is a deficiency in the galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase enzyme that inhibits the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. 

The reason is a correct statement, as the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase enzyme leads to difficulty digesting galactose in the breastmilk.

The accumulated galactose-1-phosphate causes damage to organs such as eyes, kidneys, brain, and liver. The patient will also have hypoglycemia as glucose-1-phosphate is not produced and hence cannot be used in glycolysis.

The child will need lactose-free or soy-based formula feeds, and such a diet is to be continued into adulthood.

questions.text:
163. Arrange the following stages of Androgenetic Alopecia in males in the correct sequence:

1) Hair loss progresses to the vertex (crown) 2) Recession of the frontal hairline at the temples 3) Band of hair connecting the frontal and vertex regions narrows 4) Complete baldness at the crown with only a horseshoe-shaped fringe remaining
questions.solution:
2 → 1 → 3 → 4 (Option B) represents the correct sequence of stages of Androgenetic Alopecia in males.

Androgenetic alopecia is characterized by reduced hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

The Hamilton-Norwood classification describes the following stages in the progression of male pattern baldness:

* Stage 1: No visible hair loss; full head of hair.

* Stage 2: Mild temple recession forming an "M" shape (Recession of the frontal hairline at the temples).

* Stage 3: Deeper frontal recession, exposing more forehead.     Stage 3 Vertex (a variant of stage 3): A small bald spot appears on the crown (Hair loss progresses to the vertex (crown)).

* Stage 4: Frontal and crown hair loss progress but remain separate.

* Stage 5: The bridge of hair between the frontal and crown areas narrows (Band of hair connecting the frontal and vertex regions narrows).

* Stage 6: The bridge disappears, forming a large bald area with side hair.

* Stage 7: Only a thin horseshoe-shaped fringe remains on the sides and back (Complete baldness at the crown with only a horseshoe-shaped fringe remaining)
