questions.text: 164. Which of the following statements is correct about the management of nasal fractures?

choices.text: Simple fractures without displacement need surgical management
Closed reduction of fractures, if required, must be done within 2 weeks
Walsham forceps can be used to reduce nasal septum
In children, delayed reduction of nasal fractures is preferred

questions.solution:
The correct statement on nasal fracture is closed reduction of fractures, if required, must be done within 2 weeks.

Nasal fractures must be reduced before the appearance of oedema or after it has subsided, which is usually in 5-7 days because the presence of oedema interferes with accurate reduction. It is difficult to reduce a nasal fracture after 2 weeks because it heals by that time. 

Closed reduction involves disimpaction and realignment of nasal bone fragments. Open reduction is indicated when closed reduction fails, and early open reduction is rarely required. Healed nasal deformities can be corrected by open-reduction methods such as rhinoplasty and septorhinoplasty.

Other options:

Option A: Simple fractures without displacement need no surgical management. Conservative management with topical vasoconstrictor drops helps alleviate congestion and obstructive symptoms.

Option C: Walsham forceps can be used to reduce nasal bone fragments. Asch forceps are preferred to reduce nasal septum.





Option D: In children, delayed reduction of nasal fractures is preferred, is an incorrect statement. Healing is faster in children, and therefore, early reduction is preferred.

questions.text:
165. Which of the following are false regarding bedaquiline?

* Avoided in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities

* Exhibits cross resistance with Clofazamine

* Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis

* Large volume of distribution owing to high amphiphilicity
questions.solution:
The mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline is by inhibition of ATP synthase. Pretomanid and Delamanid act by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism. It is largely deposited in tissues owing to its amphiphilicity.

Resistance caused by mutations in efflux pumps and their regulators is also observed and is linked to the development of cross-resistance to clofazimine. CYP3A4 is a major enzyme involved in the metabolism of bedaquiline. Due to the high risk of QT prolongation, the FDA has issued a black box warning against the use of bedaquiline, therefore having restricted use in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities.

Bedaquiline/ Sirturo is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. According to the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP), it is used as an add-on drug for pulmonary MDR-TB in adults >18 years.

Dosage of bedaquiline:

* Bedaquiline is given as 400 mg once a day for the first 2 weeks, followed by 200 mg three times weekly (with ≥48 hours gap between doses) for the remaining 22 weeks, completing a 24-week course.

Adverse effects of bedaquiline include cardiotoxicity (QT prolongation) and hepatotoxicity.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the World Health Organization (WHO):

* Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid

* Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine

* Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid (newer add-on drug), ethionamide, p-aminosalicylic acid

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. In patients not treated before and without the extensive disease, a shorter regimen of 6 months intensive phase with bedaquiline and other drugs is used. The other drugs are continued for 5 months-continuation phase. In pregnant women with MDR-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

questions.text: 166. A 11-year-old individual presents with ambiguous genitalia and undescended testes. Genetic testing reveals a 46, XY karyotype with a mutation affecting 5α-reductase activity. Which of the following developmental changes is most likely impaired in this individual?

choices.text: Development of the epididymis, vas deferens and seminal vesicles
Fusion of the labioscrotal folds leading to scrotum formation
Growth of the larynx and deepening of the voice at puberty

questions.solution:
The given patient presentation with ambiguous genitalia, undescended testes and 46, XY karyotype, suggests 5α-reductase deficiency. Fusion of the labioscrotal folds leading to scrotum formation will be impaired in this individual.

5α-reductase deficiency is a genetic disorder leading to impaired conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT).  In 5α-reductase deficiency, testosterone-driven internal genital development remains intact, but external genitalia may be underdeveloped at birth. At puberty, testosterone promotes the growth of the larynx, deepening of the voice, increased muscle mass, and erythropoiesis. These effects remain unaffected in 5α-reductase deficiency because testosterone production is normal. 

Testosterone is also converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5α-reductase in specific target cells. DHT forms more stable complexes, enhancing androgenic effects. Humans have three types of 5α-reductase: mainly type 1 is found throughout the skin and scalp, while type 2 is present in genital tissues and the prostate. Testosterone is responsible for the development of internal male reproductive structures (epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles) from the Wolffian ducts, while DHT plays a crucial role in forming external genitalia (penis, scrotum, prostate).

questions.text:
167. A 58-year-old woman is undergoing follow-up after completing chemoradiation for stage IIIB cervical cancer. A post-treatment plain MRI shows a hyper-intense lesion with cystic areas in the pelvis. What is the next best step in management?

SCC - Squamous cell carcinoma

choices.text: Continue with treatment and check after another cycle of chemoradiation
Evaluate with tumor markers like SCC Antigen
PET-CT scan to assess metabolic activity of the mass

questions.solution:
PET-CT scan to assess the metabolic activity of the mass is the next best step in management.

After treatment, distinguishing between residual disease and post-treatment changes can be challenging. A PET-CT scan can help assess the metabolic activity of the mass to determine if it is an active disease or scar tissue. It is the best next step because it helps determine whether the residual mass is metabolically active (indicative of persistent or recurrent disease) or inactive (potentially scar tissue or necrosis).

Other options:

Option A: Continue with treatment and check after another cycle of chemoradiation is incorrect because it is always better to be certain about the location of lesions so that more focused treatment can be given in the subsequent cycles.

Option B: Tumor markers like SCC antigen may be elevated in persistent or recurrent disease, but they lack specificity and sensitivity for treatment response. PET-CT is superior for identifying viable tumour tissue, while tumour markers are more useful for monitoring trends over time.

Option D: A biopsy is not the first step in post-treatment assessment. PET-CT helps determine whether the mass is metabolically active, and biopsy is usually considered if PET-CT is inconclusive.

questions.text: 168. A patient presents to the emergency room with a laceration on his left forearm. On examination of the wound, it is found to have an irregular edge and depth. Which of the following is the most appropriate technique to be used to achieve the most accurate approximation of the wound?
questions.solution:
Mattress suturing, seen in image 3, would yield the best approximation when the wounded edges and depth are irregular.

Mattress sutures: They can be vertical or horizontal and are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then, the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again, as seen in the figure. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially in settings where the edges are not easily approximated.

The following image shows the mattress suture technique:



In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound must be 'x'. Distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

The following image shows interrupted suture:



Continuous suture technique: The first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached. Care should be taken to maintain the tension of the suture to avoid excessive tension or leaving it too slack; hence, the use of an assistant is warranted. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures:



Subcuticular sutures: 

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound, and then, they are gently pulled together. This causes an approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured with the ends of absorbable sutures when used. When non-absorbable sutures are used, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

questions.text: 169. A 30-year-old female patient presented with erythematous papules encircled by a middle pale zone and a peripheral erythematous ring. These lesions were distributed bilaterally over the soles and palms. She has a history of mild fever 10 days ago for which she took non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The lesion mentioned above with erythematous papules encircled by a middle pale zone and a peripheral erythematous ring describes characteristic target lesions seen in erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme is a self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis as a result of cell-mediated hypersensitivity to infections or drugs. Some triggers include HSV-1(most common), drugs like NSAIDs, and conditions like lupus erythematosus and leukemias.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter and have 3 zones-

* The central zone is a dusky area with papule/vesicle/bullae

* The intermediate zone is a pale oedematous zone

* The peripheral zone shows the rim of erythema (around the lesion)

Treatment of erythema multiforme includes treatment of underlying cause and steroids.

Other conditions in which target lesions are seen are Lyme's disease (called erythema migrans) and paraneoplastic pemphigus.

The following image depicts target lesions:



Other options: 

Option A - Irritant contact dermatitis occurs due to the physical or toxic effects of environmental exposures. It has a wide range of features from stinging and burning to persistent dryness, capping, or acute caustic burn. The following image shows irritant contact dermatitis of the hand:



Option C - Fixed drug reaction is an adverse reaction to a drug characterized by recurrent lesions that are well-defined present in the same location every time the drug is taken. The lesions are generally well-defined, round, oval, erythematous, or edematous that become violaceous or vesicular.



Option D - Steven Johnson's syndrome is a mucocutaneous reaction to drugs that is characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe version of this condition.



Pearl PM2483: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.



 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.



 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.



 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: 170. The fracture seen in the X-ray given below is?
questions.solution:
The image shows an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. So the fracture seen in the X-ray is Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. The most common clinical feature is tenderness over the distal end of the forearm. 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Other options: 

Option B: Monteggia fracture is the fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of the proximal radio-ulnar joint and the subluxation of the radiocapitellar joint.

Option C: Smith's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment. It also known as reverse Colle's fracture.

Option D: Colle's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Pearl PM0649: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.



 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.



 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.



 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).



 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.



 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).



 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: 171. A 100 Hz tuning fork was used to generate a time trace while recording a simple muscle twitch in an isolated frog gastrocnemius muscle. The recorded trace is shown below. Based on the trace, calculate the tetanizing frequency between point B and point C.
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency between point B and point C for the above muscle tracing would be 25 Hz.

Tetanizing frequency is the minimum stimulation frequency required to produce sustained contraction (tetanus). Tetanizing frequency is equal to 1/contraction period. The contraction period is the time taken from the latent period to the maximum force of contraction.

In this case, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork, which means it recorded 100 waves per second. Therefore, the duration of each wave in the time tracer is 0.01 seconds.

In the image given in the question, between the point B (end of latent period) to point C (maximum force of contraction), there are about 4 waves. Hence, the duration of contraction = 4 x 0.01 = 0.04 seconds. Substituting the value in the formula, we get: Tetanizing frequency = 1/0.04 sec = 100/4 = 25 Hz.

There are two types of tetanus: complete tetanus, in which no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, in which incomplete relaxation occurs between the summated stimuli. 

When a repeated stimulus to a muscle fiber occurs before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction, increasing the total strength of the contraction. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

questions.text: 172. Which of the following is the most universally accepted health status indicator?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic conditions in which they live.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilisation, and effectiveness of health care.  

Other options:

Option B: Maternal Mortality Rate shows enormous variations according to the country's level of socioeconomic status.

Option C: Life expectancy is a good indicator of socio-economic development in general.

Option D: Neonatal Mortality Rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

questions.text: 173. A 48-year-old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis presents with bilateral pitting pedal oedema. Urine examination shows proteinuria. A renal biopsy is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following deposits will most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
AA protein deposits are most likely to be present in the renal biopsy patient. The given clinical scenario of the patient with the renal biopsy showing amyloid deposits (apple green birefringence under polarised light) suggests a diagnosis of reactive systemic amyloidosis. 

Reactive systemic amyloidosis (previously called secondary amyloidosis) is seen as secondary to a chronic inflammatory condition. While tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and chronic osteomyelitis were the predominant underlying diseases before, rheumatoid arthritis and other connective tissue disorders are now seen more frequently. Reactive amyloidosis can also occur in association with solid tumours such as renal cell carcinoma and Hodgkin lymphoma. 

During inflammation, increased levels of cytokines like IL-1 and IL-6 stimulate the production of serum amyloid-associated (SAA) protein in the liver. SAA is normally degraded to soluble end products by action of monocyte-derived enzymes. Some patients have a defect in this enzymatic pathway or have a genetic structural defect in the structure of the SAA molecule itself. These patients are at high risk of developing reactive systemic amyloidosis due to AA protein deposition.

Patients with amyloidosis initially have non-specific symptoms, such as fatigue, weight loss, and light-headedness. In time, manifestations related to the end-organ affected develop. This includes proteinuria due to renal involvement, which can progress to cause uremia and renal failure. Cardiac amyloidosis may present as congestive heart failure or arrhythmias. Amyloidosis of the tongue may cause dysphagia and speech difficulty.

The diagnosis depends on the histological demonstration of amyloid in the tissues. The most common sites for taking biopsies are the kidney (when renal manifestations are present) or rectal or gingival tissues. Abdominal fat aspirate can also be done for systemic amyloidosis. Staining with congo red shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light.

questions.text: 175. A 24-year-old male with infertility, tall stature, gynecomastia, and small, firm testes has elevated FSH, LH, low testosterone, and azoospermia. Which of the following would most likely be seen on testicular biopsy?

choices.text: Hyperplastic Leydig cells with hyalinized seminiferous tubules
Prominent peritubular fibrosis with increased germ cells

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male with gynecomastia, small testis with elevated LH and FSH is suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome. On testicular biopsy, hyperplastic Leydig cells with hyalinized seminiferous tubules are seen after puberty.

Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by feminine features in an apparent male with small testes. As seminiferous tubules are not properly developed, infertility results. Hence, the syndrome is also called seminiferous tubule dysgenesis. Plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, and estradiol are increased, and plasma testosterone is decreased.

Before puberty, testicular biopsy in Klinefelter syndrome may show absent or deficient germ cells. After puberty, there is hyalinization of seminiferous tubules, Leydig cell clumping, and Sertoli cell predominance, leading to azoospermia and infertility.

Other options:

Option A: Normal spermatogenesis with maturation arrest is typically seen in cases of non-obstructive azoospermia due to genetic mutations or hormonal imbalances affecting spermatogenesis.

Option C: Numerous spermatogonia with active spermatogenesis is typically seen in normal testicular function or obstructive azoospermia (e.g., congenital absence of the vas deferens, vasectomy).

Option D: Prominent peritubular fibrosis with increased germ cells is suggestive of testicular atrophy due to chronic injury, such as radiation exposure, infections (mumps orchitis), or varicocele.

questions.text:
176. A 50-year-old woman was brought with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she drinks 2-3 beers a day and that she had taken excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus. The vitals and results of laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Vitals and laboratory investigations:

* BP: 138/90 mmHg

* Pulse: 85 beats/min

* Temp: 98.7 F

* Hb: 11.3 g/dL

* MCV: 110 fL

* Fingerstick glucose (GRBS): 64 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with confusion, agitation, and horizontal nystagmus. This clinical history along with the recent history of heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Chronic alcoholics have thiamine (B1) deficiency, which gets exacerbated with recent excessive intake.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

* Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

* Global confusion

* Truncal ataxia

* Ophthalmoplegia

* Horizontal nystagmus 

* Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

* Memory loss

* Confabulation

* Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Hence, the initial treatment in a patient with high alcohol intake with new-onset ataxia should be emergent IV thiamine infusion to prevent the progression of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other Options:

Option B- IV glucose: It should be given after IV thiamine in an alcoholic patient to treat hypoglycemia. Because if given before, it will worsen thiamine deficiency and will deteriorate this patient's condition.

Option C- IV naltrexone: It is given to abstain from alcohol use, not for treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy

Option D- IV vitamin B12: Although this patient has macrocytosis and difficulty walking, nystagmus is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence, it is not given. Macrocytosis in this patient is due to chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: 177. A study is done to identify the association between the COVID-19 vaccine and developing severe COVID-19 disease. The scientists collected data from 2 groups of 1000 individuals each, sampled based on vaccinated and unvaccinated status. These individuals were followed up to look for the development of severe disease. Which of the following would be the best parameter to find the association?
questions.solution:
In this study, the sample population is classified on the basis of exposure (vaccinated) and non-exposure (unvaccinated) and it follows the individuals until the development of the disease, which makes it a cohort study. The best parameter to find the association in this cohort study is relative risk.

Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study. 

Other options:

Option A: The incidence rate is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. It is not a measure of the strength of the association in cohort studies.

Option B: Prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time. It is also not a measure of the strength of the association in cohort studies.

Option C: The odds ratio, also known as a cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of the association between risk factors and outcomes in case-control studies. A case-control study categorizes the population into cases (having disease/exposure) and controls (not having disease/exposure).

Pearl PM0268: Cohort Study

* A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).

* It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.

* Design of a cohort study:



* Types of cohort study:

* Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies

* Retrospective (historical) cohort studies

* Combination cohort studies

* Steps of cohort study:

* Selection of study subjects

* Obtaining data on exposure

* Selection of comparison groups

* Follow-up

* Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk

* Advantages of cohort study:

* Incidence can be calculated

* Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time

* Provides direct estimate of relative risk

* Calculation of dose-response ratio

* Minimization of certain biases

* Disadvantages of cohort study:

* Cannot use for uncommon diseases

* Expensive, requires a large population and longer time

* Many common administrative and ethical problems

* High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult

* Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate

* Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Pearl PM0265: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 



* Steps of case control study:

* Selection of cases and controls

* Matching

* Measurement of exposure

* Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio

* Advantages of case control study:

* Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive

* Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects

* Used to investigate rare diseases

* Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified

* No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems

* Disadvantages of case control study:

* Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias

* Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult

* Incidence cannot be measured

* Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

* Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

* Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Pearl PM0269: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

* Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

* It is also called risk ratio.



* It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.

* RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)

* RR = 1 indicates no association.

* RR > 1 indicates positive association.

* RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.

* Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d


 

Attributable Risk:

* Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

* It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: 178. A 69 year old male presented with back pain and difficulty in evacuating the bladder. CT spine was taken and showed the below appearance. Biopsy was taken from the primary lesion which showed a Gleason score of 9. Which of the following genetic alterations is most often associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The answer is ETS-TMPRSS2 fusion.

The given clinical scenario of an old male presenting with back pain and urinary symptoms and CT Spine showing osteoblastic vertebral lesions, following which a biopsy taken from the primary was scored using Gleason score all point towards a diagnosis of Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate. ETS-TMPRSS2 fusion is the most common genetic alteration observed in the prostate and about half of all prostate cancers show this rearrangement. 

Prostate adenocarcinoma occurs in the prostatic epithelium after exposure to risk factors such as androgen stimulation, chronic inflammation, germline MYC variants, a Western diet, and polymorphisms in glutathione-S-transferase, which is responsible for detoxifying polycyclic hydrocarbons.

These risk factors contribute to the acquisition of hallmark mutations that act as driver and passenger mutations for neoplasm. The usual order in which these mutations is believed to occur is as follows:

* TMPRSS-ETS fusion, Critical telomere shortening and GSTP1 gene hypermethylation result in prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia(PIN), a recognized precursor lesion for carcinoma.

* Loss of p27 results in conversion of PIN to localized adenocarcinoma of the prostate.

* PTEN loss combined with activation of telomerases results in metastatic carcinoma of the prostate.

*  Aggressive prostate cancers result from further mutations in TP53, MYC, Androgen receptor and RB. Androgen receptor mutations make these tumours resistant to hormonal therapy and also make them independent of solely androgen receptor stimulated growth.

Advanced prostate cancer has a propensity for osteoblastic (bone forming) metastasis as shown in the above CT scan. Osteoblastic vertebral metastases in old men should immediately prompt a prostate evaluation. Spread occurs via hematogenous route primarily to the axial skeleton. The lumbar spine is most frequently involved followed by the proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in descending order.

Other Options:

Option B: RUNX1-RUNXT1 fusion gene is seen in acute myeloid leukemia(AML )and its presence is considered to harbour a favourable prognosis. Morphologically, the full range of myelocytic maturation is seen. Auer rods are noted in the cytoplasm of these myelocytes.

Option C: EWSR1-FLI1 fusion gene is a highly specific mutation seen in Ewing Sarcoma. More than 90 percent of Ewing Sarcoma cases contain a balanced translocation between genes on chromosomes 22(EWSR1) and 11(FLI1).This code for an abnormal chimeric protein that binds DNA and accelerates cell division and growth.

Option D: PML-RARA is a special reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 producing the PML-RARA fusion protein which results in acute Promyelocytic leukemia, a variety of AML with a good prognosis.

questions.text: 179. An anesthetist is performing the regional block technique shown in the image given below. This technique cannot be used for analgesia/anesthesia in which of the following conditions/procedures?
questions.solution:
The image shows a needle at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid. This procedure is used in superficial cervical plexus block. This cannot be used to provide analgesia for a dislocated shoulder.

Interscalene blocks are used to provide regional anaesthesia for conditions of the shoulder like shoulder dislocation.

The cervical plexus is derived from the C1, C2, C3, and C4 spinal nerves and innervates prevertebral muscles, strap muscles of the neck, and the phrenic nerve. The superficial cervical plexus provides a cutaneous sensation of the skin between the trigeminal innervation of the face and the T2 dermatome of the trunk. The deep cervical plexus innervates the musculature of the neck.

Cervical plexus blocks (CPB) are techniques of regional anaesthesia that is used to provide anaesthesia/analgesia in various head and neck surgeries.

The superficial cervical block is achieved by inserting a 22-gauge needle, at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The needle is inserted 4 cm deep, and 5 mL of the solution is injected along the posterior border and the medial surface of the sternocleidomastoid.

This technique can be used for surgeries like

* Carotid endarterectomy 

* Thyroidectomy

* Tracheostomy

* Lymph node dissection

* Plastic surgery repairs

* Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy

* External ear surgery

The complications that may occur are inadvertent intravascular injection; phrenic nerve injury (rare); blocking of the accessory nerve, leading to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscle weakness; and puncture of the internal jugular vein and carotid artery.

This technique is contraindicated if there is an active infection overlying the injection site, contralateral phrenic nerve palsy, previous neck surgery and radiation, and allergy to injected drugs.

Interscalene block results in the blockade of the superficial and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. To perform this technique, the patient should be in the supine position, with the head turned away from the side to be blocked. The interscalene groove is palpated. A transverse line from the cricoid cartilage is drawn to intersect the interscalene groove. This point of intersection indicates the transverse process of C6 where the drug is administered.

questions.text: 180. Both PT (prothrombin time) and PTT ( partial thromboplastin time) can be used to assess all of the following coagulation factors, except _______.
questions.solution:
Both PT and PTT can be used to assess factors II, V, and X. PT is used to assess the extrinsic pathway, therefore, it cannot be used to assess Factor VIII which is a part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

Prothrombin time evaluates the extrinsic pathway, i.e, factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen. It measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin).

Causes of prolonged PT:

* Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs (vitamin K antagonists)

* Liver disease, particularly obstructive jaundice

* Vitamin K deficiency

* Disseminated intravascular coagulation

* Rarely, a previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect

Isolated prolonged prothrombin time occurs due to the deficiency of clotting factor VII.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma via the intrinsic pathway, i.e, factors XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

Causes of prolonged APTT:

* Disseminated intravascular coagulation

* Liver disease

* Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells

* Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants

* A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)

* Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII (since it is part of the extrinsic pathway)

* APTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency

APTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency (in which factors II, VII, IX, and X will fail to activate). A patient with previously undiagnosed hemophilia or another congenital coagulation disorder can also present with an isolated prolonged APTT.

questions.text: 181. The findings shown in the image are most likely to have been caused by?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows birdshot pellets within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia. The wound shown in the image is most likely to have been caused by close-range shotgun injury to the knee.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

The image below shows a shotgun cartridge:



Ammunition of a rifled weapon:

* There is a metal cylinder, closed at one end, which is the ‘shell’ or cartridge.

* The cylinder carries a percussion detonator in the base, either centrally or peripherally.

* The shell is loaded with explosive propellant such as nitrocellulose and the bullet is firmly clamped into the open end.

The image below shows a rifled gun cartridge:



Note: Blast particles would not have a uniform pellet size as seen in the image, which is characteristic of shotgun pellets.

questions.text: 182. A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the mechanism behind this condition?

choices.text: Automaticity of multiple foci in the atrium
Macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different P wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). The mechanism triggering multifocal atrial tachycardia is the automaticity of multiple atrial foci.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals; hence, it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). However, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.



Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.  

Identifying features in ECG:

* Heart rate > 100, typically between 100 and 150 beats/min

* Irregular rhythm

* Narrow QRS complex

* Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies 

* Variable PR interval

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are useful in slowing the atrial and ventricular rates. Radiofrequency ablation of the AV node is another treatment modality. Cardioversion is ineffective. 

Other options:

Option A - Increased atrial automaticity is seen in atrial tachycardia, which is a narrow-complex tachycardia in which abnormal P-wave morphology is observed. It can lead to an AV block if the rate is too rapid.

Option C - Atrial flutter is characterized by a macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium, which is usually encircling the tricuspid annulus. ECG shows characteristic saw-tooth flutter waves.

Option D - Abnormal bands of conductive tissue between the atria and ventricles are seen in atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia. ECG shows a characteristic delta wave in the presence of these accessory pathways.

questions.text: 183. A 50-year-old diabetic female presents with complaints of progressive pain in and around her left eye. It is associated with the development of multiple vesicles and pustules. These symptoms were preceded by an episode of influenza-like illness a week before. What is the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit-lamp finding of her eye?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus and the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit lamp image is called nummular keratitis.

Nummular keratitis is the earliest finding of the corneal stromal involvement. It is characterised by multiple, fine, granular, coin-shaped infiltrates in the anterior stroma. This condition presents during the second week of the infection and may cause permanent scarring.

questions.text: 184. A 2-year-old male presents with fever and productive cough. He has had a history of multiple respiratory tract infections since birth. Laboratory investigations show elevated IgM antibody levels. IgG levels are found to be low, while IgA and IgE are absent. Mutation in the gene encoding for which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Elevated IgM with low to absent levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies suggest hyper-IgM syndrome. Mutation in the gene encoding for the CD40 ligand is responsible for this condition.

CD40 ligand is normally responsible for class switching. Class switching refers to the genetic recombination event in which the heavy-chain constant segment of the IgM gene is replaced with a different constant segment that leads to a different type of antibody being produced (e.g. IgG, IgA, IgE, etc.).

Mutation in the gene that codes for CD40 ligand will impair class switching of the IgM antibodies to any other antibody type, and this results in relatively higher levels of IgM. Frequent infections of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract result from lower levels of other antibodies. Elevated IgM antibodies can sometimes react with blood cells, causing autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In others, IgM-producing plasma cells may proliferate and infiltrate the gastrointestinal mucosa.

Other options:

Option A: The adenosine deaminase (ADA) gene is deficient in the autosomal recessive variant of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). This results in the production of toxic metabolites that destroy the rapidly dividing T-cell lineage (affects T-cells more than B-cells). These children are susceptible to recurrent infections, and without a bone marrow transplant, they usually die within the first year of life. 

Option B: Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene is mutated in X-linked agammaglobulinemia. It occurs because the B-cells fail to undergo maturation. All lines of immunoglobulins are found to be low in this disease. Since it is an X-linked disorder, it is most commonly seen in young males. They present after the age of 6 months with recurrent respiratory tract infections.

Option D: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene is mutated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. This is also an X-linked disorder that presents with eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. They usually show low IgM levels, normal IgG, and elevated IgE and IgA levels.

questions.text:
185. Assertion: Activating mutations in FGF23 cause profound hypophosphatemia due to phosphaturia.
Reason: Control of serum phosphate is determined mainly by renal tubular reabsorption.

choices.text: Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason does not explain assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason explains assertion

questions.solution:
The correct answer is that both assertion and reason are true and reason explains the assertion.

The assertion states that activating mutations in FGF23 cause hypophosphatemia due to phosphaturia. This statement is true and can be substantiated by Autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets(ADHR), a rare condition where activating mutations in FGF23 cause reduced serum phosphorus levels due to phosphate loss in urine.

FGF23 is responsible for hypophosphatemia by at least two mechanisms. Like PTH, it causes reduced phosphate reabsorption in the PCT due to reduced expression of phosphate transporters in the apical membrane.

Secondly, it reduces the hydroxylation of vitamin D precursors to their active form, reducing active Vitamin D levels in the body and resulting in hypophosphatemia. 

The reason states that control of serum phosphate is determined mainly by renal tubular reabsorption. This statement is also true. The control of serum phosphate is by renal tubular reabsorption by various phosphate transporters like NaPi-2a and NaPi-2c. Filtered load of phosphate is 4-6 g/d and fractional excretion of phosphate is generally in the 10-15 percent range.

Dietary levels of phosphate are reflected in serum phosphate levels. Normal serum phosphate level in turn, is maintained by the kidney as urinary phosphate excretion is not constant and varies with dietary intake.

Higher phosphate absorption in the intestine causes an increase in serum levels of FGF23 which in turn induces phosphaturia by altering apical expression of phosphate transporters. Reduced dietary intake reduces urinary phosphate excretion by a similar mechanism. Hence, renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate, which is controlled by FGF23, is the controller of serum phosphate levels.  The assertion is explained by the reason.

Other evidence of the role of FGF23 in phosphate metabolism is:

* In X-linked Hypophosphatemic rickets(XLH), mutations in the PHEX gene cause overexpression of FGF23 and high serum FGF23 levels, which in turn induce phosphaturia resulting in hypophosphatemia.

* In Tumour Induced Osteomalacia(TIO), some tumours produce FGF23 which causes renal phosphate wasting and hypophosphatemia.

questions.text: 186. A patient was found to have spontaneous and continuous writhing movements at the neck. A lesion in which of the following structure is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
A lesion in the globus pallidus is most likely responsible for the given condition.

Lesions in the globus pallidus frequently lead to spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face. These movements are called athetosis.

Other options:

Option B: Lesions in the subthalamus often leads to sudden flailing movements of an entire limb, a condition called hemiballismus.

Option C: Lesions in the putamen lead to flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body, called chorea.

Option D: Lesions of the substantia nigra lead to Parkinson’s disease, characterised by rigidity, akinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: 187. Which of the following statements regarding puerperal sepsis is incorrect?

choices.text: After a vaginal delivery, infection usually starts at the site where the placenta was attached
A single dose of perioperative antibiotics for cesarean section reduces the risk of puerperal sepsis
The most common route of spread is through the hematogenous route
Puerperal sepsis can cause subinvolution of the uterus

questions.solution:
The most common route of spread of puerperal sepsis is direct ascension from the lower genital tract (not hematogenous).

Puerperal sepsis is a life-threatening postpartum infection that primarily affects the placental implantation site, decidua, and adjacent myometrium after vaginal delivery (option A). In cesarean deliveries, infection typically arises from a contaminated surgical incision. Bacteria from the vagina and cervix directly invade these areas rather than spreading via the bloodstream. Puerperal sepsis can prevent normal uterine healing and causes subinvolution of the uterus, leading to prolonged bleeding, pain, and tenderness due to ongoing infection and inflammation (option D).

A single dose of antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporins) given before cesarean delivery significantly reduces the risk of postpartum infection (option B).

If hemolytic Streptococcus is present in patients with puerperal sepsis, they should ideally be isolated. Supportive care includes IV fluids, calorie maintenance, anemia correction, and urinary catheterization if needed. Empiric IV antibiotics like gentamicin, clindamycin, and metronidazole are started while awaiting culture results. Severe sepsis is treated with IV piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenems plus clindamycin, while MRSA infections require IV vancomycin or teicoplanin.

questions.text: 188. A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with sudden pain in his scrotum associated with fever. His condition rapidly progressed and his scrotum appears as below. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for which he is taking canagliflozin. IV fluids are started and vital signs are noted to be stable. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image findings of cellulitis of the testis are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. The next best step in the management of this condition is IV fluids, intravenous antibiotics, and urgent surgical excision of the necrotic tissue.

Fournier's gangrene - 

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. 

Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as

* HIV

* Alcoholism

* Diabetes (the SGLT-2 inhibitors currently available are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin which can also cause Fournier's Gangrene)

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus can be seen as shown in the image below.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, it is also called shameful exposure of the testis. It is a surgical emergency.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical excision of the necrotic tissue. When the infection has been controlled, the vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful.

questions.text: 189. A 50-year-old male patient was undergoing a craniotomy procedure for a posterior cranial fossa tumor in a sitting position. Intraoperatively, there was a sudden drastic drop in EtCO2 to 8 mmHg and blood pressure dropped to 80/50 mmHg. A venous air embolism was suspected. What is the immediate next step of management?

choices.text: Compress jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation
Administer nitrous oxide to eliminate the emboli
Stop 100% oxygen administration to prevent further air embolism

questions.solution:
In this given scenario of venous air embolism (VAE), the immediate next step of management is to compress the jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation.

The goal of treatment in VAE is to prevent further air entry, treat the intravascular air and hemodynamic support.

* The first immediate step is to notify the surgeon to cover the surgical field with a saline-soaked dressing and tilt the table to prevent further air entry. In surgeries done in a sitting position, the jugular venous compression can restrict air entry into chest circulation.

* Improve patient oxygenation by administration of 100% oxygen. It also reduces embolus volume by eliminating nitrogen. Nitrous oxide should be discontinued even after minor embolic events to prevent the air from reaching left-sided circulation.

* Air entry to the right side of the heart may be relieved by a partial left lateral decubitus position. Aspiration of air from the right atrium can be tried by the use of a Bunegin-Albin multi-orifice catheter.

* Maintain optimum fluid status and stabilize the patient with inotropes or pressors if needed.

* In case of massive VAE with cardiac decompensation, initiate rapid cardiopulmonary resuscitation with chest compression.

* To decrease the severity of the disease, initiate anticoagulation therapy with heparin. The usage of steroids is controversial as steroids do not have any effect on cytotoxic brain edema resulting from air embolism.

VAE refers to the entrapment of exogenously delivered gas or air into the venous vasculature resulting in systemic effects. It may occur during surgeries like sitting neurological procedures (posterior cranial fossa surgeries), obstetrics, and orthopedic surgeries. Other causes include mechanical insufflation during laparoscopic surgeries, iatrogenic air entry during venous catheterization and dysbarism. 

VAE should be considered when unexplained hypotension or a sudden fall in end-tidal CO2 level occurs intraoperatively in high-risk cases. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: 190. Your friend, as a part of her fitness routine, performs the plank as shown in the image below. Which of the following cardiovascular parameters show relatively minimal change in her body?
questions.solution:
During isometric exercises such as the plank, the cardiovascular parameter that shows minimal change is stroke volume.

At the start of an isometric exercise, heart rate (option D) increases, primarily due to a reduction in vagal tone (vagal discharge). Psychological stimulation acts on medulla oblongata and reduces the vagal tone with sympathetic activation playing a secondary role.

As the exercise progresses, both systolic and diastolic blood pressures (options B and C) rise significantly, as muscle tension increases vascular resistance. However, stroke volume shows only a slight change due to the decreased venous return caused by sustained muscle contraction.

In contrast, during isotonic exercises (like running), the increase in stroke volume is more substantial, driven by enhanced venous return and myocardial contractility. Systolic pressure increases moderately, while diastolic pressure either remains stable or decreases due to the vasodilation of peripheral blood vessels.

Length of muscle Decrease Increase Same
Tension Same Same Increase
Movement Against resistance With resistance Nil
Peak tension: Amount of resistance More More Less
Example Biceps during the upward phase of the exercise Biceps during the downward phase of the exercise When biceps is holding the weight still

questions.text:
191. A 50-year-old patient with a history of acute PE five years back presents with increasing dyspnea and exercise intolerance over one year. Echocardiography shows severe tricuspid regurgitation with estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure of 38 mm Hg. NT-proBNP levels are elevated. A ventilation perfusion scan was performed, and multiple segmental mismatched perfusion defects were observed. CTPA identified eccentric filling defects in pulmonary vessels. Which WHO group of the disease does this case fall into?

PE: Pulmonary Embolism

NT-pro BNP: N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide

CTPA: CT- Pulmonary Angiography
questions.solution:
The given case falls under WHO Group 4.

The given clinical scenario where a man presents with dyspnea and exercise intolerance, and ECHO shows severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) with estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure >35mm Hg with serum NT-proBNP levels elevated, are suggestive of pulmonary hypertension with strain on the right heart. 

Based on past history of PE, combined with V/Q scan (ventilation- perfusion scan) findings of mismatched perfusion defects combined with filling defects in pulmonary vessels on CTPA, are highly suggestive of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension(CTEPH). CTEPH is a WHO Group 4 condition causing pulmonary hypertension.

Pulmonary hypertension is divided into 5 groups by the WHO (2018) classification. Preliminary diagnosis of PH requires a mean Pulmonary Arterial Pressure (mPAP)of >20mm Hg measured by right heart catheterization(RHC) across all 5 groups. Further, to identify whether the cause is precapillary, postcapillary or mixed, the Pulmonary artery wedge pressure(PAWP) and the Pulmonary vascular resistance(PVR) are calculated.

 GROUP CAUSE PAWP & PVR
Group 1 Pulmonary arterial hypertension

Group 3 PH due to chronic lung disease/ sleep disordered breathing

CTEPH is an uncommon but important cause of pulmonary hypertension. The usual presentation is an individual who may have a history of pulmonary embolic events (many times no such history is present as the thromboemboli are subclinical) who presents with symptoms of right heart decompensation such as dyspnea, ascites, peripheral edemas, elevated JVP, etc.

On evaluation, ECHO may show tricuspid regurgitation and elevated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure. Elevated NT-proBNP and BNP indicated right heart strain. Further RHC will show isolated precapillary pulmonary hypertension. Two investigations that help confirm the diagnosis are 

V/Q scan, which shows areas of mismatched perfusion due to old thrombi causing low blood flow to some areas CTPA(CT Pulmonary Angiography) shows mosaic attenuation in bilateral lung fields and may also show filling defects in the pulmonary vasculature indicating thromboemboli. Further, investigations like d-dimer support the diagnosis.

Treatment of CTEPH involves surgical pulmonary thrombectomy and embolectomy followed by medical management with drugs like ambrisentan. Anticoagulation is also warranted with drugs like warfarin. In recurrent cases or those who don't qualify for surgery, Riociguat is used.

questions.text: 192. One year ago, a 60-year-old man was diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma and treated for it. At present, on further evaluation of this patient, you suspect him to have Trousseau’s syndrome. Which of the following features helped you come to this diagnosis?

choices.text: Recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs
Enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node
Contraction facial muscles on tapping over facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear.
Painful carpopedal spasm on applying inflated sphygmomanometer cuff above the systolic blood pressure.

questions.solution:
The coexistence of recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs(migratory thrombophlebitis) with visceral carcinoma, particularly pancreatic cancer, is called Trousseau’s syndrome.



It is a paraneoplastic syndrome, also known as Trousseau's sign of malignancy, and is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumour or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur.

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in: 

* Pancreatic cancer (most common)

* Lung cancer

* Gastrointestinal cancer

* Ovarian cancer

* Prostate cancer

* Lymphoma

Other options:

Option B: Troisier sign is the clinical finding of a hard and enlarged left supraclavicular node (Virchow node), and is considered a sign of metastatic abdominal malignancy.

Option C: Chvostek sign is contraction of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear.

Option D: Trousseau sign is accoucheur’s hand position which is a painful carpopedal spasm on applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure for 5 minutes.

Both Chvostek and Trousseau signs are seen in hypocalcemic tetany. Image showing Trousseau sign:

questions.text: 193. Identify the histological section of an abdominal organ from the image below.
questions.solution:
The histological section shown in the above image is the spleen. 

The spleen is histologically composed of:

* White pulp - For some distance, each arteriole is surrounded by a dense sheath of lymphocytes. These lymphocytes constitute the white pulp of the spleen.

* Penicilli - The arteriole then divides into a number of straight vessels that are called penicilli.

* Ellipsoid - Each of the penicilli shows a localized thickening of its wall that is called an ellipsoid. The ellipsoid consists of concentric lamellae formed by the aggregation of fibroblasts and macrophages.

* Ampulla - Distal to the ellipsoid, the vessel dilates to form an ampulla, the walls of which become continuous with the reticular framework.

* Red pulp - As a result, blood flows into spaces lined by reticular cells, coming into direct contact with lymphocytes there. The part of splenic tissue, which is infiltrated with blood in this way is called the red pulp.

* Sinusoids - Blood from spaces of the red pulp is collected by wide sinusoids that drain into veins in the trabeculae.

The splenic artery after entering the hilum of the spleen divides into about five branches that enter the organ independently. Each branch divides and subdivides as it travels through the trabecular network. Arterioles arising from this network leave the trabeculae to pass into the inter-trabecular spaces.

Stave cells: The sinusoids of the spleen are lined by a somewhat modified endothelium. The endothelial cells here are elongated and shaped like bananas. They are referred to as stave cells.

The image given below shows the histological section of the spleen.

questions.text: 194. A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room with fever and hypotension. She has rigors, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Her BP is 70/50 mmHg; SpO2, 89%; respiratory rate, 26/min; pulse, 140 bpm; and temperature, 39.5°C. She opens her eyes when you ask her to do so, produces only sounds, and withdraws her leg when you stroke it with the knee hammer. What is the qSOFA score of this patient?
questions.solution:
qSOFA score for this patient would be 3. Only 3 parameters are considered for its calculation, and the respective scores are as follows:

* BP: 70/50 mmHg → Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg) → Score 1

* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min → High (≥22 breaths/min) → Score 1

* Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score: 9/15 → Altered mentation (GCS score, <15) → Score 1

* Opens her eyes on command -E3

* Produces only sounds-V2

* Withdraws leg when stroked with the knee hammer-M4

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

* low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),

* high respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min),

* altered mentation (GCS score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis. This is a simplified derivative of SOFA score. The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score, which includes assessment of:

* Circulation - Systolic BP and need for vasopressors; platelet count

* Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 and need for mechanical ventilation

* Mentation - Glasgow Coma Scale score 

* Hepatic function - Bilirubin level

* Renal function - Creatinine level

A SOFA score of ≥2 defines organ dysfunction. Another score that has been used is the National Early Warning Score (NEWS). It ranges from 0 to 20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature, systolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and level of consciousness. ≥5 out of 20 is considered a positive score. 

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

* The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

* The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System (LODS) score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

Pearl PM1636: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

* Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count

* Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation

* Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)

* Hepatic function - Bilirubin

* Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

* Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg

* Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min

* Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

* SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.

* qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

* Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 OR

* Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: 195. A 24-year-old woman who is two weeks postpartum was brought by her husband due to extreme tiredness. She gave birth to a healthy baby at term through vaginal delivery. However, post-delivery, she had post-partum hemorrhage and received 3 units of packed red blood cells. He reports that she has been unable to produce breast milk. On examination, her pulse is 96 bpm and blood pressure is 80/50 mm of Hg. Which of the following sets of serum findings are likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of fatigue, failure of lactation, and hypotension following post-partum haemorrhage is suggestive of Sheehan's syndrome, which causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. There is a decrease in the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) which results in decreased cortisol.

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk for haemorrhage and infarction. 

It can present acutely with sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS haemorrhage and death.

Also, it can present late with the following features:

* Lactation failure due to prolactin deficiency

* Amenorrhea due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity

* Loss of pubic and axillary hair

* Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 

* Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Damage to the pituitary results in decreased production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) causing secondary adrenal insufficiency which in turn results in decreased cortisol levels. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone production is relatively preserved as it is independent of ACTH. It is the most life-threatening complication.

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

Other options:

Options A and B: This patient does not have any signs of hypercortisolism like moon facies, buffalo hump, truncal obesity, purple striae, or hypertension. Cortisol production is decreased in secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Option C: Decreased cortisol and increased ACTH is seen in primary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol production is decreased due to a primary adrenal disorder which in turn causes an increase in ACTH by negative feedback. These patients present with symptoms of low cortisol such as fatigue, loss of energy, and hypotension. A distinguishing feature in primary adrenal insufficiency is hyperpigmentation, due to stimulation of melanocytes by excess ACTH (molecular similarity with melanocyte-stimulating hormone). In primary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone and adrenal androgen levels are also decreased.

questions.text: 196. A 38-year-old multigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presented to the outpatient department with a history of painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is a fall in fetal heart rate when the fetal head is pushed into the pelvis. Identify the true statement about the condition associated with the sign described.

choices.text: Transabdominal sonography is the most accurate method of assessment.
MR imaging has replaced sonography in diagnosis.
Per vaginal examination should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of painless vaginal bleeding with positive Stallworthy's sign is suggestive of placenta previa and the true statement associated with it is per vaginal examination should be avoided, as it can lead to torrential hemorrhage.

Stallworthy's sign refers to the slowing of the fetal heart rate when the head is pressed down into the pelvis. It recovers as soon as the pressure is released. It is suggestive of the presence of a low-lying placenta, particularly if located on the posterior wall of the uterus. 

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include

* Previous cesarian section

* Myomectomy

* Advanced maternal age (>35 years)

* Smoking

* multiple gestation

* Multiparity

* Prior curettage

Diagnosis :

* Transabdominal sonography: A quick and accurate localization can be accomplished if the placenta clearly overlies the cervix or if it lies away from the lower uterine segment. Its limitations include:

* Poor visualization in obese women

* A full bladder may give a false impression that the placenta is overlying the cervix.

* Transvaginal sonography: The most accurate method to assess the placental location. It is not contraindicated in placenta previa and is safe even when there is bleeding.

* MRI: Localizes placental location excellently, gold standard but does not replace sonography in routine diagnosis.

* In case of inconclusive USG reports or USG revealed type 1 placenta, a vaginal examination is done in operation theatre under anesthesia. This is done with preparation for an immediate cesarean section. 

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment.

* Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.

* Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.

* Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).

* Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.



Note: For clinical purpose, the types are graded into,

* Mild degree (Type-I and II anterior) and

* Major degree (Type-II posterior, III, and IV).

questions.text: 197. A 25-year-old male agricultural worker presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sweating, and generalized weakness. He handles fresh tobacco leaves without any protective gear. There is no history of ingestion of any toxic compounds. On examination, he has tachycardia and hypotension. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sweating, generalized weakness, tachycardia, and hypotension in an agricultural worker who handles fresh tobacco leaves without any protective gear point towards Green tobacco sickness.

Green tobacco sickness (GTS) occurs due to dermal absorption of nicotine while handling fresh tobacco leaves. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, diaphoresis, weakness, and cardiovascular manifestations like tachycardia and hypotension, which typically resolve with symptomatic treatment.

Other Options:

Option A: Chronic Nicotine Poisoning occurs due to long-term tobacco use (e.g., smoking, chewing). Symptoms include chronic bronchitis, cardiovascular disease (hypertension, arrhythmias), Buerger’s disease, anxiety, headache, and tremors. This patient has acute symptoms from occupational exposure, ruling out chronic nicotine poisoning.

Option C: Organophosphate Poisoning causes a cholinergic crisis with SLUDGE symptoms (Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Diarrhea, GI distress, Emesis). OP poisoning causes bradycardia and miosis (constricted pupils), while GTS causes tachycardia and sweating.

Option D: Pyrethroid Poisoning occurs due to exposure to insecticides. It causes neurotoxic symptoms like paresthesia, tremors, burning sensation, muscle fasciculations, and seizures.

questions.text: 198. A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

* The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.

* If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.

* If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: 200. Intrinsic resistance of gram-negative bacteria to linezolid is mediated by __________.
questions.solution:
The intrinsic resistance of gram-negative bacteria to linezolid is mediated by endogenous efflux pumps.

Linezolid is a bacteriostatic agent used to treat resistant gram-positive bacteria, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE). It has excellent oral bioavailability. Prolonged therapy is associated with myelosuppression as well as ocular and reversible peripheral neuropathy.
